Look. like everyone here, the game is fantastic, for RPG players and story driven content the game is really something else. The voice acting is next level.

But the game has its issues.

1. Companions often trigger traps when you are not directly controlling each one in turn base mode when you encounter them. Its really frustrating.

2. Autosave is NOT auto save. Auto save in the last I dunno 10 years has been a feature that saves every so often with at least 3 saves from the past 20-30mins of play, This is true autosave. The game right now as it stands SUCKS with saving. I am so used to playing games with autosave features that work properly that constantly having to press F5 and having to remind myself IN GAME when the game is sooo GOD DAMN immersing is beyond frustrating. I am often losing 30-45 mins of game play because you are throw into some insane situations suddenly that wipe your party. I really don't understand why the devs have not or will not implement this feature. Its basic. U can add slider bars for penis size but you cant add a simple quality of life feature? That has been around for a long time?

3. Dialog miss click results in frustrating play. When you are interacting with game environments and there are a lot of things to click sometimes you miss click on a companion, and if you don't correct quickly often opens up into the dialog box. I am had this occur often and its jarring. Allow a option to key bind this to a shift modifier so that when I hold down shift and click a companion only then will it open a dialog box.
Must have RPG if you love D&D, from the story to the mechanics it is incredibly hard to fault this amazing game. Single player and Co-Op, with online and LAN options. An addictive 11/10!

I'll do the dislikes first as there are not many,

Dislike: Sometimes combat can bug out and people wont make their move for some time and can cause a crash, Its super rare and if you kill them before a turn it wont happen. Some dialog is still silent but its getting patched out every time so less and less its likely to happen.

Like: The STORY. It is that simple the game just keeps throwing things at you time and time again. Some of them you can see coming if you read books and pay attention but i lost track how many times this story had me in my emotions. Also, the replay value is insane in this game. Every single time i play it i still find something new to see or a new option that opens more talking that i did not see before, and i have gone through act 1 at least 5 times. Not counting the other acts because i can only imagine the things i have missed in them. Lastly what ill say is that every character has their own quirks and ways of looking at everything you do it cant even be counted (though i am sure it has) the special interactions you will have if you take the time to just talk with everyone in party/camp. 

Anyway enough on that. Basically i would 10/10 say this game is worth the money you will pay, and the time you put into this game will very likely be remembered for years to come.

this game came out and is still unfinished. maybe people only played up until act 2 but my drive to play this game was completely destroyed by the dozens of updates that not only added content that should;ve been there in the first place, but fixed things i could've used 280 hours ago. 280 unpleasant hours of getting all my weak sissy characters to jump 3 meters, 280 hours of not being able to edit my character (i restarted my first playthrough bc of this), 280 hours of buggy, see through environments, 280 hours of disappointment. is it wrong for me to be frusturated that the devs couldnt have waited idk a couple months to release this? or idk... maybe do the thing that made act 1 run so well *cough* playtesting *cough*

i also got complaints about the story being really uninteresting for the amount of urgency its given. i just dont think the story is good. there are interesting moments here and there but almost all of your gameplay is combat and the only worthwhile dialogue comes from a select few companions. also maybe its just me, but the inclusion of internet humor about your game is so fucking cringe theres a reason tik tok commenters arent in the writing room. leave the cringe to those people, come up with your own stuff its so much better.

last thing, what is this sorry excuse of a cc? they get all the social justice points for the pronouns and the option to have both boobs and penis, but the protag is silent, and the facial animations just cycle through 4 attempts of what could be perceived as an "expression" what use is it to have such a limited CC if your character doesnt even do anything that intense with its face? bethesda managed with the freeform CC, why cant larian? idk, maybe if the presets werent so fucking ugly i wouldnt be complaining, but its true. unless you're a twink half elf or somehow manage to find 1 good face for any other race, all the faces are ugly. whats even worse is that these faces are also on the random npcs you talk to throughout the game. which means that you'll most likely run into an npc who looks exactly like your character, completely destroying your sense of individuality. imagine if skyrim only let you use the faces of other npcs, youd be pretty disappointed, right?

[None Spoiler Review]

Baldur's Gate 3 is a triumph in the world of role-playing games, offering a rich and immersive experience that is sure to captivate players.

The world is a beautifully crafted fantasy realm that feels alive and vibrant. From the bustling city streets to the eerie dungeons and lush forests, every corner of the world is filled with detail and intrigue. The lore of the world is deep and complex, drawing players in with its history, myths, and mysteries waiting to be uncovered.

In my opinion, the companions you find along the way are truly the heart of the game. Each character is expertly written and brought to life with engaging dialogue, nuanced personalities, and compelling backstories. Whether you're forming alliances, making difficult decisions, or engaging in heartfelt conversations, each and every one feel like real individuals with their own hopes, fears, and desires.

Visually, Baldur's Gate 3 is a masterpiece. The game features stunning graphics that showcase detailed character models, lush landscapes, and dynamic lighting effects. Exploring the world is a visual delight, with every area exuding a unique atmosphere that draws players deeper into the game's world.

The soundtrack is equally impressive, with a sweeping orchestral score that sets the perfect tone for each moment of the game. From epic battles to quiet moments of reflection, the music enhances the overall experience and adds depth to the game's world and characters.

In conclusion, Baldur's Gate 3 is a standout RPG that excels in world-building, lore, character development, visuals, and soundtrack. It is a testament to the power of storytelling in gaming and a must-play for any fan of the genre.

The adventure. The lore. The drama. The love. The grief. The lust. The unforseenable. The challenge. This game has it all, and even more. I say, for I felt a bit like an orphan for great RPG games, Larian has made a masterpiece! Looking forward to what's next for them, and wishing the team all the best. You guys and gals brought me back to the good ol' days when Bioware made this very kind of game-experience, captivating and incredibly in depth.
Here's to a new dawn for gloriously made role-playing games! KUDOS <3

One of the most striking aspects of Baldur's Gate 3 is its commitment to narrative depth and player agency. From the moment you step into the shoes of your chosen character, you're thrust into a richly realized world teeming with lore, intrigue, and moral ambiguity. Every decision you make, whether in dialogue or action, carries weight and consequence, shaping not only the outcome of your own journey but also the fate of the world around you. This level of narrative complexity is a rarity in modern gaming, where linear storytelling often takes precedence over player-driven experiences. Baldur's Gate 3 reminds us of the power of choice and consequence, reigniting our passion for interactive storytelling in the process.
It's a very good representation of Dungeons and Dragons. Sure, some rules differences but mostly true to mood and theme and versatility.

Great game and well worth the money. I've already been playing for more than 50 hours and haven't even gotten to act 3. I can already tell that there will be a lot of replay value based on the number of ways the game can go and choices you make.

Excellent story, cinematics, voice acting, I really enjoyed it.  I definitely recommend it.

There are frustrating glitches and bugs that are constantly in your face.  The camera moves automatically during combat to give you a better view, often it moves to give you a closeup of a roof, or an arch, or a hill and you can't see what happened.  Often it is impossible to click on the floor beyond the doorway, it targets the doorway itself unless you manually move the camera.  You have limited control of the camera, it would be nice to be able to control elevation.  Inventory is frustrating to work with.  There is much polishing yet to be done to provide a smooth experience without frustration.  The mechanics of BG2 were done better.

Also, I wish there were six characters in the party, like BG2, instead of only four.

What can I even say about this game that hasn't been said? Maybe one of the greatest and *most accessible* RPGs of all time. While I'm not extremely familiar with all the old DnD RPGs of the past, out of all the DnD RPGs I've played, this one felt the most like a traditional campaign. The freedom, the atmosphere, and the story are all top top tier. While I am eagerly awaiting the DLC, the beauty of BG3 is that you can do countless play-throughs and have exciting and unique experiences each time. Truly in a league of it's own and Larian deserves their flowers.

Great game with an incredible amount of replay value. HOWEVER! The bugs! I PERSONALLY have no played a game with so many bugs. I never played Cyberpunk or any of those other games that were trash on launch. I know of them but again I didn't play them. I did play this game though and I haven't had a single play session without multiple bugs or crashes or something happening. 185 hours so far and so much of the good is overshadowed by how obnoxious it is to play the game, to the point where I don't even want to play because I know there's going to be some bugs or crashes that's going to ruin the experience. The game has been out for far too long to justify the incredible amount of bugs and crashes still occurring or how insanely long it's taking to fix them. Shield bash straight up did nothing for over 6 months. Other games would not get away with this but BG3 gets a pass.....for some reason. It's really sad to see such a great game be plagued by so many issues. I hope Larian hires another person or 2 to help speed things up because It's not shocking to me that people aren't even clearing Act 1. It's a lot of game to play which means there's more opportunities to see issues. Worth the money. Larian and BG3 deserve the praise. But they also need to step it up.

I was a complete noob when I started playing this game - the last time I played a game was over 20 years ago (Maple Story beta), so this was a steep introduction to video game literacy and D&D lore. However, I was frustrated with all the inane dialogue choices that my partner was making in his play-through in the background that I wound up creating my character on his computer and playing for around 70 hours before eventually buying a new computer so that I could play my own copy. Some initial mistakes that I made:

- Died in tutorial after mucking about in acid and not noticing the changes in stats on the overwhelming number of displays on all corners of the screen 
- Did not level up my characters until my partner noticed the screen stats
- Attempted to cast Detect Thoughts, Talk to Animals during battle
- Bypassed key characters who were "right there" (according to my partner) because I couldn't read the environment and map
- Did not understand that italicised dialogue options were actions, triggering fights
- Tried to play catch with Scratch by throwing the ball at him, triggering a fight in camp
- Trusted Gale to show me magic
- Hated Astarion's unwarranted snark and disapprovals of my choices; kept him in my party anyway because locks
- Recast Call Lightning because I didn't know that it was a continuous spell ready in my side panel
- Did not understand the concept of video game time and felt genuinely rushed to complete (and loot) things before key events transpired

I've just completed my first play-through in a little over 180 hours (before my partner did) and even got comfortable creating small video tutorials to friends who just started playing!

if only steam had a mixed / neutral rating, but i still had alot of fun going through the entire game with my friends so i'll still recommend it. the entire playthrough ([spoiler]up till the reunion party after you beat the Netherbrain[/spoiler]) took about 78 hours to complete on Balanced mode.

im not the biggest fan of DnD as i find it kinda boring, so i was hesitant to get this game when my friends suggested i give it a shot and run a campaign with them. i'm glad i did, as i had a good time exploring every nook and cranny of Faerun with them. finding new secrets and lore at places you least expect is also exciting. what i do like the most are the characters, as all of them are just so full of personality and charm (even the NPCs). we recruited every possible playable companions and completed their questlines, and the payoff for doing so is definitely rewarding.

final fight spoilers: [spoiler]the fight against the Netherbrain was honestly hype, seeing as all the other NPCs you've befriended come to assist you. reading their letters at the reunion party was honestly pretty sweet as well (funny with Harleep's).[/spoiler]


however, i find the story extremely lacking. the initial premise was great! the urgency to get the tadpole off our brains and trying to foil the Absolute's plans really hooked me in. however, there's just so much wasted potential in [spoiler]the entirety of Act 3[/spoiler]. the main villains' actions, [spoiler]mainly Gortash[/spoiler], are just kinda questionable. [spoiler]why did Gortash not only lay down his guard around us, but also expect us to not betray him when he offered to cooperate with us?[/spoiler]. i also don't really enjoy DnD style combat  where it's all just dice rolls and checks, but thats a me problem. there are also some bugs and glitches here and there, but those are easily fixable so its not a big deal.

overall, i still had a really fun time with the game, especially when playing the campaign with friends. i do feel like the game is way too overhyped though. it's definitely a good game with a lot of love and care put into it, but i do not think it is the "genre defining" or "game of the generation" people are claiming this to be.

I want to preface this by saying - Larian is generally a shining light in a dark and depressing space. Most game companies focus on taking as much money as possible from their players, and Larian is focused on making fun, interesting games.

I have to recommend that no Mac player buy this game, however. I repeat, if you have a Mac - DO NOT BUY THIS GAME. 

I only get a few hours a week to play BG3, and I have a party with PC friends. At this point, our weekly game sessions are presumed cancelled because Larian keeps releasing updates for PC well ahead of Mac - with absolutely no information on when Mac players can expect updates. It has caused the cancellation of nearly 50% of our planned game sessions, and I am finding it so frustrating that I may put the game down until it is sorted out.

Larian - get it together. I appreciate that you make BG3 for Macs, too. But please - just release the updates all at the same time.

Having companions that compliment you and praise you, not just with their words, but their deeds... and their responses are what would any person want in real life!
May it be a "good" run or an "evil' run, the companions will continue to praise your Tav (the player). I think this is what make me come back for more. 
Of course, your usual "great graphics and story - superbly written and fully voiced acted by talented individuals" are there,  but what makes Baldur's Gate 3 stand out is the experience and immersion that player feels. Very addictive and intoxicating... And of course, I am talking about Astarion.
Maybe I am enjoying Baldur's Gate 3 differently than what the creators intended. But I'm still enjoying it nonetheless. Thank you for making this and sharing it to the world. ^_^

Larian Studios has once again outdone themselves, crafting an experience that feels both nostalgically familiar to fans of the classic RPGs and refreshingly innovative for newcomers.

Graphics and Atmosphere: The game's visuals are stunning, with beautifully rendered landscapes, meticulously detailed character models, and fluid animations that breathe life into every encounter. The atmospheric lighting and weather effects immerse you fully into the Forgotten Realms, making each exploration and battle a feast for the eyes.

Gameplay Mechanics: Baldur's Gate 3 strikes a perfect balance between tactical combat and narrative depth. The turn-based combat is challenging and rewarding, requiring thoughtful planning and strategy. The addition of environmental interactions and verticality adds a new layer of tactical depth that is genuinely engaging. Outside of combat, the game offers a wealth of exploration, dialogue options, and side quests that are as compelling as the main storyline.

Story and Characters: The narrative is where Baldur's Gate 3 truly shines. The story is intricate, filled with twists, turns, and moral dilemmas that test your resolve and shape the world around you. The characters are wonderfully written, each with their own backgrounds, motivations, and emotional depth. Building relationships with your party members feels meaningful, with dialogue options that genuinely impact the story's progression and outcomes.

Baldur's Gate 3 is among the best fantasy turn-based RPG's ever made. Compared to its peers, it is not possible NOT to recommend it. There is really only one title it CAN be compared to; Larian's predecessor, Divinity 2: Original Sin. And so, compare them I will. 

I played the original Baldur's Gate and Baldur's Gate 2. They were revolutionary games for their time. To be honest, BG3 only improved on them (and Divinity 2: Original Sin) in two areas: overall graphics and voice-acting. These are AAA worthy, and among the best in the genre. I took for granted how everything looked after being wowed by the initial cut-scenes, but did admire it on many occasions. In particular, characters are rendered excellently. 

Combat remains enjoyable, though only a few areas had much challenge on default difficulty setting. On the plus side, I never felt grinding was needed to level up fully. Like D2: OS, maps have enough to explore without getting bogged down or getting lost. This may not be a good thing for those that like YUGE maps, or more open-ended exploration. Personally I feel the approach they used is best for the story-driven RPG. 

BG3 gave me over 100 hours and is certainly worth the coin, even at full price, which I paid as tribute to Larian for their masterful Divinity 2: Original Sin (I gave 10/10). Now we turn to my quibbles, of which there were none in Divinity 2. 

The story: I expected a masterpiece, like Divinity 2. The first two acts were good, but the main plot was rather stupid TBH. A giant brain flying around wearing a sort of crown? Really? That's the best they could come up with? The giant brain is co-controlled by three bosses you'll have to fight. The first in Act 2 was good, both in backstory and quests. The last two were contrived and (sorry Larian) boring. Yes, in Act 3--Baldur's Gate itself...what should have been the climax became mostly slog and boredom. Should I not have been yearning to play each night, well past my normal bedtime, like the best games bring out? 

Soooo, exploring the city, I soon notice a lot of the characters look and talk like oddly dressed 21st century Americans. Black, White, and other ethnic groups all have in common vapid small-talk. Some of the city guard are midgets, and while not as annoying as the ones in Cyberpunk 2077 that seem to be everywhere, we do have to suffer through the least likely Medieval fighting unit, a black female midget sagely investigating a murder. Remember the South Park episode when Cartman dreamed they were all replaced by more....diverse....actors? That is what Baldur's Gate has become. There is also lots of gay characters and you will be hit on by more than one, including a shirtless tentacled alien, even if by your choices its clear you are not gay. 

The gay elf vampire kind of grew on me, but his story-line is FAR from original and though we did eventually get a good boss fight out of it, his whole quest/plot seemed out of place. The githyanki main character was irritating, and I disliked her whole ugly reptilian race. 

Shadowheart...now here is a lovely elf with a dark backstory that was quite intriguing. Didn't hurt that she was very pretty. In fact, clearly the ability exists to make attractive characters in this game, yet the population is mostly unattractive. That IS real life, but this if fantasy! It would have been nice to see more beautiful characters. 

The odd colored people with goat-horns were okay, but were yet another refugee subplot. The fact that we've had 10,000,000 migrants cross our border in the past few years makes this particular plot (the city of BG is also full of refugees) unwelcome. 

Gods....this was an interesting addition to the game, and could have been more fully developed. 

Jumping? No....just no. 

Traps...gotta grind through them, borrrrrring. 

Feminine rage: thankfully mostly contained in the annoying githyanki character, at least without delving into such questions as "Why are all the mindlfayers male?" When you see a female NPC at the end savagely pitchfork one through the heart, the thought dawned that the mindflayers could be symbolic of an evil patriarchy corrupting society. Then again, there was an evil female Hag character, so I'm probably reading too much into that. 

Where does Larian go from here? I hope they keep Woke out, but suspect more will creep into their next title. 

Final score: 8/10. 9/10 compared to others in the genre, but 7/10 compared with Divinity 2: Original Sin.

This is the best game I've played this decade and is in my top 5 of all time games. The music is some of the best I've heard and up there with DOOM, Star Wars, Skyrim and RDR2. The gameplay is fun and engaging. You can do most anything you can think of. Turn an enemy into a sheep and chuck it, sure. Have an owl bear jump onto a 400hp boss and one hit it, that works too. I've only played D&D once and it was fairly easy to pick up the rules of the game. 

The acting is phenomenal and the best I have seen in any video game. The story line is engaging and the companions feel real. I still tear up at the end of most of their quest lines. If you have any interest in RPG's, story based games, turn based combat, and to say goodbye to your life besides this game, then buy it! You won't regret it.

Never got past act 1 and I don't think I ever will. It's not for me and I can't figure out exactly why. I have more than 800 hours in Pathfinder: Wrath of the Righteous, so it can't be anything related to it being a CRPG. It might be a "death by a thousand cuts" situation. Just a million small things that I don't like which added up to ruin the overall experience for me. Some of them might be fixable, like the mess that is inventory management, but most are stylistic choices, so there's nothing really to "fix".
For example, I hate Lae'zel, Shadowheart, Astarion, and Gale. It wasn't until I met Wyll that I found an origin character I liked. I also like Karlach btw. While this alone didn't kill the game for me, it added up to my pile of "things that annoy me in BG3". In the end the whole game just doesn't work with me, it's fine, but I can't be bothered to keep playing. It's still a good game, just not one that works with my specific taste, and that's why I'm leaving a positive review. If I had to give a personal rating, however, and this is just by my tastes and standards, I'd give it a 4/10.

After finally finishing this game at 105 hours i'd like to give a comparison of this game, and another that was released in the same year, that are only 10gb different in size. Star Wars Jedi: Survivor (130gbs) and BG3 (140gbs)
I finished survivor in 23 hours and haven't played it since, it has no repeatability as there are no choices to make in the game. The only reason to keep playing after completing the game is to unlock and find cosmetics for your Cal Kestis. That's it. And i didn't do that because i absolutely hate doing stuff like that because it isn't fun. The story is okay, the fights are fun but that's all it is. It doesn't give you anything else apart from that. It's an incredibly large game too, 130gbs for no repeatability, no story choices, and cosmetics? 

BG3 is 140gbs, and in that game is something with almost infinite repeatability, exceptional depth and attention to detail and incredibly involving choices, dialogue, and characters. Where Survivor only had a few main characters with minimal story telling or character development, BG3 has exceptional character development and an unparalleled story. 

I cannot recommend BG3 more, it is utterly impeccable.

Ive seen some negative reviews and Im not really sure why. While I havent played BG1, BG2 or Neverwinter Nights in like 15+ years, this game really hits the spot and feels just right. Took me a couple hours to really get comfortable with what you can do in the world as far as jumping over obstacles, shooting arrows at hanging baskets of fire, etc. You can think outside of the box when you encounter enemies - I took out an entire room secretly by staying in the shadows. 

Im sure if I went back and played the originals that there would be elements I like and dislike about both the new and the old, but overall, I would definitely recommend this game if you like this style of game play. 

Edit: Ive since started a second play through on Honor Mode. Went through my first game as a good aligned Barbarian and Im doing the second play through as an evil-neutral style Wizard with the dark urge. Even though I specifically sought out every single little thing and quest I could find, I somehow still missed some stuff on my first play through that Im discovering in the second. 

Playing as a different class and forcing myself to choose more of the evil dialogue options has really made the game feel completely different. Interactions with quite a few NPCs has resulted in a different direction for some quests and/or opened up quests that I never had before and canceled quests that I did.

I wish to give this a neutral, but seeing as there are overwhelmingly positive reviews already, I will give the thumbs down.
The game is a masterpiece in storytelling, and role playing, but sadly it is just frustrating to play. I get the game mechanics follow DnD closely, but this is at the expense of a fun game. Each encounter feels like a slog, the constant long rests after every single fight, the save scumming and long load times, getting stuck in endless skip turns due to some obscure enemy spell and needing just the right counter spell, constantly missing attacks and spells when there is a 90% chance, and then if you do hit - the enemy health goes to 1 and they kill you next turn. There's also the quality of life improvements that are missing to help with the overwhelming need to customize each fight - why can't I quickly dismiss companions from the main map? Why can't I see my full inventory from the camp? Why are there so many variations of each type of armor and weapon - which makes choosing the best one like writing a research paper? 
If you fully understand the DnD mechanics, you will surely like this. Otherwise I only recommend picking this up if you use cheats. 
Lastly, to prove my enthusiasm for the game's quality, I recommend that if you pick it up to pay full price - Larian deserves it.

I'm not going to say this is a bad game, but I will say it is over hyped 100%. I feel like they expect people to have played 1 and 2, which leads to many mechanics not being explained. Many parts of the story provide the illusion of choice. If you reload and try every option, most of the time there is only one outcome. Combat and load outs are not explained making the first hour or so frustrating.
Incredible story, awesome writing, has to be one of the best games of the decade :D

enemy turns are too long, dice rolls u can speed up only a little, running outside combat is too slow... I mean this game just don't respect ur time at all; no matter if we compare it to other turn-combat games, where we have XCOM2 (2016!) with zip mode where all animations are speed up or JA3 where enemies move at triple the pace and ur party get the speed boost outside combat, or to classic crpg with the active pause like BG2 (nice "upgrade" xD) where u play the game all the time and not just half the time or Deadfire where u can just speed up time up or down as u wish, it's just bad design.

I srsly can't play this game without a TV show in the background or playing Hearthstone on my phone during enemy turns... 

Also, almost all of the available companions are boring... ppl like this game for romance, but all I see is a group of thirsty teenagers following me around, and the wampire is just rapey. Look at Deadfire or the new Torment, even Divinity 2, an older game of the same studio as BG3 (!), has great companions with character and unique vibe each.

SF plot of alien invasion in a fantasy world is good (not as good as a mid book about the topic, but good for a game) and many sidequests are amazing, but go the evil route, this way u get to interact with all the cool characters, almost every good character is boring (in the Act 1 at least), but it's a sin of the franchise since BG1, so maybe they are just for different target audience... but I hate being evil, so it's an unpleasant dissonance for an RPG.

6/10, will finish it once and have a good time, but for comparison, BG2 I've beaten like 10 times, and by the title I thought I was target audience, but nope, not at all.

Baldur's Gate 3: An Epic Adventure with Infinite Possibilities!

Dive into the captivating world of Baldur's Gate 3 and get ready for a journey of excitement and laughter! This game has everything a gamer's heart desires and more.

The story is so gripping that it draws you in and you simply can't stop. Every step holds new secrets and unexpected twists that keep you glued to the screen and fuel your curiosity.

The gameplay is a true thrill! With each move, there are new challenges to master and exciting battles to engage in. The variety of options keeps boredom at bay and ensures that you are constantly evolving and improving.

But the best part about Baldur's Gate 3 is definitely the fun factor, especially when playing with friends. The shared adventures bring an extra dose of humor and joy to the game. There's nothing better than roaming the world with your crew and facing epic battles together!

Baldur's Gate 3 is more than just a game - it's an experience! A must for anyone looking for an entertaining and challenging adventure. Those who don't try this game are definitely missing out on something amazing!

And the best part: Baldur's Gate 3 offers countless outcomes and decisions that influence the course of the story. This makes the game even more fabulous and promises endless hours of excitement and surprises!

Let's dive into the world of Baldur's Gate 3 together and experience adventures we'll never forget!
The sheer choices alone in this game to influence the out come and the incredible room for creativity is enough to keep me coming back for more.

It helped distract me and gave me something to look forward to at the end of the day; it re-sparked my love for game development too! This game is definitely one of my favorite games. Everything about it is just so amazing and it's my first big turn based game. I love how involved Larian is with the fan base, which is so nice to see! I wish I could play for the first time again. This game is by far my favorite video game ever made and will most likely continue to stay that way. Here's some pros and cons I have shambled together.

-PROS
--Easy to understand gameplay for both newbies and those familiar with D&D
--Compelling and intriguing character personalities and narratives
--The ability to play with or without friends (you need friends for D&D womp womp)
--Pretty good character creator
--LOTS of tiny things that warrant other playthroughs to check out
--Tons of silly dialogue options that randomly make me giggle
--The ability to forge your own path and make your own choices that actually affect the world and its denizens
--Beautifully crafted OST
--Tons of races, subraces, classes, and subclasses to make every character different
--Weirdly satisfying to break the game in tiny ways
--Spooky stuff galore
--BY FAR SOME OF THE COOLEST VILLAINS EVER.
--Pretty easy to get into character if youre with friends (my half-orc druid named horgunk the hungry who eats mind flayer tadpoles for fun is a prime example)
--Ice pick lobotomy (you get a cool eye from it)
--Bear sex

-CONS
--Movement pathfinding sometimes screws you over
--Sometimes attacks just don't select a target??
--Egirls obsessing over Astarion (vampire twink) and making the worst looking characters known to man
--Karmic dice is on by default, which isn't really true to the whole "dice roll random" thing
--Very large game, youll need some storage for this one
--Tieflings (tiefling racism is by far the funniest thing ive seen in this game especially with some vicious mockery lines against them)
--Baldur's Gate is the entirety of Act 3, leaving me and my friends booing throughout the first 2 acts ("whos baldur and where is his gate")
--Any creature that has Unstoppable, Sanctuary, or go invisible
--Can't kill children, bad game design!!!
--Bear sex

If you want the gold dice then just grab someone's save file, load it onto your system and then do the epilogue. Even then it will bug out so just keep doing it until the save file will enable it.

One of, if not the best game I've ever played.  It's up there with KotOR, RDR2, Skyrim, and Fallout NV for me, maybe at the top.  The beauty, for me, is not just in the story or the graphics (though the set pieces and environment are amazing - enough to make you leave your character and game behind to cruise and rotate around the map), but the near infinite replayability. 

There's so much to do and so many ways to approach it with so many didn't classes, play styles, party make ups, etc that you can play it over and over and not get the same experience.  On top of that, there's untold amounts of ways to handle combat encounters.  It's choose your own adventure on steroids and the choices matter and can be far reaching.

It's as close to perfect as a game can be.

Baldur's Gate 3 is an outstanding CRPG, and in my opinion, the best game of 2023. It stands in stark contrast to the usual formulaic "AAA RPGs", if you can even call them that. This game is the closest you can get to playing an actual pen & paper D&D campaign in videogame form.

If you're a fan of the older Baldur's Gate games, this game might put you off with its turn based combat, but I really think you should give it a chance. Combat is fun and challenging, and in the harder difficulties you'll need to use everything at your disposal to win.

The visuals in this are amazing, specially for a CRPG. These games often don't have a big budget because of their niche nature, and Baldur's Gate 3 is an anomaly in that regard. Every conversation is beautifully animated and motion captured. The textures, lighting, particle effects are all quite good.

All the companions are interesting and romanceable, regardless of who your character is, and they all have backstories, secrets, and personal sidequests that develop as the story goes.

The story is good but nothing too mindblowing (heh). I think it's enough to get you out into the world, and works well for the game. I think the game really shines while doing the sidequests though, solving personal problems for the characters or finding secret knowledge that probably shoud've remained sealed away.

All quests, be it the main story or side activities, have lots of ways they can play out, and this is the most refreshing part of this game. This is where the game gets very close to an actual D&D adventure. There's so many ways of getting what you need that it can be a little overwhelming. You can get out of the usual gamey mentality and do some common sense stuff, and it'll probably work.

Overall, this game feels like those "once a decade" experiences. It's amazing how deep and engaging it is. If you're a sucker for CRPGs, don't miss out on this one.

First of all, I dont really like turnbased games but as a huge Dragon Age Origins fan I couldnt pass up the chance to play the game series that it got inspired by and it was worth it mostly, Act 1 and 2 is great, lots of things to do, lots of interesting plotlines and so many choices you can make that it made a really interesting and unique journey. Gave me a lot of Dragon Age vibes, the only downside i'd say is you dont get to visit as many areas as you do in DA:O, yes DA:0 is a shorter game but has a bigger world somehow. 

But then Act 3 starts and most of the endings of the storylines thats from acts 1 and 2 seems rushed, a TON of sidequests are incomplete with no explanation as to why somethings happening, the unique elements from first 2 acts seems to be gone and there isn't as much interesting encounters and even after so long there's a ton of bugs still in act 3 specifically. The team 100% rushed this, needed a year or 2 more, they claim not to have investors so why would they feel the need to rush this out? Very large missed opportunity imo.

Ending can basically be described as Mass Effect 3-like. Its not satisfying and unlike the rest of the whole game the ending locks you down to 2 choices, no matter what you do you are forced into doing something which a lot of proper rather not do. I heard they added the epilogue in a later patch so originally it was worse but yeah the epilogue makes it a tad better, maybe they can improve the choices upon it in the future, it'd be a shame to have a game this good have such bad endings. Even after 14 years Dragon Age Origins' ending is still superior and they didnt need to patch in an epilogue lol.

This game was a bit of struggle for me to get started on. As someone who has played table-top DnD for something like 20 years, the lack of variety in available sub-classes available from the base game was difficult to get accustomed to. (Essentially, only the sub-classes that were shipped with 5E player's handbook and base rules were available.) I spent the first 28+ hours of playtime in this game either making painstaking decisions at the character screen, or re-rolling once I hit level 3 because I couldn't see myself liking that character for an entire play-through.

Keep in mind, this was before the ability to re-roll your class, which was added sometime after I had hung up the game after those rough beginnings. Even with the ability to change classes, I was miffed that I couldn't change my race or starting background, as all true addicts to character creation in DnD can attest that a race that makes a great fighter may not be the same that makes a great illusionist wizard for example.

I also understand that I could simply download one of the many community-built mods out there to expand the choices of sub-classes. But doing so would run the risk of taking away from the carefully designed world that the developers intended, and I didn't want to 'cheese' fights with mechanics or combinations that the developers hadn't intended to be in the game yet. I'm sure some of you are rolling your eyes at that, but for now, that was and is my stance.

Needless to say -- I desperately wanted to enjoy the story and world this game had to offer, so I made myself  a compromise: I would play the game as a class that I didn't really play at the table, just so I wouldn't be obsessed with the 'perfect' build or with trying to recreate some of the great experiences I had with table-top characters. This allowed me to simply roll a character that could get into the world and encounter whatever there was to encounter and take it as it came. This worked for me, and now I'm 50+ hours into that character and not looking back.

I'll probably roll a new character after I finish and come back, hopefully when the dev team has introduced several new playable sub-classes/races. But either way, this has been a great experience and I'm glad I found a way to enjoy this truly remarkable game. (If you're curious, my compromise class is a fighter using a 2H weapon; an arch-type I have never found all that interesting.)

Baldur's Gate 3 is a captivating journey into the mesmerizing realm of Faerun. Its visually stunning world, from the sunlit streets of Baldur's Gate to the mysterious depths of the Underdark, feels like a living painting.

The game's fusion of artistry and gameplay is truly exceptional. Combat is a strategic ballet, while dialogue choices weave a rich narrative tapestry, each decision shaping the story in profound ways.

The diverse cast of characters adds depth and emotion to the adventure. From the enigmatic Astarion to the steadfast Shadowheart, their stories intertwine with mine, creating lasting connections. (got to love Astarion dating sim)

Baldur's Gate 3 spins an epic tale of intrigue and danger, inviting players to confront the darkness threatening Faerun. It's more than just a game; it's a soul-stirring odyssey that captivates with its beauty, gameplay, and unforgettable characters.

All of this is achieved with best in class acting, writing, and character animation. If this game had just had one of these strong points, it would have been a hit. The fact that it has both makes it basically unmissable for video game enjoyers.

Wow, what a journey this was. This was my first time experiencing a DnD type of RPG game thanks to a very dear friend of mine and oh boy was it a great suggestion. You can have up to 4 people in your party, but there are more than 10 people that you can recruit into your camp but every single one of these characters have their backstory fully fleshed out and extensively immersive. I mean I played 95% of the game with the same party but your whole playthrough can change just because you're going with another party member. Not going to lie, the combat can be fun but I was immersed with the story and the world itself so after 2-3 hours I went back to the easiest setting and I think it was the right choice for me since what hooked me was not the hardness or the combat system but the story and world itself. And I don't think I lost much, although again, I played this game more casually than any other player, not caring too much about the min maxing but even with that game had an extreme depth of a story. The choices you make are permanent and you can like blind yourself for the whole playthrough just by choosing a dialogue option or just plain out kill a main character without talking to him and that character's actor won the best actor in TGA. So you can just not make him talk in the game and killing him and it does not really affect the game but make it a little smaller. I mean I can go on and on about the story, voice acting, different branches that the story can unfold, your party's and everyone around's story has different endings, choices and more. This was a masterpiece of a game. Definitely, definitely should be played. Easily one of the best games I've every played.

The closest you'll currently get to a 1:1 DnD experience, mechanically faithful with a few great adjustments to make the conversion to a digital play space more enjoyable. One of the most immersive worlds in any video game that's not only filled with some of the most endearing characters in any RPG, but also fully realized with so many ways to authentically interact with it. 

As someone who spent a good portion of their life in people's basements/living room playing 5e, I cannot recommend this game enough to anyone else looking to replicate the fun of a traditional tabletop game of DnD.

In general the game is OK in most aspects (especially if you are a fan of BG series).

But biggest showstoppers/experience breakers for me were:
1) Overwhelming amount abilities/skills/bonus skills/special actions/passive/active/etc., that should be selected/obtained from first levels without at least somewhat clear examples how it would work further in game.
I played NWN and NWN2 and never had such problem.

2) It is hard to predict possibilities of upcoming enemies (even if they are on the same level). Sometimes my party could become mostly paralyzed/frozen/asleep/onhold/etc. and there was not much I could do to mitigate such situation. 

3) Fast travel can not be used to return to previous locations to complete companion quests.

4) Sometimes (too often for me) "dice roll" mechanics felt like "gambling".

I'd recommend to wait for sale if you never player BG game or played NWN games previously in order to minimize potential disappointment.

But if you are a fan of BG or just feel risky today - go on :)

P.S.: Dropped it after 70Hrs+ in 3rd Act. Really disappointing :/

This is hands down my favorite game of all time. It's a return to form for this genre and innovates the CRPG genre. 

If you like detailed games that you can really sink your teeth into, then this title is not just for you, it is a MUST for you.
If you like DnD and you don't have time to set time with friends this game is for you.

Story: Story is quite thrilling. You are abducted by mindflyers, which are highly intelligent, mind dominating creatures, scheming to conquer the world. You have been planted with one of their tadpoles into your brain. With fear you can transform into one of the tentacle thralls any moment, you are pushing forward to find answers as soon as possible. Story progresses with feel of urgency and it is full of unexpected twists and important decisions. Through 3 Acts you will visit wilderness, underdark, shadow-cursed lands and revisit the great city of Baldur´s Gate from original game.

Gameplay: Surprisingly true to D&D tabletop rules. Almost every aspect is implemented. Most notably there is roll for each skill check with 20-sided dice using your primary stats and proficiencies. This dice become without doubt most recognisable feature of this instalment. This time around your party is restricted to only 4 characters, which I am not fan of. This results in constant changing of your party composition. In original Baldur´s Gate I was using 5 characters most of the time and 6th spot was reserved for guest companion tied to some side quest. I really appreciate I could choose side and go semi-evil path, which i took without hesitation. This is improvement from previous games, where evil options were present, but fairly limited to few minor quests.

Character creation: Pretty basic, but sufficient. There is good amount of customisation and races to choose from. There is no rolling for stats, but you simply assign extra points to attributes you will use the most according to your class. When level up, you have really nice look on your characters. Every couple of levels, you can choose special ability or attribute improvement. I find special ability choices with few exceptions quite marginal and I almost always took main attribute improvement. If I compare it to previous rulesets, i think levelling up in Baldur´s Gate 3 is better than Baldur´s Gate 2, but worse than Icewind Dale 2.

Graphics: Graphic side is simply amazing. I have made literally thousands of screenshots. Locations are beautifully done with attention to detail. Underground areas are especially immersive. Lights and shadows create spectacular projections. I really appreciate return to isometric view, which is true to original games, but with ability to pan and zoom. What will not please is lack of dynamic weather or day and night cycle. 

Cutscenes: This is where game shines. It is clearly an area where most money went and it is visible. Hours and hours cutscenes. Certainly, it deserves awards for best story, cinematics, atmosphere, immersion and voice acting. Especially voice acting is mind blowing. Every character is voiced by different actor and voice acting is really there. It is not just soulless reading. Almost every character with few exceptions has its own unique face. Their face mimics and voice syncing are breathtaking. 

Music: Ranging from OK to good. There is no track overly bad, but no memorable either. Soundtrack does good job overall. I mostly like music and ambience from dungeons, rather than music from outdoor or city. In no stretch it can compare to excellent soundtracks from Baldur´s Gate 1+2 or Icewind Dale 1+2 by Jeremy Soul, which i keep dear in memory to this day.

Combat system: Not a fan in the slightest. Combat itself is easily the worst part of the game for me. Main reason is turn-based combat. In original Baldur´s Gate, there is dynamic real time combat with option to pause anytime. Turns were used merely for effect duration and how often you can cast spells or make your next attack. Tactical pause was a such distinctive feature in the series and game feels less authentic without it. Main action and bonus action system is step in right direction. Fact that everyone can jump around during combat across the battlefield is straightforward bad design, your formation means nothing. Combat in this game is few and far between. This is not necessarily bad thing, because you can role play and talk out from most encounters, if that is your preferred game style.

Magic system: Nothing to write home about. Feels like placeholder. Spells don´t have enough information on them. You can´t even say if it is area of effect spell, touch or missile. You can´t see duration of effect. I would much rather have spell book from original game, where i could inspect all effects, spell pre-requisitions and detailed description. Option of using higher tier spell slot for lower tier spell is nice, but it makes chaos in spell tabs. I can´t properly see what is naturally tier 3 spell and what is boosted low level spell. I have been using it by selecting tier I spell and then chose which tier i want to use, never other way around.

Inventory: Terrible experience with inventory. Loads of junk and garbage. Lot of items you will never need. Mostly uninteresting magic items, which i could barely remember i have in inventory. I think it would be better to have fewer items in the game but more useful. Lack of dedicated potion bags, scroll bags and arrow quivers. Yes, there are plenty of bags and such, but no way to differentiate them one from another. Also, you can´t sell stuff stashed in bags. You need to manually remove them from bag and then sell it. Short and neglected item descriptions. In Baldur´s Gate 1 and 2, Items had their page with detailed monochrome hand drawn picture, history and description. Hundreds of different potions with not enough opportunities to use them. You can´t see duration of a potions and in lot of cases you can´t use multiple potions together, because they nullify previous effect. I was using lot of poison coatings though. 

UI: Could be much better. You have hundred icons for basic attacks, movements and abilities. Not sure what led developers to implement this MMO style layout. It is hard to organize. When you do reorganize it, each new item will insert new icons into empty slot and makes mess again. There is an option to switch between different tabs though, like main action, bonus action, special ability and such, which i have been actively using.

Final Verdict: 8/10. 
Story and immersion carrying this game sky high, but it is dragged down by bad quality of life features. There is room for improvement.

Act 1 almost had me quit this game. It didn't feel like Baldur's gate game at all. I don't mean the engine, I don't mind it, and I have +200 hours in DOS2. I mean the mood and atmosphere, the feeling of freedom, the feeling of "what the hell I am supposed to do now". Things actually got interesting only after reaching Last Light Inn, but no spoilers. After that it started to feel little more like Baldur's Gate, and after reaching next area it had like 90% of BG's charm. 

The Cons:

- Camera and hiding floors is annoying. You get stuck in places and have to reload because you jump/fly/teleport to a place but then camera doesn't show the upper platforms so you can't jump/teleport/fly back (Cazador's Dungeon for example). This could be solved by adding "Show all walls and floors" button.
- Pickpocketing is as bad as it was in DOS2.
- I want to punch pretty much every single companion I have to their stupid faces

The Ok's:

- Unlike DOS2, this feels like I have so many ways to approach the bigger issue, but I still feel like every single way eventually leads down to same place and same fights, but I have about 200 hours too little to be sure about this. 

The pros:

- I can punch every single companion I have to their stupid faces.
- Throwing enemies is fun
- Petting dogs
- It's a BG
- It's a Larian game

Summarum: 
I'm bit underwhelmed about this currently. I expected better based on the fact that it carries name of the best series ever, it's made by Larian, and the hype like never before. It's definitely not a bad game, it's a good game, but not the Jesus Christ reincarnated and don't expect too much.

Update:
After 5 playtroughs and finishing in Honour mode, I'm not underwhelmed anymore.

did i know what i would get for skills, passives, etc in the next lvl up? no. there is no way to see what i will get for multiclassing for example. you have to commit, then use it on battles, and then regret and start watching vids on youtube. frustrating
most info is just not there until you get there and i see myself spending too much time reading things in game, after ive spent time reading things on the wiki and watching videos.
to be minimally knowledgeable of what im doing at any given point, i find myself wasting lots of time reading and trying to understand things

I endured the abrupt nonsense that was the finale of Divinity 2. It's among my Bottom 5 worst moments in gaming. The way the final fight happens is not telegraphed, has no lead-in, and does not make sense. I did not have much faith the same studio that did that would make another narrative-heavy game a winner. 

But, some of my regular gaming partners from college wanted to play a co-op Baldur's Gate 3 game. It seemed to work smoothly enough. The first act was interesting. So, I gave it a shot. 

It ended up being one of the glitchiest add-insult-to-injury-as-often-as-possible experiences I've had in gaming. 

1. Combining Polearm Master and Sentinel does not work as intended. They interact appropriately about 20% of the time. IT'S NOT EVEN ALWAYS OR NEVER. HOW DO YOU GET THE MECHANICS WRONG LIKE THIS??

2. The romance option I kinda fell into by accident in my parallel single player game, ended up being abruptly cancelled, as best I can tell, because I simply didn't have enough Long Rests in Act 2. It was not telegraphed. HOW CAN YOUR WRITING BE SO BAD THAT YOU DO THAT WITH NO TELEGRAPHING? THIS IS SUPPOSED TO BE **THE NARRATIVE GAME**. 

3. Using the whole tabletop long rests + spell slots system in a computer game was a dubious choice from the beginning. A whole bunch of interesting alternatives are well demonstrated at this point. There are lots of ways to avoid the arbitrary restrictions this imposes on the game. 

4. One of the clear-and-specific benefits the DND roleplaying system ought to have provided to this type of game should have been the lack of exponential increase in item power as your characters increase in level. (In my mind, this was the other flaw of Divinity 2, aside from the absolutely scarring abruptness of the finale. A Level 11 shield tended to be twice as powerful as a Level 10 shield. That does not make sense in any system or universe. Except Divinity 2, apparently.) 
Instead, they introduced so many unique mechanics in items that lots of build guides, and my more optimization-focused friend, basically can't talk about a build without listing off all the essential items for the build. This has a pile of narrative and overall-path-through-the-game consequences that can easily suck the fun out of a playthrough by itself. 

5. Jumping doesn't work. 
JUMPING DOESN'T WORK.
I GOT STOPPED IN MIDAIR THREE TIMES IN OUR MULTIPLAYER GAME FOR NO REASON. The paths said I could do the jump. THEY WERE WRONG. 

6. THE THIRD FAILED JUMP PUT ME IN A CHASM AND KILLED ME. 
WHAT THE EVER-LOVING FUCK IS THIS??!??
It's jumping. You guys tested this. I do not need to do this in the form of a question. I know you tested it. How did you fuck this up? It's a Bonus Action that every class gets, and they all have use cases for it. And it abruptly killed me when the trajectory arrow said it would work. 

The awards tell us that you're plenty strategic about it, Larian. But you have basic quality-of-life features that you do not give a fuck about. There's no way you didn't test for this. But you left it broken. So FUCK YOU. This is comfortably my worst experience in a video game.

I wrote a silly joke-review when I was just a couple of hours in, about my character yelling "It's Baldurin' time!" and Baldured all over the Gate or something along those lines, but this game doesn't deserve that. 
Now that I've got... a few more hours under my belt, I figured it's time to do it right.

I waited so long, trying to make up my mind about wether I should get this game or not. Obviously I finally decided to go for it, and I have not regretted it a single second!
I actually don't think I've got enough words to properly describe this game, but to put it a bit into perspective: I've never played D&D, so I had no idea about how that part worked, and turn-based combat has never been my favorite, but this might actually be the greatest game I've ever played. At least it's in the top 5 of all time. And I've been playing videogames for about 30 years or so.

I haven't even finished the game yet, and I'm already planning my next playthrough. And I haven't been spending 112 hours on one playthrough because it's too hard. No. It's just too damn good! I want to see everything! I want to do everything!
I've lied my way into a huge goblin camp to murder their leaders. I've sniffed a spider carcass. I've talked a boss into killing himself. I've avoided so many fights because I'm just too damn handsome (and I also excel in the arts of persuasion and deception). I've made people laugh. I've made people dance. I've argued with a tax collector about gold. I've watched surgery being performed (not my fault, but definitely my fault). I've talked to animals. I've talked to corpses. I've solved murder mysteries. I've uncovered conspiracies. I lied to a skeleton. I'm wearing some sexy underwear that I stole from a boss I killed. My best friend is a brain. An angel lives in my camp. I've got unstable blood that explodes when it comes into contact with fire. My hat is fabulous.
Also, what's not to love about being a halfling bard with a lyre, running naked through the streets of Baldur's Gate, showing the citizens and the Steel Watch just how dangly the game's physics can be?
And there's still so much I haven't done. If only I waited just a bit longer before advancing the story.

To summarize:
The story = Amazing
The side quests = Unique and exciting
The characters = Interesting and believable
The combat = Fun
The choices = Many! So many choices!
The graphics = Beautiful
Replay value = Very yes!
Quick save = Gets used
Should you play it? = Absolutely! (Well, maybe not if you only play competitive shooters, but if you did, you probably wouldn't be reading this anyway, would you?)

The travel of table top to CRPG has a long and fraught path. The famous letters to Lord British leading to Ultima 4. Goldbox Games. This game's predecessors (both developer and franchises). The DREADED Gen 7. Pieces got to that level of interactivity and reactivity like DOS2, Pathfinder, and Solasta. But one has finally got there, all while not scaring the bejesus out of everyone else but inticing them: BG3.

There's also a ton of little fixes to both D&D5e rule system and Larian's battle system. Brilliant use of Shove, Throw, Jump, and how the famous surface system is toned down to be a fun advantage and no longer a Splatoon-fest of insanity.

The characters as a group are subtle (god knows they aint as individuals, but I digress). What starts as a gang of drama llamas (and Karlach) show real varied depth and maddening oxymoronic traits by close.

Big quibble with the lack of sliders for sound. Only overworld barks could be adjusted individually, continuing the backslide seen in SMT V, whereas the below Nayuta did have this.

But overall, we have the first of two watershed moments for their genres this year, and to see Larian grow and so many "get" this kind of intricate prep and insight-heavy gaming is heartwarming.

I have not finished the game, however my current playthrough so far has been enjoyable. Baldur's Gate 3 has funny dialogue, personally intriguing and visually good looking characters and engaging (at least on the tactician difficulty) combat.

Despite that, I can't recommend the game to the average consumer. People usually have 500GB to 1TB drives. Baldur's Gate is 120 Gb*. Installing BG3 comes with the opportunity cost of not having 3 - 10 other games in the same space. For reference, let's compare it to it's genre peers.

* NOW IT'S 132 AS OF PATCH 5
* 141, Patch 6

Baldur's Gate 3 equals
2.4 Wasteland 3's (50 Gb) 
5 Disco Elysium's (20 Gb) - Which includes more voiced lines than BG3 
5 Torment: Tides of Numenera's (20 Gb)
8 Tyranny's (15 Gb)
8.5 Shadowrun Trilogies (10 + 2 + 2 = 14 Gb)
OR one of each of these games. 

Now, as I said, Baldur's Gate 3 is really really fun. It also has a lot of content. Is it more fun and more content than what you could get from all of the previous games combined? No.

Though each playthrough follows broadly the same story line (like a module in D&D) there are enough ways to change your path that it keeps it fresh. Well-executed, good mechanics, great attention to detail.

Baldur's Gate 3 is a fresh breath of air after disappointment and disappointment with the gaming industry. I played hundreds of hours of BG3 on my Xbox Series S and I'm very close to finishing my honor run on there. I like BG3 so much, I bought it again on my PC so I can play with mods. I have played Larian's last title, Divinity Original Sin 2 and it was also excellent. BG3 is a game that has so much depth, every new run I play, I find something new in it. The game isn't perfect but it is one the closest games to come near perfection. Combat is challenging but fun, frustrating if it is in honor or tactician mode but its supposed to be. Story is incredibly fleshed out and characters have a lot of depth and choices. As long as Larian keeps up with this amount of quality, I look forward to their next game.

After almost 600 hours, I'm rewriting my initial review. Baldur's Gate 3 might be the best video game I have ever played. The thing that makes it stand out above every other single-player game I've picked up in the last few years isn't the amazing voice acting, the excellent story, the creative and interesting characters, or the deep and engaging class system of DnD, though all of those things are excellent and worthy of praise. The thing that puts this game above anything else I've played recently is that every encounter you experience in its world feels intentional. If you get into a fight as you're exploring, those enemies, and that whole encounter, are interesting and unique. If you start a conversation with an NPC, chances are they have something individual to say to you. If you pick up a quest, it is unique and memorable. When you make a choice in one place, it affects your outcomes in another place, because everything about this game was put together with thought and attention.

On top of this rock-solid foundation of a core game design that respects the player, Baldur's Gate 3 also possesses outstandingly engaging, replayable turn-based combat; branching narrative decisions which, after 600 hours, I haven't even come close to exhausting; and all of the visual polish of a AAA game. The biggest problem with BG3 is that Baldur's Gate 4 doesn't start as soon as the credits stop rolling, but that's also somewhat okay since this is the first single-player game since KOTOR that I've wanted to play over and over again.
Read any good review for this game and trust that they are honest.

Baldur's Gate 3 je remek-delo koje nudi neograničene mogućnosti i neprestanu zabavu. Sa više od 310 sati igre i više puta završenim pričama koristeći različite likove, mogu reći da sam potpuno zarobljen u ovom nevjerojatnom svetu.

Ova igra se može pohvaliti ne samo prelepom grafikom, već i pažljivo osmišljenim svetom, dubokim narativima i izazovnim borbama. Svaki put kada započnete novu avanturu, osećate da se suočavate sa potpuno novim svetom, jer svaka odluka ima posledice i oblikuje vašu priču.

Mogućnost kreiranja vlastitih likova, svaki sa svojim pozadinskim pričama i veštinama, dodaje dubinu igri i čini je beskrajno ponovljivom. Svaki put kad počnete novu kampanju, imate priliku istražiti nove puteve i testirati različite strategije.

Baldur's Gate 3 je odlična igra za fanove D&D sistema, ali i za one koji se prvi put susreću s njim. Sve je predivno objašnjeno i pristupačno, što omogućava uživanje svima bez obzira na iskustvo.

Iako je trenutno u early access fazi, razvojni tim marljivo radi na ažuriranjima i poboljšanjima, što obećava još više uživanja u budućnosti.

Iskoristite priliku i upustite se u ovu avanturu. Sa svojom neograničenom ponovljivošću i dubinom, Baldur's Gate 3 je igra koju ćete igrati satima, dugo nakon što završite glavne priče. Sjajno ostvarenje, neka ne propusti!

Every single person in my friend group was raving about the game, so I decided that I would buy it and give it a go. In the beginning I kept waiting to be hooked in like everyone said I would, unable to put the game down. It was an easy pick up and put down in the beginning, but now I'm obsessed with getting every single sidequest possible and pick up everything I can get my grubby little hands on.

To make matters worse (or perhaps even better), I introduced my mom to the game. I thought it would be a fun little hour or two of running the keyboard while she made the decisions, and then she would be done wtih it. That was very much not the case. My mother LOVES this game. My dad does, too. In fact, so many people in my house want to play it that I had to buy a second copy so we could play at the same time! Astarion (also known as Oregano/Octavious/Octogon/Asparagus) is a favourite because of how ridiculously high you can get his roll bonuses for lockpicking. It is a surreal experience when you hear your father go "Astarion tried to proposition me last night and got all snippy when I said no". Especially when he is somewhat laughing.

My mother is obsessed with Karlach and is determined to make Karlach her character's girlfriend. Said character is named "Dolly Parton", a super beefy high elf war cleric who runs around in skimpy clothing and beats the ever loving shit out of all her enemies. Easily the best $60ish usd I have ever spent. My parents have put in more playtime than I have, and I replayed a solid 20 hours because I decided I hated a decision I made early on. They play it for date night. Its one of the cutest things I've ever seen.

The character customization is not as extensive as I would have hoped, but the various sassy dialogue choices more than make up for it. 100/10 would reccomend, hands down a delight to play!

This is a high quality D&D game that takes advantage of the offerings of a computer to track things and speed up detail management so that combat can be nitty and tactical without slowing down the game excessively.

Baldur's Gate 3 is, without a doubt, the best game ever made. Larian Studios, congratulations on this fantastic game. I was afraid it might be a repeat of Divinity: Original Sin 2, but nope! This game brought me genuine joy, and at no point did I feel like I was wasting my time or getting bored.

To newcomers to Dungeons & Dragons, please, try this game. Baldur's Gate 3 offers a perfect introduction to the D&D universe, with gameplay mechanics faithful to the 5th edition rules. The immersive story, well-developed characters, and captivating quests make this experience an unforgettable adventure, even for those unfamiliar with tabletop role-playing games.

What truly sets Baldur's Gate 3 apart is its ability to capture the essence of the Dungeons & Dragons universe. Every decision you make has an impact on the world around you, allowing you to shape your own narrative in a unique way. The dialogues are rich in depth, and interactions with non-player characters feel authentic, further immersing you in this fantastic world.

Additionally, the game offers incredible replay value. With multiple narrative paths, extensive customization choices, and a variety of classes and skills to discover, each new playthrough brings a completely different experience. Whether you choose to be a cunning wizard, a fearless warrior, or a charming rogue, Baldur's Gate 3 gives you the freedom to play how you want.

In conclusion, Baldur's Gate 3 is a masterpiece of role-playing games, offering an epic and immersive adventure that will delight fans of D&D and newcomers alike. With its perfect blend of rich storytelling, tactical gameplay, and endless exploration, this game rightfully deserves its place among the greatest of all time.

A lot of love has gone into this game. The writing is phenomenal, not to mention the performances, the environments feel natural and are fun to explore, and Larian's community management is second to none.

And your character can be trans, which blew my mind when I first started playing the game. It makes me very happy to play a character who is like me. <3

I had poured 70 hours into my honour mode save only for it to screw me over with game-breaking bugs. I was in act 3 and was so close to ending the game and finally getting the achievement that would make me feel good about myself. Then when I killed the red dwarf, all my companions started attacking me, and then i thought it would be a good idea to SAVE THE GAME. WIPING THE EXIT TO THIS MADNESS BECAUSE HONOUR MODE FORCES YOU TO ONLY ONE SAVE FILE. I could have loaded the previous one. Maybe lost a couple of minutes collecting stuff, maybe redone the monks quest that was also bugged, talking to Bhal's victims that they would die "none of them took me seriously" and then i could have done it all over again. But my dumbass wanted to save the fucking game with the bug that ruined my honour run COMPLETELY.

So dear Larian Studios, if you would be so kind and fix this bug (and maybe remove the single save file setting) that would be perfect.

Edit: It's fine I completed it but I got the tactician difficulty achievement instead. Shouldn't be mad about it because I at least managed to get something from it.

I decided to buy this game after merely seeing the character creation options. After that, this game consumed my life for a month up to levels some would consider...unhealthy.

I've played 179h so far. However, that consists of only 1 playthrough (of Tav origin), and my last save (at pretty much the last decision point before the ending credits) is at approx. 141h. Which means I spent ~38h reloading either due to curiosity getting the better of me and/or simply on the verge of wiping a battle (TBF, I reloaded every time somebody in my party died - even if I could've resurrected them).

As someone relatively new to the DnD scene, it was a rough start for me, learning to survive bigger battles, even on Explorer mode. My brain, used to regular RPGs with limitations, couldn't even imagine all the creative approaches this game allows the player to take.
On the other hand, I've learnt more about DnD mechanics in general from this playthrough than I ever did from internet guides...

I did a playthrough of 141h, occasionally peeking at guides to explore and find everything possible...and there are still multiple locations/interactions I managed to miss. Not to mention all the story paths I didn't take.

I aimed for a good-aligned playthrough with as good endings as possible, and yet, nearing the endgame, it got trickier and trickier to correctly guess the 'good' course of action.
So. Many. Plot twists. So. Much. Lore.

Cons?

My major gripe is that a certain party member bugged out a bit before the transition to Act 3 and I wasn't able to ever actually add them to my party after that.

Inventory and party management could still use some QoL improvements. Nothing a few mods can't fix, but an official patch would be better.

One could argue that the Act 3 could still use more fleshing out and improvements. There have (allegedly) been some major changes in the storylines compared to the Early Access version, and the rushed bridging occasionally shows, with some minor details not really making 100% sense.

Still, by the time I actually finished the playthrough, quite a few essential patches had already been applied to the game, so aside from the specific companion mishap I was able to progress through the game relatively smoothly.

Would I recommend it?

Hell yeah!

Now excuse me while I go make a new character with a Durge origin and go on another adventure!

EDIT: 582 hours in. I have completed all the achievements and just started my 5th playthrough. There are still rooms I haven't explored. Send help.

The game is solid enough for the most part.  I think it gets most of it's hype by just being old-school as a game instead of what gamers have been subjected to from AAA studios in recent years (that is buggy unfinished poorly designed over-monetized piles of trash with pretty graphics), so when this comes along and it's NOT the usual garbage it got a very warm welcome.

And for the most part it deserves it.  Plot has been solid and pacing is ok, graphics and sound are nice, voice acting is on point, map design is lovely, combat rewards interesting use of the environment, and so on.

The main cast though?  Uninteresting.  Boring.  Disappointing.  Overly difficult to get to know with the one most ready to talk about their life stories being the one who is supposed to be keeping secrets as a matter of religion.  I suppose I was expecting something closer to the old BioWare experience of character writing and presentation like from Mass Effect or Dragon Age, but this is just... missing something.  Part of it at least is how little they interact with each other or the main character in general which I think stems from not just committing to a central player role ala Cmd Shephard that can be written around and instead having to write around the protagonist being any of the pre-made characters OR a player-made option.  The result is just a bit 'meh'.  And when your main cast feels 'meh' it makes it harder to care about the main story because it's harder to care about the cast that's in it, and this is especially a bad thing for a story-driven RPG so what would have been a mole-hill problem feels bigger.

The other thing holding the game back from being a great game is the modern-day D&D mechanics.  It feels like Baby's First Leveling System.  Customization is bare-bones at best, classes don't really feel all that impactful and just kind of feel like all you're doing is choosing a primary DPS option for each character.  Sure, it means you don't strictly need any particular class types or whatever but it also means none of them are all that interesting either.  The multi-classing is also a disappointment.  The choices made in leveling just don't feel all that meaningful when compared to D&Ds of yester-year.  Streamlined is not always better once you've been streamlined out of making interesting choices.  

I've also never been a fan of the D20 core dice mechanic as it's too linear and 'dice-y' making it feel like the outcomes rely too much on dice and not enough on player choice or skill.  Replacing the D20 with 2D10 would make a far better game on it's own.  Bell-curve dice outcomes give you a better feeling of player agency when you have a generally reliable range of results on the dice with a noticable curve of things getting difficult or easy and still get that outside chance of amazing or terrible outcomes once in a while.  But again, that's a D&D problem which this game just inherits by sticking so close to table-top rules.

The character editor, while 'ok', is also disappointing.  Body sliders should be a given in this day and age, or at least instead of 'normal' and 'tall' body types have a few actually different body types and a height scaling slider.  But then, my standards were set by City of Heroes 20 years ago and the vast majority of games have been a disappointment in character customization ever since.  Not being able to pick a casual clothing outfit is also disappointing, especially when I have to steal Shadowheart or Minthara's outfit if I want something other than 'villager #67' as an outfit.  I also continue to be mildly dissappointed that a game actually feels the need to give genital options but still doesn't have one for hermaphrodites.  I mean if you're going to go that far on that one customization option, why not go all-in?

Still, at the end of the day the game is worth the price and you'll have many enjoyable hours out of it.  Just because it has room for improvement doesn't mean it's Bad.  I'm also all for supporting this classic business model of one-time buy and done in the big mass-market gaming space.
