[i]Baldur's Gate 3[/i] is such a long game, and each person will have a unique experience while playing through the campaign. That's the game's magic, and that's also why I'm not even going to attempt to do a long, detailed review of the game. I'm not someone who necessarily vibes with the combat in [i]Baldur's Gate 3[/i]- I prefer things to be faster pace, and a bit more forgiving to the occasional incorrect input. However, that's not stopping me from being extremely positive on [i]Baldur's Gate 3[/i]. The main reason why I love it so much, and probably the best thing I can say about it, is that it respects your time and decisions more than any game I've ever played. Companies like Telltale blew up by creating games that give you the illusion of choice; you pick between option 1 and option 2, but the ultimate outcome is essentially the same regardless of your choice. [i]Baldur's Gate[/i] doesn't do crap like that. You will make decisions 2 hours into this game, that will impact quests and stories 50 hours into the game. Your decisions will impact who lives, who dies, who you're allied with, etc. This expands out on such a scale that there isn't 1 or 2 different outcomes, there are hundreds, probably thousands of different outcomes to thousands of different scenarios. If you and 24 of your friends all play this campaign, you'll all have wildly different experiences across the entire game; that's not something you can say about other games that have sold themselves on "player choice/agency". This same respect translates to exploring the world; you're rewarded with unique weapons, spells, character interactions, etc. The respect Larian has for your choices and exploration, combined with the brilliant characters and voice acing make [i]Baldur's Gate 3[/i] an unforgettable experience that is extremely replayable. 

[b]Highly Recommended[/b]

[i]If you found my review helpful, please consider following my [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/44234346/]Steam Curator page[/url], where you can see more thoughts and recommendations[/i]

I've heard many people talk about how they typically lack interest or experience with this type of game and wouldn't usually deign to try something from this genre. That was me as well- until of course I started seeing clips everywhere and decided to give it a go.

From my experience? Baldur's Gate 3 is a genre-defining game for this generation. It ties in and streamlines CRPG elements into gameplay while weaving story-rich and character-driven narratives thoroughly throughout its run.

It's very evident that Larian as a team put in a lot of passion and care into their development of BG3, whichyou can see in the countless amounts of small details laid out throughout the various dialogue and mechanical interactions a player can make towards resolving an encounter. Talk it through? Sure. Blow it up? Sure. Jump from the top rope of a 300 foot drop as a bear to RKO a walking heap of infernal machinery? Nothing stopping you besides your creativity.

Virtually fully voice-acted (and particularly excellent work on this). Graphically pleasant and solid in building the right feel for each environment and situation. Lovable characters with a whole range of depth. Compelling baddies and NPCs and factions and encounters. Fantastic replayability. Engaging gameplay for the turn-based enthusiast. Bear sex scene, as advertised. And certainly much more- the game's a gem and definitely deserving of it's GOTY win for 2023. Cannot recommend enough.

Overall: It is a brilliant and charming game with intriguing characters and an engaging narrative. This is a game you will have to devote quite some time to if you really want the full experience. There are so many different routes you can take that every playthrough will feel unique. However, Act 3 is not laptop safe. You will need a decent pc to be able to experience it in full. The game will struggle to run otherwise with entire buildings not loading, lag spikes and sending pc fans into overdrive.

Great game, a lot of tailored content, unique interactions, and replayability packed in. Won GOTY for a reason.

 Only downside in my opinion, is that while Acts I and II are more exploration based and spread out in content (allowing you to take a breather and process where you are at in the story), Act III is super content dense, and all packed within the city of Baldur's Gate. I've had the game for awhile now and still haven't been able to finish Act III, because its so dense that it doesn't give you the opportunity to catch your breath, as your constantly being pulled around every-which-way into the climaxes of quests you have been on throughout the entire game. 

Act I and II's average time between encounters is 0-3 per hour, whereas Act III's average time between encounters is closer to 5-7 per hour.

Best to play on the weekends or after work in several hour long marathons, I don't think it is sustainable to play for 1-2 hours every now and then.
This game is amazing in both adventure and humor. I would love more story content in an expansion.

Listen, I'll be upfront. I think this game is vastly overrated and what frustrates me most is that it gets away with things that other games get shredded for.

What don't I like about it? Well...

First off, the game doesn't run particularly well if you're not running it off of a SSD. I got the weird portrait bug multiple times during my playthrough, crazy texture pop-in and even T-posing models at times. Granted, I was running the game just fine otherwise, but it was really jarring how unpolished this game was technically just because I wasn't using an SSD.

I think the writing is extremely overrated. If someone gave you this storyline in an actual D&D game, I guarantee you would think it's boring. I don't like putting spoilers in my reviews, but yeah - the game has a twist that doesn't really end up mattering that much depending on your choices, and the overall plot just doesn't land. There's no driving factor beyond the Mindflayer thing (being careful not to spoil here). Any other game would get shredded for how utterly mid the story of BG3 is.

And people really love the characters of Baldur's Gate 3. They're designed well, they're voice acted well. But to give Astarion of all characters Best Performance? All love to the VA, but no way. Astarion's story doesn't even progress until Act 2, more specifically the end of Act 2. And then once you get to the city, his story's done. How is that worthy of Best Performance? That'd be like if in 2015 we gave Best Performance to Piper Wright of Fallout 4 instead of Geralt from The Witcher 3. It sounds ridiculous on paper.

I do like the companions, I do! But they're not that interesting. They're all good, and none of them are great. I love Gale, but his story just ends on a conversation unless you detonate him. Wyll's story is probably the most entertaining, and you have to do his too, since you can't get a satisfying end for Karlach unless you do. Yeah, unless you do these specific things for another character (Wyll), Karlach doesn't get a happy ending. I know people love Shadowheart, but good God is her story boring. I don't care about any of this, and I actually killed her by accident in dialogue at one point. Which by the way, bugged out, causing the game to fade to black, and then when the game faded back in, she was permanently gone, so I had to reload. No indication that I killed her. I got the best ending for each character and honestly, I wish I cared more.

People love calling this game a sprawling RPG, but it's actually quite small if you really think about. It has huge open areas, but those are only really a puddle deep once you really start exploring. There's a good amount of side quests, sure, but none of them were really that interesting or worth doing until you get to the city in Act 3. And I did actually like doing quests in the city. I loved doing back to back run arounds in the city, since it gave me shades of Oblivion, which I love.

I think the worst part of this game that gets a pass is the combat. But I think I just personally hate 5th Edition. I think 5E has a plethora of issues compared to previous versions that weren't mitigated in this game. Larian used the most boilerplate and generic as possible version of D&D, with what feels like the Player's Handbook alone. And then they have the nerve to cap you at Level 12 instead of 20. Why? But I'll ease up on Larian a bit and blame the issues with the combat mostly on my gripes with 5E. I've whiffed so many damned attacks in this game. I've whiffed attacks more than XCOM! How's that even possible?!

I'll leave this by saying I hated playing this game, but I respect it and I'm still going to score it high. Because I respect Larian and I think they made something great here, but I don't personally find it fun or interesting to play. To be honest, if BG3's combat used an Mana system instead of 5E, I'd enjoy it way more as a whole - because Larian is very good. The game's beautiful, it's colorful, it's voice acted well, it has choice and consequence, it has replayability, it's great. Just not for me.

TL;DR: Baldur's Gate 3 does a lot of things well, but those things it does well are Larian things in spite of how garbage D&D 5e actually is, and I believe it gets a pass for the things it doesn't do well. Overrated, but I still respect it a ton.

this is a far cry from what i was expecting but i guess that’s on me. if you see hordes of people declaring this is the best game they have played in the past decade, the game they put 2000 hours into in just a month, the game that got them into or back into gaming, whatever else they say—clearly you should NOT believe them. yeah, the writing and the branching paths and the amount of decisions and possibilities and choices you can make is crazy—but the awesome length and scale of the game is a double edged sword. the thing is, this game isn’t very fun to play, especially for a game with a story you’re encouraged to sink hundreds of hours into. the game design has innumerable frustrating quirks and questionable choices, and over the hours these frustrations add up until it’s difficult to find the game enjoyable at all. i *want* to enjoy it, honestly, i’m nearing the end of my first run and there’s like 7 lae’zel playthroughs i want to do, but god the game is not fun to play. it’s a slog to go through. i wish the gameplay felt a little less like pulling teeth, because the writing is great! the possibilities make you want to play over and over! but after 130+ hours, these days i just end up turning it off after barely an hour, even though i *want* to continue with the shory. now, i did play it entirely on the deck (& thought it ran impressively well—the SD performance wasn’t an issue at all, imo), but dear god. the inventory is a NIGHTMARE, switching party members took 10 minutes before they changed it (but why did that take months to implement?), managing party members in general sucks (why do i need them in the party if i just want to change their gear), the game can’t be paused in singleplayer (come on), i encountered a number of rather serious bugs (which is to be expected in a game of this magnitude, sure, but these occured early on in act 1 and after i specifically waited for months, thinking such obvious problems would be patched by then), battles take forever, forcing you to watch as enemy after enemy takes 3 minutes to decide what to do with their turn, and gortash isn’t even a beautiful butch lesbian…. like it just doesn’t end. god knows if i’ll ever get to those 7 lae’zel playthroughs i had planned. whatever man

Probably one of the best games I have ever played in my entire life, playing most of the greats and even many indie or unpopular titles that were still very good. 

The choice making in this game is fantastic, there's almost always an option for something I'd do in every situation. This is genuinely the best game I have ever played. I've had this game for 2 weeks and can't stop playing it. Super excited to keep playing and discovering the rest of the world! 

The graphics and level design are astounding, the voice acting is impeccable and the story is everything I've looked for in every game I play. The game doesn't hold your hand as you begin but it also isn't overly challenging from the start. It encourages exploration with intriguing surroundings and something new on every corner that even I- someone not particularly fond of exploring being a huge aspect in the game- can't get enough of every tiny location. Everywhere you go there is someone to talk to, something to do or someplace to loot. There are multiple ways to achieve the same goal, and each one brings something different to the table. At first I was sceptical about the turn-based gameplay and dice rolls because I dived into the game with a very vague understanding of DnD. Yet, everything fits together so well and I've come to appreciate if not love dice rolls and TB combat the more hours I sink in.

I didn't expect to be this pleased but truthfully I think this has surpassed every one of my all time favourite games, including ones I have played over and over, and shot straight to being my all time favourite game. I can't wait to play it for years to come and try to exhaust all the possibilities in my future runs!

Baldur's Gate 3 is a true testament to the artistry and depth that the RPG genre can achieve. As a long-time fan of the series, I embarked on this journey with high expectations, and I'm thrilled to say that Larian Studios has not only met but exceeded them in nearly every aspect.

First and foremost, the world-building in Baldur's Gate 3 is nothing short of breathtaking. From the moment you step foot into the mystical realm of Faerûn, you're enveloped in a rich tapestry of lore, intrigue, and danger. The attention to detail in every nook and cranny of the game world is evident, and it's clear that the developers poured their hearts and souls into crafting an immersive experience that pays homage to the iconic Dungeons & Dragons universe while still feeling fresh and original.

One of the standout features of Baldur's Gate 3 is its robust character creation and customization system. Whether you prefer to play as a cunning rogue, a wise wizard, or a stalwart warrior, the game offers a staggering array of options to tailor your character to your preferred playstyle. The depth of choice extends beyond mere aesthetics, with each decision you make during character creation impacting your abilities, strengths, and weaknesses throughout the game.

Of course, no RPG would be complete without a compelling story to drive the action forward, and Baldur's Gate 3 delivers on this front in spades. The narrative is masterfully crafted, weaving together themes of betrayal, redemption, and the struggle for power in a way that keeps you hooked from start to finish. The characters you encounter along the way are equally captivating, each with their own motivations, quirks, and hidden depths waiting to be uncovered.

In addition to its engrossing story and world-building, Baldur's Gate 3 also shines in its gameplay mechanics. The turn-based combat system is both strategic and satisfying, requiring careful planning and tactical thinking to emerge victorious in battle. The ability to interact with the environment in creative ways adds an extra layer of depth to combat encounters, making each skirmish feel dynamic and unpredictable.

All in all, Baldur's Gate 3 is a masterpiece of the RPG genre that seamlessly blends the classic elements that made its predecessors so beloved with innovative new features that push the genre forward. Whether you're a seasoned veteran of the series or a newcomer looking for an epic adventure to sink your teeth into, Baldur's Gate 3 is an absolute must-play. Highly recommended.

As you can probably tell from my time played, I wanted to like this game. I wanted to see the phenomenal best CRPG ever that everyone else saw, but I don't. I see an average CRPG with pretty graphics, decent writing, a poor adaptation of DnD 5e (a combat system I actually really like), MCU dialogue (not a good thing), very poor PC optimisation (I had more crashes in 48 hours of this than I've had in 150 hours of Starfield), safe faux-edginess, and a fanbase who thinks it's an eroge and are probably the most annoying people on the internet right now. It's a 7/10. But what's most egregious to me is one simple fact: it's not a good sequel. Baldur's Gate 1 and 2 are among the greatest video games ever made and this doesn't feel like a sequel. It references their events on occasion, sure, and has a couple of returning characters, but frankly they feel like completely different characters and the world feels totally different. One of the most disappointing games I've ever played.

While its a slight departure from the original games it stands on its own as being one of the most enjoyable gaming experiences i have had in recent memory. i believe i will be putting the majority of my non-ttrpg free time into this game for at least 2 or 3 more skyrim re-releases

I'm having a good time with this game, but not a great time. The characters are fantastic, and the world is fun to explore and seems to have something new to do around every corner. Combat is fun and interactive. The open-endedness of a lot of situations makes to look like there will be a good amount of replayability. There's also a great amount of content for the price of the game.

I really want to love this game but it's bogged down by some of the worst camera and controls I've ever seen. The camera has a nasty habit of falling into pits, and the locked angle means that a task as simple as looking up a flight of stairs is a challenge. The controls are similarly lacking. Sometimes you'll try to move to some location lower down and the game will decide that the logical way to do this is to jump down and take 30 damage rather than use the ladder next to you. AI controlled characters are a chore to have helping you. They'll run straight into your cloudkill spell and nearly die, then become hostile to you.

Overall it's a game with huge potential which is somewhat held down by poor controls and a frustrating camera. 7.5/10

Every patch adds a multitude of new bugs. Right now, the game crashes when making a skill check or saving throw (not every time, but often enough to make the game almost unplayable).

Lacks an official mod support. You have to use a third person mod manager, and if you want to play a modded multiplayer, you have to put much effort into having the same version, the same order of mods, and even then, it's not guaranteed you can play together. I just spend over 2 hours trying to fix an issue of a friend not being able to join my lobby, modded and unmodded. Every solution I could find on the internet isn't working.

I guess I won't be playing until Larian either stops patching the game (since that breaks both vanilla and modded saves ever since I started playing pre-patch 4), or adds an official mod support. Because right now, the game is unplayable modded, and vanilla game is extremely unpolished (and buggy).

Also, it took them a few months to fix shield bash not working and for Halsin to actually play his voice lines as a companion, so I assume if you want to play a finished product, and not one that seems like an early access, you will have to wait a good few years before this game becomes playable, or before Larian stops trying.

Baldur's Gate 3 is an absolute masterpiece that effortlessly transports players into a realm of fantastical adventures, rich storytelling, and strategic combat. As a long-time fan of the franchise, I had high expectations, and I'm thrilled to say that Larian Studios has exceeded them in every way possible.

First and foremost, the depth of storytelling in Baldur's Gate 3 is unparalleled. From the very beginning, you're thrust into a world teeming with political intrigue, dark magic, and compelling characters. Each dialogue choice feels meaningful, shaping not only your own character's journey but also the fate of the world around you. The writing is superb, immersing you in a captivating narrative that keeps you hooked from start to finish.

The gameplay mechanics are where Baldur's Gate 3 truly shines. The turn-based combat is both challenging and rewarding, requiring careful planning and tactical thinking. Whether you're engaging in a heated battle against formidable foes or navigating treacherous dungeons filled with traps and puzzles, every encounter feels dynamic and engaging. The freedom to approach situations in multiple ways adds a layer of depth to the gameplay, ensuring that no two playthroughs are ever the same.

Visually, Baldur's Gate 3 is a stunning achievement. The attention to detail in the environments, character designs, and spell effects is nothing short of breathtaking. Each location feels alive and brimming with personality, inviting you to explore every nook and cranny in search of hidden secrets and valuable loot.

Furthermore, the voice acting is top-notch, bringing the diverse cast of characters to life in a way that feels authentic and immersive. Whether you're conversing with allies or facing off against adversaries, the performances are consistently impressive and help to further immerse you in the world of Baldur's Gate.

In conclusion, Baldur's Gate 3 is a must-play for fans of RPGs and newcomers alike. With its gripping storyline, strategic gameplay, and stunning visuals, it sets a new standard for what an RPG can achieve. Larian Studios has crafted a truly unforgettable experience that will keep you coming back for more, long after the credits roll.

It really pains me to go against the consensus here, but this *might* be the best game of all times - at some point in the future, when it ceases to crash twice per hour.
If your PC is not solidly ABOVE recommendations, expect it to CTD during dialogues and cutscenes A LOT. For a game based on an existing and well tested engine (D:OS 2) that has been in EA for *three* bloody years - not excusable.

Update: Patch #2, Hotfix #6
New computer, a MILE above recommended specs, all drivers up to date of course.
Clean new game, started after patch #2. Act 1 runs well. Single crash in 30 hours. Now in act #2, just had my FOURTH crash this evening. Don't want to imagine act 3...
STILL not able to recommend this, I'm afraid.

Final Update: Patch #4, Hotfix #10
Crash, crash, crashedy-crash, crashcrash-crashedy-crash.
I quit. This game is obviously broken beyond repair. And no, it's not my rig. That has run Starfield in the meantime for almost 400 hours with NO significant stability issues.

Post-final update, patch #6, hotfix #18
So, well, I yielded after some more fixes. Did *everything* recommended to minimize crashes. Clean inventory, fresh boot, no program whatsoever in the background, disabled launcher, deleted level cache, optimized settings, up-to-date drivers. Was able to play through the game with only a few annoying random CTDs (sometimes an entire evening WITHOUT crashes. Reached the final battle. 9 crashes in 9 attempts, every time at another point (once even when it was trying to switch to the "You Win" cutscene.
Larian, you owe me 60 bucks for this burning heap of bugs.

Baldur's Gate 3 delivers a breathtaking and immersive experience that transports players to a world filled with magic, mystery, and adventure. As a long-time fan of the Dungeons & Dragons universe, I was eagerly anticipating this release, and I can confidently say that it exceeded all of my expectations.

One of the most striking aspects of Baldur's Gate 3 is its stunning visuals and attention to detail. From the lush landscapes to the intricate character designs, every aspect of the game is meticulously crafted, pulling players deeper into its fantastical realm. The environments are rich and diverse, ranging from bustling cities to dark and foreboding dungeons, each with its own unique atmosphere and challenges.

The gameplay itself is incredibly engaging, seamlessly blending elements of classic RPGs with innovative mechanics. The ability to interact with the environment in meaningful ways adds a layer of depth to exploration and combat, allowing for creative solutions to encounters. Whether engaging in strategic turn-based battles or navigating intricate dialogue trees, every decision feels impactful and meaningful, shaping the course of the adventure.

One of the standout features of Baldur's Gate 3 is its robust character customization options. From choosing your character's race, class, and abilities to shaping their personality through dialogue choices, the game offers a level of freedom rarely seen in modern RPGs. This allows players to truly inhabit their role within the world, forging their own path and forging meaningful connections with the diverse cast of characters they encounter along the way.

Speaking of characters, Baldur's Gate 3 boasts a memorable cast of companions, each with their own personalities, motivations, and storylines to explore. Whether forming alliances or facing off against enemies, the relationships you forge with your companions have a tangible impact on the narrative, adding depth and replay value to the experience.

Furthermore, the storytelling in Baldur's Gate 3 is nothing short of exceptional. From epic quests to intimate character moments, the narrative is expertly crafted, drawing players into a gripping tale. The world of Faerûn feels alive and vibrant, teeming with lore and history waiting to be uncovered.

One of the very rare few games that I've played that genuinely feels like it ruins almost all other video games for me. The sheer amount of player freedom, choices to be made, build variety, character dialogues, moral dilemmas etc. that the game features just leaves every other game I've ever played in my life in the dust. These days I have very little patience for newer experiences and I have a rather unreasonably high bar for what I consider to be a game that I place in my favorites, but BG3 has shattered all expectations - even moreso considering the fact that prior to this, I wasn't even a fan of CRPGs or D&D in general. Unlike most games I've played in recent years, this game genuinely feels like a labor of love by dedicated and talented devs, and the fact it received GOTY and is recognized for its achievements gives me hope in the midst of a rather bleak moment in the games industry.

I recognize it's sometimes unreasonable to say this considering every developer and game has its own strengths and uniqueness to it, but I do hope that developers and designers will look to BG3 as a lesson and inspiration for what a game of this scale, depth, and dedication looks and feels like.

P.S.: pls add Minthara as an Origin character :c

Before I rant I just want to say BG3 10/10. 

Now for some rantings:

Divinity Original Sin II completely changed how I felt about what games are capable of. Baldur's Gate III proved just how unique the ideas in DOS2 were by meshing the format with DND. One things for sure... the studio behind these games are quite different from their contemporaries. Where others have attempted to garner attention with flashy licensing deals, battle passes, and loot boxes, BG3 instead brings us back to the time where games were just... games. 100% of the progression in BG3 and DOS2 are in-game, no pay 2 win, no store page, no paid DLC. Hopefully this game allows the AAA industry giants like Ubisoft, Activision, 2K, EA, etc... to take a hard look at their financial models and maybe just maybe... put more time and effort into making a fun but challenging game on launch rather than the shopping malls most games are becoming nowadays. BG3 10/10.

let's talk about how this game has already released 4 hotfixes and 2 patches on top of being one of the most popular games of all time.  wtf?  not only did the games release shake up the world of gaming, its post-release has been nothing short of perfect.  Larian Studios deserves every bit of acclaim it gets, and more.

this game continues to surprise me with its sheer depth and complexity - there's as many solutions to as many problems as one can think of.  the reactivity of the world and characters to your player actions is amazing.  this game is like no other, and is probably, in my opinion, the best video game ever made.

EDIT:  I do have some criticisms now.  One of the things I originally thought was great, the constant updates/bugfixes/whathaveyou, are actually getting a little out of line.

Imagine this: you're half-way through the very long game, then updates come out, and they are MASSIVE, code-changing, mechanics-changing, story-changing, you name it, updates.  There's several big issues with this.

First, it is pretty easy that the save game becomes broken.  Now you have to start over, even if you didn't want to.

Second, the mechanics/story/etc. change, and maybe now you want to start over.  but, you wonder is it worth it just to see what's different?

Third, you know what you're doing but then you do something as simple as visit a vendor, and the entire system is changed.  Yes, the new version may be "better", but I'm half way through a game, I don't want to have to re-learn how to play it.

I think doing bugfixes and hotfixes was a great idea in this early part of the games release; HOWEVER, I think changing core mechanics, battle mechanics, lines of dialogue, and essential pieces like this, should have probably waited for a Definitive Edition release - or - until the majority of players had finished their first run of the game.

Its better for the players, and its better for the game, because, if say I had beat the game already, and then found out you changed/updated a lot of things, that gives me more incentive to play it through again and see the differences.

I do not, however, want to be in the middle of the game and have the game completely change on me, when I was enjoying it as it was.

That all being said, its still a fantastic game.

BUT IF YOU HAVEN'T ALREADY PURCHASED/PLAYED GAME - I WOULD HIGHLY RECOMMEND YOU WAIT TO DO SO, UNTIL THEY ARE DONE FUCKING AROUND WITH THE GAME AND RELEASE ITS FINAL VERSION.

Thanks and have a wonderful day.

A fantastic game, one which you can tell the developers truly care deeply for and must've had a lot of fun making. Baldur's Gate 3 blows modern gaming out of the water, especially with the recent lacklustre releases from other companies. It's given me hope for the future that perhaps the gaming industry can return to a time when greedy companies who couldn't care less about their customers, microtransactions and DLC that was clearly just cut out from the final game was practically unheard of. Everything from the story to the individual characters is written flawlessly and the companions you meet throughout the story are so well written and refined that they put the generic characterless companions from other games (especially open world games) to shame. And, like myself, you don't even need to play DnD to understand and enjoy this masterpiece, the quality of the game speaks for itself.

Baldur's Gate III is a sad example of tons of wasted potential. With the right writers, with some competent game designers and a clear content roadmap, this truly could have been a worthy Game of the  Year.

As it stands, the game is basically an inferior clone of Solasta: Crown of the Magister, except with better graphics and far worse gameplay mechanics, a distinct lack of customizability and modding potential, a horrible cast of characters that you want to strangle after a 2 minute conversation and a nonsensical story that craps all over established Mindflayer and Githyanki lore. Speaking of which. Are you a fan of BG II? Do you remember being a fan of characters like Valygar and Haer'Dalis? Well, in Larian's eyes 'extraplanar' now means 'non-binary drag queens who make skeletons dance for entertainment purposes'. Yeah. I was actually relieved when I found out they didn't turn Zariel into someone who identifies as a man. I just hope these people never get their hands on the Planescape Torment IP. You get it, right? This game has a serious case of gender ideology allyship, right down to the incredibly offensive 'body type' nonsense that also plagued Cyberpunk.

Is it all bad? No, mechanically the game is fine, it's your standard party-based Western CRPG, there are just entirely too many chests, satchels, barrels and other (often locked) loot boxes added everywhere, so if you are a completionist, the game quickly becomes busywork. The AD&D system and combat mechanics are implemented well, but they removed all the interesting stuff like character alignment and meaningful differences between the races, leaving us with a bland and communist interpretation of Faerun. The inventory also reflects this communist mindset and design philosophy. There are millions of lackluster items, all with with poor to downright unhelpful effects and a couple really good ones that you have to be lucky enough to stumble across. A lot in this game is left up to chance, and in my eyes that's just poor game design. I don't want to spend hours sifting through random crap, only to find a necklace of Charisma +20 lodged in a dead cat's anus. How can this game be worse than Solasta at this? It's not like Solasta was the gold standard of CRPGs, far from it. But at least they didn't encourage you to click on every single speck of dust in their game world.

What Larian did give us was a bunch of fun and meaningful decisions, even though the eventual ending is about as good as Mass Effect 3 and nothing really mattered. And the Jaheira character, she is pretty faithful to the original, so I'm very pleased about her inclusion. I am also pleased with the amount of freedom the game gives you, especially in the sense that you can kill almost anyone you don't like. There are hardly any consequences and you can act good or evil without any internal consistancy and the characters, nor the game world, will punish you for it. I will admit, finally running a spear through a certain Aasimar was probably one of my happiest gaming moment for 2024. And I seriously can't stop cutting off Karlach's head. I must have seen her ugly, malformed mug roll through the mud about 10 times now.

Do I recommend you try this game? Absolutely not. I finished it because I paid for it in Early Access, but this was definitely my last Larian game, ever. This game killed any and all faith I had in the company. Too bad, because some of the people who worked on this clearly have talent. All i can do is hope AI development speeds up to the point where I can design my own party and rely on my own writing instead of being subjected to more of this distasteful gender propaganda.

One last thing: there is no dwarf dominatrix with a whip in Baldur's Gate, so don't get your hopes up. Larian teases you with this, but she's already dead, and it's a pointless quest. Another wasted chance to make this game into something worth playing. Well, we'll always have Loviatars priest.

This is something else.  I usually bounce around different games/genres in my free time such as rts, 4x turn-based strategy, fps, card games even.  But as soon as I started this, I just dropped my other gaming and spent all my free time playing this wonderful CRPG for a few weeks.  

It has a depth to it.  Characters and conversation pathways are very branched out and diverse.  Graphics are popping even on my lower end gaming laptop.  The turn-based combat system is fantastic and this plus the story is what really drives the game.  

It has a great atmosphere and I was truly sad to be finished with my campaign.  I'm already thinking about having another go at it with a different lead (you customize from start) and focusing on different ensemble throughout.

This world of BG 3 was made with a passion and is a treat to immerse yourself in.  There is a reason this is the only unique game among Steam top games.  9 of the top 10 of them are shooters/battle royale types and then there is this standing out amidst those others.  I just had to see for myself what made BG 3 so unique, and what a great decision that was!  

Gaming done right.  Period.

I'm late to review this game. I'll just give my input as an old tabletop and PC gamer who played the entire Baldur's Gate franchise. It's extremely good, well made, attentive and an accurate implementation of D&D rules and lore. Not a whole lot of negatives, except for maybe the enormity of this game. Too much to explore, too many character arcs, side quests up the ass, insane item glut, so much to steal and so many backs to stab. A good problem to have in a game I guess, but it can be overwhelming. Definitely not a pick-up-and-play kind of game and the turned-based combat isn't for everybody. But the story is great, and the characters are well written and voice acted. BG3 is similar in scope and time spent on the Witcher 3 base game.

Absolutely incredible in every way. As game for three decades, it's the best game in the RPG genre I've ever played by a longshot.

Having gone through the entire trilogy of Baldur's Gate games, and finally finished this one, I can say I am glad I stuck around for the whole ride.

- 5e DnD has been changed slightly for this game, and I think the changes have so far been for the best. BG3 knew how to tweak the underlying system for the video game's maximum enjoyment and I am glad they did. I wasn't sure DnD 5e would be enough to carry a game that is trying to do so much, but they added some clever complexity that works great for the video game (but might not be feasible at a table).
- As someone who went through the previous two games immediately before this one, I can say confidently that you do not need to play the previous titles to get a good time out of this. That said, as someone who did play the previous titles, I was given plenty of callbacks that I understood.
- Like the previous two entries in the series, the story, characters, quests, and overall plot are the strongest suit of the games. While I am not a big fan of the Forgotten Realms as a whole, the stories told in it have been worth the effort I have put in.
- The game looks gorgeous, certainly a big jump from coming off the previous two games, but I think it was the only way it could be done today. The amount of motion capture this game must have seems staggering. Conversations feel so fluid and real, and just looking at everyone as they speak has been lovely.
- Like many others, I find that I might be even more well-prepared for playing real TTRPGs after my playthrough was finished. DnD 5e is also not my favorite TTRPG, but this didn't stop my enjoyment of BG3.
- As someone who played Dragon Age games abck in the day, I can see the influence in this title, and I can also see that they have made many of the ideas they might have taken and made them their own.

Overall: this is a game worth checking out.

I bought this game because i was craving for something new to play, since 2023 dropped nothing but shit games.
I have never been interested in turn based combat games as i am more familiar and intrigued with shooters, so this game was a gamble for me first when i picked it up. 

I can honestly say i have never been blown away by a game so unique for it's genre and it's unique approach to setting the staple to what a good game is supposed to be. It has been one of the best experiences i have had in my 20 years of gaming. I haven't even finished the game yet since i dont want it to end, it's really that amazing.

I love games that introduce a good story, and since it's an RPG i didn't have any big hopes that it would deliver just that. I imagined it would follow the basic formula of ''Here take this quest, go there, kill that thing, return and get your reward'' and repeat. No character or development to the quests. But that is simply not true in this case. Every single person you talk to if it is to just to simply chat or take a quest from literally changes the game in some aspects. These can be huge and they can be minor you will simply find that out by making them. They can be personal changes in your party, how your companions will react to you how much they will like you or hate you. They can change the world around you literally bringing up new things to do or things that are now unavailable to do thanks to your poor/good choices. All these choices you make will affect the outcome of the game since there are countless different endings that are not bland at all, but extremely detailed, making them all feel crucial to the players taste when making their choices, deciding who they want to be in the world.

Alot of RPG's lack something that other games of different genres such as Red Dead Redemption, The Last of Us or God of War dont. Character development. This game defies that bane entirely, your character is mute and has no dialouge when chosing things to say (Except certain cutscenes) And your character feels more alive than ever still. There are so many dialouge options to pick not just simply ''yes'' or ''no'' but things that gives the character life and his/hers personality. Not to mention your companions you are going to encounter on your journey that has one of the best pieces of writen character arc and dialouge i have ever seen or heard. You start to literally care for someone that is not real and their feelings and ambitions because they feel so alive and real when you speak with them.

The score of the game is amazing, nothing more to say about that honestly, listen for yourself.

When it comes to the world of the game and it's accessability open world is a sort of. The game is divided into acts and during each act you are in a specific area with things to do and explore. People to talk to, help and kill if you so wish. You are limited to that specific area until you reach the next act of the game by playing the story, this might at first sound like it is limiting the players freedom but in my opinion it is encourging the player to explore the points of interest and characters that are available to them. An important thing to mention is that when you are done with an act and you enter the next one in the story, you can not return to the area again. You can not talk to the characters there, you can not explore it it is simply over. This will impact your run in the game since there could be important characters or quests or enemies you didn't explore there that could and will impact the outcome of the game.

Baldur's Gate 3 is a great game. This comes from someone who is not only a fan of CRPG but also the original TTRPG. Larian absolutely knocked it out of the park, but i'm sure you don't need me to tell you. There are some points that may rebuke certain players :

1. This is a very horny game. Larian knew what they were doing when showcasing the bear scene. There is an option to turn of nudity, however, it won't help with your defense if someone walks in the room during a frisky scene
2. This is a very long game. It took me around 450h to complete the game 4 times and get the 100%. An average playtrought will need around 100 to 120h. It is important to note that I am very slow, so my situation might not be applicable to everyone.
3. It is a turn-based combat rpg, so if turn-based combat is not your thing, you might very well not enjoy this game.

One of the greatest strenght of BG3 is the way it react in a way that matters to your decisions. Since every dialogue is mocaped and voice acted, Larian cannot take the simple route most rpg takes by planning a simple text. One would think this restricts the potential for BG3 to make companions of npcs react to events, yet it doesn't seem to. After all the time I spent with it, there are dialogue, items and outcomes to quests I have never seen in game. The map is huge and filled with new things to discover at every corner. Most important of all, it never seems like are there just to be slain. A majority of the time, you can tell what they were doing before you showed up to behead them, that is if you choose to do so. 

On another note, the decisions you make do not impact the story as much as it let believe. Most choices to be made dictate the path you will take, but the destination will majoritarily stay the same. No matter what is done, the second and third acts of the game will end in the same fight despite your choices. Act 1 is not included as you don't even need to engage with it's content to proceed to the next acts. The game ends with 2 possible ends, but the permutations are so numerous I wouldn't dare to count them all. So while the story cannot be changed in a major way, the consequences of your decisions taken torought the game are taken into account a displayed with such care the small amount of possible ending doesn't even bother me. 

As for the system, it is much more simpler than most crpg you can find, the original was meant to be played pen, paper, dice and no calculator (looking at you Owlcat, I like your games but the math gives me a headache). It is very similar to D&D 5e, but with quality of life improvement to simplify so rules while adding to the possible combat options. The fights gain a lot of depth with the addition of environmental hazards and conditions not present in the original pen and paper rpg.  The added rules do give way to overpowered builds and cheese strats, but I wasn't even aware of most of them until my second playtrought. It is also a solo non-competitive game, so balance doesn't really seem like an issue to me unless it truly ruins the experience of first time players. 

To conclude, Shadowheart is bae.

Coming from Divinity 2, with some reservations about it, I could not wait to finally be able to gather my trusty friend and jump into this new adventure now that it was officially released.

We started the game excited about what was to come and it took us a total of two months to the clock to finish it. In our case, we decided to go with two custom characters and build relationships with the various origins characters in the game. We created our characters and thrust ourselves into the new campaign, both completely new to the world of Baldur's Gate, but not new to the work of Larian. 

The game's writing is amazing, with every choice having the weight you'd expect if not more. The approach to the narrative, storytelling, and story progression is in your hands completely. From smaller things like specific races and backgrounds having extra options during certain dialogues giving more depth to your story, to annihilating an entire faction. Easily one of the best implementations of DnD to a game.

8h into the game, while exploring, we unlocked a way to reset the levels of our characters. Considering this was a title developed after Divinity 2, I went into it expecting there would be the possibility to change your character's appearance, but that wasn't the case. When the option wasn't available alongside the respec, especially as it has less actual impact on the game, I decided a quick search was mandatory as both me and my friend wanted to change a few things about our characters we were not happy with.
Although a way to change your looks has now been patched into the game, that was not the case more than two months ago and in an attempt at enjoying the many more hours we'd have on the title, we restarted from scratch, recreated our characters and quickly got back to where we were. 

After that, it was smooth sailing. We kept exploring every crook and cranny and would never leave a region before making sure all loose ends were close and we had explored everything. The quantity and quality of content the game offers it's magical and calls for multiple playthroughs just to see how much love and attention has been put into it. We took our time - clearly - and made sure to play as meticulously as we would alone not letting the coop get in the way of attention to lore, books or dialogues. We had a wonderful time, really. Great game to play with the right person!

All dialogues have so much depth and have been motion acted! There is a moment in the late game, where one of the dialogues has such amazing voice acting and animation that it has forever engraved itself in my mind. That's how good it was. Another moment that comes to mind is a discovery we made during a mission. Something very unexpected, yet it was the truth and completely changed our objectives going forward, at least for our roleplay whereas for others it might have motivated them even further. This is the beauty of this game, everything you do and every approach is just as valid as the next one. This was not unique in these 160 magical hours. Throughout all of them, me and my friend kept being shocked by the level of detail, interaction, and ramifications of the story. There are so many other examples I could give. 

But where there is good, there is bad. During the final Act we did encountered a few bumps. Still god-tier, but it is worth mentioning. Progression in particular felt sluggish, as if at every corner we would meet a wall that would make all our choices and plans crumble somewhere else as a consequence. It took us many hours, with a lot of different approaches to our progress to find the perfect balance for what to do first.

Regardless of our best attempts and careful approach, during our finale, we could not forsee this turn of events. We had to make a really hard choice to get the best outcome and find common ground with my friend, so I was already saddened by that. Right after that, my favorite origin character, my romance and companion through most of the run took a steep turn I didn't expect in their story. I was so confused by this end result considering the path we had both walked on was not the one they were now choosing, even slightly hinting at it being also my idea when it never was. I later learned shortly after seeing the finale that what I thought was an inconsequential choice made during a dialogue -  one I would even say was quite neutral - was the dialogue that would permanently determine their story. This was prior to even learning and talking about the potential alternative new objective for this origin character. There is no other dialogue or check of any sort that can change that and, in my experience, nothing in the game made me understand things would have gone this way after I made this choice. Hell, it even sounded like it was still up for debate. 70h after I learned my price. 

For the whole game, I have been preaching this, so: I know it's technically the result of my own choices, and since then I accepted the end result and found many ways to level with it when it comes to roleplay. That said, I stand my ground that having the choice to determine which path the character will follow, prior to knowing what are the options, and with a neutral response isn't well done, not when for everyone else it was quite clear. A simple dialogue after the events would have done it.
 
Add to insult injury, although I was the host, my friend during the whole finale was the only character visible besides the origins, only because he had the character that could defeat the final boss in his group. That was the case even for dialogues with my romance and companion. The coop never had any such issues until now, often having our characters at least in the background during dialogues.

The game is a solid top-down CRPG, and controls very similarly to Divinity 2. I wished for some of the prior games' limitations not to show up again. After all these years of early access and a new camera zoom that can go close to third-person perspective, I was disappointed in not having the choice to bind movement to WASD when that is the default for controller players. Especially in a game that, with all the dev's good intentions, still struggles with camera angles and environment objects at times. Yes, things become transparent when too close to the camera, but are still interactable making your character move in the wrong direction or teleport back to the area you just came from simply cause it's a big door and its hitbox is still in front of your mouse.
As a hoarder, something I also was hoping would have been improved is inventory management. There are plenty of bags in the game to order your items around, although you can't name them. When sorting, identical items will not merge into one stack, making entire lines of the same spell scroll unless you manually stack them, which I obviously did. A small icon next to books to let us know if we had read them would have also been a nice addition, especially with the large amount of literature available. 
Other than that, the game plays perfectly fine and it's an extremely polished experience, with almost no gameplay limitations but your imagination.

Still, you know what they say: it's not the destination, but the journey that matters. Although I had wished for a better ending to my adventure, nothing can change our journey. What really matters is how excited, happy, and impatient I was to come home and play this game, and no amount of sour endings could erase that. I made a mark in this world and shared this crazy adventure with a friend, with highlights we'll bring back for likely the rest of our lives as already do with other titles, or until the next Larian game. 

I find myself already thinking of what to do on my next run. No matter how hurt I may be from how a part of my story ended this time, it clearly can't keep me away from this game or lower it's magnificence, and that speaks volumes.

Great dialogue and story, awesome mechanics. Fun level design and all around great gameplay… when it works. 

This game is a buggy mess and shouldn’t be considered in a playable state. Main story works fine but side quests and even quests that lead into the main story are broken to hell with wild bugs. Act 3 alone is a bugfest that honestly ruins the experience. 

If the game worked it would be a 10/10 but Jesus Christ it just doesn’t work! I have over 200 hours and 100 hours are from restarting due to game breaking bugs. Still haven’t finished the game and before you say anything my pc requirements exceed the maximum recommended specs and I rarely have issue with any other game… unless they are unoptimized to shit like this one. 

Don’t get me wrong I want to support this game because it has great bones, no microtransactions, and has a fantastic story… but fuck it’s like it is still in early access. 

I cannot recommend this game until the bugs and issues are resolved.

The best role playing game since Planescape: Torment (and, if you are not that old, since Dragon Age Origins and Mass Effect Trilogy). The amount of content and freedom you have in BG3 is unprecedented, and it's hard to find another RPG that combines story, character development and exploration so well.

I could talk about how good this game is for hours, and I did with my friends. Mind you, we are all 40+ yo and have a lot of things to do. But for BG3, we managed to find 100+ hours to finish it. Because it's THAT good.

However, there is one big issue (at least for me), and it's the combat system. Obviously, DnD isn't the best choice for a computer RPG, and in terms of battles BG3 feels like a step back compared to Divinity Original Sin series. I don't get why we should limit ourselves by a dice roll in XXI century, and getting those critical misses is incredibly frustrating on balanced, might lead to losing a battle on tactician, and even be game ending in honour mode.

Sure, there are a lot of ways to "cheat" in this DnD implementation, and there are many very powerful character builds, but dice roll rng still feels annoying and unnecessary in a modern computer game. Still, BG3 on balanced is definitely easier than Original Sin on normal, so at least there's some counter balance to using a paper based game system in a CRPG. And other than that, the game is practically flawless.

Baldurs Gate 3 is a great game.  Looks great, the plot is engaging and interesting, combat is satisfying (when it's not unbelievably frustrating), and there's lots of little things to do that make the world feel alive.  And, for TTRPG fans, it's an incredibly faithful translation of the 5e rules, a better than the previous Baldur's Gates/Icewind Dales/etc did with 2nd/3rd Ed D&D.  It redefines fantasy tropes and presents scenarios that allow the player to actually role-play a character rather than always go for the "most perfect" choice.  
So, obviously, this game is worth playing.
That being said, there's some real bad flaws in there that need to be addressed.  Some I can see getting patched up, others are inherent to the game itself.

The former: 
The camera:  Oh sweet, merciful Selune, the camera.  It is probably the single worst thing about the game; it will get hung up on objects in the scene and pull WAY back making interacting with the world much more difficult.  Sometimes higher floors will display between your camera and character, forcing you to go to the absolute (get it?) tightest shot of your characters face to see anything, again making the environmental interactions a pain.  And then, on occasion, it'll just freak out and bounce around, trying to find an angle that it thinks works.  It's awful.  
The timing: There's this weird concept where your party can be in turn-based-mode but the rest of the world is still moving through time normally.  This is truly insane; it's as if your whole party and the people they are immediately fighting are literally waiting while everyone involved politely takes their turn, all the while other NPCs are just walking around at a normal pace and glancing over going "what the hell are those guys doing", until they too get sucked into this weird game and start participating in the "I'm next" fight.  It makes setting up ambushes much more tedious to arrange.  
The Shadowlands: Without giving too much away, at some point in the game you will encounter an area that does Necrotic damage every turn, with (as far as I can tell) only one solution to mitigate.  Unfortunately for me that solution bugged out so I was forced to screw around for a few hours in the easiest mode until I found a way to get around it.  To my mind, the entire area should have used the much-under-appreciated "Exhaustion rules" from 5e, maybe inflict a level every so many rounds, something like that, but either way, they gotta fix that bug since the plot funnels to that point.

The Latter:
Incredibly mopey yet horny world: If NPCs aren't moaning on and on and on about their misery or threatening to murder you then they are desperately trying to get in your pants.  It becomes comical after awhile, especially against the backdrop of the plot; "What's that?  You've got a worm in your brain too?  I find that irresistible...".  Having the option to romance a ton of different characters sounds good on paper but plays out in a very awkward way.
Wildly Imbalanced Encounters: Definitely not the rule but, in several important spots, the encounter challenge is way too high.  That wouldn't necessarily be the case if it weren't for the timing issue mentioned above.  Trying to take down a building full of enemies quietly, a room at a time using Silence and surprise attacks gets all screwed up when patrols are still moving in real time against your round-by-round actions.
No Hovering: While you can fly from a surface to a surface, there is no levitation.  You can't have a mage float up off the ground out of melee range and bombard the enemies with fireballs and magic missiles, only to get shot out of the air by a lucky crossbow-bolt.  Real missed opportunity.  
No Weather/Day Cycle: Or at least I haven't encountered any.  Huge missed opportunity; could of had rain dousing fire and interfering with missile attacks, returning to sites at night to loot the place while everyone is asleep, etc.  

All that being said, if you made it this far, I do recommend buying it even at full price.  But, boy-oh-boy, prepare yourself for some moments of real frustration.  Great game, 9/10.

Played since very, very early access. Has been amazing to watch this game go from 'can die to imps and fire in the first 5 minutes bc of glitches' to what it is today :)

The Good:
Great game that continues to get better with each patch. I really like the story and the depth of the conversation tree's. The voice acting, sound effects, and music is outstanding. The game mechanics are fun and the closest thing I have found to playing 5e as a video game. The Mature game rating is defiantly appropriate and I've enjoyed the adult setting and how far they push some of those aspects of the game. You can play as so many different races, classes, and moral paths to get several replays out of it. 

-

The Bad:
Some of the graphics are a little sloppy. Hands moving though things, armor glitching, etc. Even playing with a 3080 and having everything turned up, it sometimes feels a little last gen in some areas. Honestly this is a minor issue and every patch it seems to clean it up a bit. 

I just don't like how much inventory management there is. I'm constantly sending stuff to camp or cleaning my inventory. Its not always clear what items will be useful, so its easier to send it all back to camp than to risk losing it forever. I honestly spend 1/2 my time playing the game just sorting inventory. 

-

What I'd change: 
- Ability to send items to any teammate, even if they are currently back at camp. 
- A "wares" bag where you can put anything you want to sell. Currently when you add something to wares, it clogs up the main inventory page and cant be placed in a bag. 
- Documents and items with no action should not automatically show up on the action/weapon wheels. It takes forever to scroll through it. 
- Items shared between teammates should also show up on all weapon/action wheels or not be shareable. Scrolling though the inventory trying to track down that random spell scroll you need is a pain and really takes me outta the fight.




Worth every penny 9.5/10

I have finally finished it, what an outstanding game. 

This game came out in early access in 2020, i decided not to get it and waited 3 years for the final release, the wait was absolutely worth it. 

It's perhaps the best RPG i've played since The Witcher 3. Everything, from the story, to the gameplay, graphics is exquisite quality. 

The story is set up in a very clever way, all major and minor quests are interwoven together so that your decisions in small ones make a big impact towards the end of the game. I have not found a single quest that was filler material or boring. What stands out the best from the story point is the characters. Each and every character is thoroughly written, well voiced and have a distinct personality. The characters are so distinctly different from each other that you will quickly have favorites and non-favorites. Let's go over some of them in summary:

1. Shadowheart: Absolutely the best girl and my favorite in the game, she's a cleric, have a "Damsel in distress" story arc which is a joy to explore and complete her companion quest. Very logically written character.

2. Karlach: Karlach! Can i say enough about how adorable this character is? For some funny reason she always calls us player "Soldier". Absolutely endearing character, a bit rakish and devastating in combat. A must have character in your party.

3. Wyll: A Warlock, always sounding upbeat and boosting the party's morale.

There's so many more characters you'll encounter during your playthrough.

Now gameplay, combat is punchy and smartly designed, i'm more of a RTwP (Real-time with Pause) RPG liker but this game made me like Turn based combat, the physical attacks are devastating, the spells are spectacular, especially the Warlock/Sorcerer spells are great. Cleric/healing spells and others are a thing of their own. Moving party here and there and is great, it's basically D&D game with much simplified combat. You will feel the imposition of the spells and attacks during combat.

Graphics, the game looks beautiful, character models are superbly detailed and environments are colorful and have a sense of atmosphere. The spells graphics are great, the costumes, armors and awesome looking, you can dye your armor with different colors. 

Sound, just click on Fireball in a sorcerer/cleric spell bar and listen to the character preparing the spell with whiffs of fire getting reading to be shot, the sound design is impactful, certain environments have atmospheric sound that set the tone of the area, some areas are downright jolly and some are spooky. Voiceovers are professional and well done. 

This game needs to be experienced, one pointer i would give is to not skip any side quests, i skipped some in Act 1 by mistake or didn't understand properly and had to struggle with XP, you need XP to level up, so do all the quests in order to have proper level as the later fights in the game get quite tough. 

All in all, it's a great achievement by Larian to develop such a game, it won several awards including Game of the Year (2023) and it was well deserved. This game is not to be missed.

Baldur's Gate 3 is everything I wanted in a D&D video game. It's as close to playing tabletop D&D as I can imagine a game getting. The ONLY real issue I have is that cross-platform play isn't available *yet*. I'm the kind of gamer that is all about the story when it comes to video games, often lamenting a lack of depth in game plots (and the impact of decision making) despite great gameplay/mechanics, but BG3 might have*too much* story. It's so deep and nuanced and adapts so well to your decisions and random ideas that I've purchased it here on Steam, on Xbox series X, and other copies for friends. It's THAT good. I can't recommend this game enough! I can only hope that Larian puts out more content for Baldur's Gate 3 in the future (more subclasses and companions in particular would be nice).

Okay, so let me tell you about Baldur's Gate 3. I've played a LOT of games, but nothing—absolutely nothing—has grabbed me quite like this one. It's like the folks at Larian Studios took everything I love about fantasy and RPGs, mixed it all up, and then dialed it up to eleven.

First off, creating your character is a trip. You've got all these races and classes to choose from, and it actually feels like it matters who you decide to be. Your character's background changes how people in the game treat you and what options you have for dealing with stuff, which is super cool.

Then there's the fighting. It's turn-based, which might sound a bit slow if you're used to hack-and-slash, but trust me, it's intense. You've gotta be smart about how you approach battles, using the environment and planning your moves. It's like chess, but with fireballs and sneaky backstabs.

The game looks incredible, too. The worlds are so detailed and beautiful that I've spent hours just wandering around, looking at everything. And the magic effects? Insanely cool. Every time I cast a spell, I'm sitting there like, "Wow, did I just do that?"

But what really makes Baldur's Gate 3 special is the story and the characters. It's not just some generic "save the world" deal. Your choices actually matter, and they can change the game in big ways. The folks you meet and team up with aren't just there to carry extra swords; they've got their own stories, and getting to know them is half the fun.

Voice acting and dialogue? Top-notch. I've laughed, I've gotten a bit teary-eyed, and I've shouted at my screen because of the choices I've had to make. It's like being in a really good fantasy movie, but you're the star.

In a nutshell, Baldur's Gate 3 is the most fun I've had with a game in ages. It's like the ultimate fantasy adventure that you never want to end. Whether you're a hardcore RPG player or just someone who likes a good story, you've gotta check it out. Hats off to Larian Studios for making this masterpiece. Seriously, if you haven't played it yet, what are you waiting for?

Super fun combat system with a single mechanic that ruins it. The miss chances harm the pacing of combat and just lead to me feeling like I was cheated out of an attack, especially if I put in the work to buff my hit rate to 98% only for it to miss. I understand that a lot of the game is balanced around the mechanic but I just hate it. I spent my 140 hours save scumming every one of my turns because playing without doing so was miserable. Negativity bias also probably plays a big part since it feels like the enemies land every single attack.

Aside from some performance issues, the rest of the game is probably a 10/10.

In Baldur's Gate 3, there is a lot to do. And I mean a LOT! Playing with one of my friends on multiplayer mode, he was telling me that there had been a ton of things that I wanted to explore was not even remotely in his play through on his first single player run. There was an entire other area that we had discovered that he had never seen before but had fun exploring. We hadn't even scratched the surface 25 hours in when the first Act ended. 

There are also some really cool things that can happen if you choose to play as one of the characters already made for you at the beginning of the game. I don't know if that is possible for the custom characters though. The character, The Dark Urge, has a lot of things that you can't control, and it's interesting how you can respond to each instance. But, I don't want to give out any spoilers so I'll leave it at that. 

I would like to point out how detailed the game is and how easy it is the pick it up and put it down. There are a lot of beautiful scenery moments and the dialogue choices are amazing. In fact, one piece of dialogue could change how things turn out in the end. Choose wisely. Your life could very much depend on it. You can also save at anytime, even when in the middle of dialogue. It makes it easy because you don't feel like you have to finish a battle or figure out how to get somewhere in one go. It's very easy to understand, too, when you look at the different spells and weapons and what they do for each character. It takes a little bit of getting used to but I love how they lay it all out for you in the, I'm gonna call it an action bar, and it's very easy to click and cancel each of the actions if needed. 

In conclusion, this is, overall, a really well-done, thought-out game that takes the hobby of D&D to a whole other level. I hope you guys enjoy it as much as I have. I hope this review helps! Have fun out there!

updated update: Game is too fun to get mad about the bugs and story. go play it, although ideally if anything could change your mind anyway you'd wait for definitive edition

update: I might change my mind slightly soon, but be aware that the technical issues persist and I'm pretty sure it's my RAM 

I typed up my whole-ass review without switching which thumb-button I was on and when I switched the button it deleted my review. Thanks, Steam. What the hell.

Game is buggy as frick. There's too much content and a huge amount of it isn't properly integrated so everything starts spazzing out if you do things in an unintended order. There's also something wrong with it because my PC specs really outstrip the recommended specs but it's still dipping to 30fps all the time. Not sure if it's a CPU or RAM bottleneck because I've got a 10700K and 16GB/3600MHz RAM, but those still both are overspec'd, so I'm thinking it's the fact the game absolutely sucks at cleaning up after itself.

Also the story is mindblowingly mid so far, though I haven't even made it to the eponymous Baldur's Gate yet. Like you have a lot of cool setpieces, but none of it feels like it belongs in the same game - and not in a good way. I couldn't give less of a rat's ass about what's happened in the story so far because I don't care about any of these people or places, and the companions feel like wet toilet paper used for stroking off the player character or something. The depth is incredibly superficial. Origin characters getting their soul sucked out of them if you play them is also fantastic (sarcasm). I know these story complaints are #JustWRPGThings (I hate WRPGs generally speaking), but the genre being what it is doesn't mean you are supposed to pretend a single-player experience can play out like a live D&D campaign and keep the flair.

All these complaints and more, and yet I can't stop freaking playing because the gameplay itself is great and scratches a primordial FE/XCOM itch that those games can't quite reach. It's just... I'm nearly at my breaking point wrestling with the insane FPS stuttering when I move the camera just because I use the controls like an RTS gamer, and when games are jank, I usually press on for the story, which in BG3 is basically just "lol look you can play Curse of Strahd with the tulpas in your head"

Genuinely might be one of the best games I've ever played, in terms of story, content, and just overall feel of the game. This game is so fleshed out it puts other games with massive stories to shame, I tried my hardest to find and do as much as possible on my first play through, missed a bunch of stuff, started a second play through, did a LOT more stuff, and I STILL haven't done everything this game has to offer. There is plenty more to say but I but I really recommend playing the game and figuring things out for yourself like I did.

So, this game is great—lots of choices and consequences and all-around fun. But it's a game where I feel you have to invest a lot of time and energy into understanding the gameplay to have a better experience, or you will go down a frustrating journey. Don't be like me.

Combat rules:

Always examine new types of enemies (right-click and press examine) to see what works and what doesn't. Read everything and press "T" on effects you don't know.
Spellcasters are weak, so use your tanks and physical attackers in the enemy's face.
If you fight on split levels, establish high ground as fast as possible.
Always use your action and bonus actions as often as possible.
When you can pick a feat, pick Tough for everyone. After that, follow this:
Shadowhart: War Caster (Helps her keep concentrating)
Karlach: Savage Attacker
Your Tav (Rogue): Savage Attacker
Wyll: Ability improvement. Put both points into Charisma.
Here were my impressions the entire time I played—minor spoilers ahead:

That part where you have to kill all the goblin leaders took ages. I ended up looking online because I wanted to avoid killing everyone in the place, but I did that anyway. I only had one stealth potion and ended up using all the gold I stole from the goblins to resurrect my companions after legging it away with a bunch of goblins and other creatures, knowing what I just did inside the sanctum. I will admit, it was fun trying to problem-solve how I was going to kill these three leaders without alerting everyone else, lol.

Why is Wyll so weak? Also, Shadowheart, why do you suck with fireballs?

Shadows are cowardly enemies; they'll often attack my character who's just been revived and teleport away or just suck the companion's energy. As soon as I'm done with all the shadows, there's one left, but he keeps hitting my teammate and blending in. Screw those lemons!

The difficulty really starts to ramp up in the shadow-cursed lands. It feels like no matter the level I'm in, enemies will be tougher. Every boss is too high-ranked for me to take on properly.

Gale is starting to annoy me as he keeps eating the good loot I find. I ended up ignoring him.

That session has me knackered—protecting Hansil with the portal while getting overwhelmed. I ended up having to change from a Drow rogue to a wizard for more power. I barely won in the end.

I reached the moonlight tower, and some orc told me to find someone, but this battle was really annoying. That fat-ass demon that keeps his mother in a jar didn't lift a finger to help. The enemies kept spawning and spawning, a mix between Hansil's beast form and a lot of healing from Shadowheart got me through it. I eventually ended up blocking one of the archers so he would target me instead of the rest. It got tedious, wave after wave, until it was 4x4. I felt this fight.

So, I got to the part where we siege the general, but a frontal attack wasn't the greatest idea. After 3-5 attempts, I found out I should have talked to the wolf creatures about turning on the master. But when I took the invisibility potion and did that, the fight began. Oh no, we died. In the end, I started the battle with a two-sided attack from the front and the side. It was great, but eventually, most of the people on my side died.

Auntie Ethel is back, and I killed her again. But it's annoying, as I also had to kill those reviving fungi. Stay dead, Ethel.

I ended up reuniting then betraying Dayme. Due to some real-life things happening, I just wanted to be evil, and it reinvigorated my interest in roleplaying as my character, the opportunistic bastard he is.
