This is definitely an adult game. The character stories and dialogue are well thought out. The main plot is unique. It's fun for D&D lovers, those who love playing through an amazing story, and even those with a tactical mind.

An excellent addition to the series. The DnD elements of this are done in a fantastic way and you can see the WotC involvement with it.

I bought this in very, very early access. I believe I only paid £15 for it - so as value for money, at 170 hours in I have nothing to complain about.

To address the elephant in the room of this being 'woke', it really isn't. The age/sex/race elements of the game are just all open-ended, so you can be any age/sex/race, and have sex with any age/sex/race. It really is as simple as that. It certainly isnt forced down your throat as people are making out. It is a mature game for a mature audience with no hard-set boundaries in that space. That's it.

As for the gameplay, I would describe the story and world open-linear. The main campaign is mostly getting from A to B with some dice rolls in between. Ultimately, you do get to the same place in a round about sort of way. The rest of the quests and stories are totally optional and can be completed or skipped entirely.

The in-game store-keepers have set items which refresh every hard-load of the game, while this makes controlling the items available to the player easier, I feel this should have some element of randomisation to it. Its quite normal for traders to have different items day to day. On the plus side, as their funds refresh, you can rinse money from them selling stolen junk.

The class selection and progression is relatively sane and inline with DnD. There are of course some certain combinations which probably 'over-perform' compared to others, to the point of almost being broken, or in the words of Spiffing Brit, 'as the developers intended'.

The control and movement is your standard point & click outside of battle (I use M+KB, cant comment on controller!), with a pretty standard turn-based interface and dynamic. The turn mechanics take into account the DnD style of turn-based battling in quite a clever way, so I do advise to any newcomers to this format, that you take the time to do the tutorial aspects of the game. There is a lot of options at your disposal later on, and knowing how to properly use the option available to you can make you a truly formidable opponent. As a wizard for example, you can attain sorcery points to use for giving yourself spell-points or casting more powerful offensive spells. There are also items for getting more spell/sorcery points, adding a bonus action to your turn or even action points. Knowing how all of this ties together in combat can make the difference between winning confidently or loosing miserably. A similar thing to note is the dice rolls - if you are new to this type of dynamic, I would take the time to learn what you can do, and what different things mean (advantage, disadvantage, modifiers, penalties). You can stack some things to get extremely high rolls, so that's worth noting.

The lore and story of this has kept me interested and engaged to a very high level - to the point I have read basically every note and book in the game. Some of the books/notes you find tie up to other books/notes so you can loosely follow other stories within the world. I found this to be an interesting point. I wont give anything away about the story, but it does make sense, lots of twists and turns - even late game - where snap decisions must be made. There were part that came to light as I played I certainly wasn't expecting. The Dark Urge story line is particularly interesting.

All in all if this is your type of game, you will enjoy it. The game is still getting updates and improvements, so can only hope this game continues to evolve and improve, and seeing what Larian have done so far, I am confident it will.

Baldur's Gate? More like BALLER GAME!!!

Ok now that THAT horrible comment is out of my head and out of the way, it's honestly refreshing to play a game where your dialogue options and actions in the game ACTUALLY affect how you experience the rest of the game. 

Remember all those times other gaming companies have promised that your "decisions have consequences," and then you come to realize that the only consequence is that one of the npcs now thinks you're a jerk but that's all that changed? 
That is NOT the case for this game! 

Don't like a certain NPC? Kill'em. I don't care. The game does though and you might regret it later. Or not. Who knows? Maybe it was beneficial? You'll find out later! Or not, if that something that *would* have happened required that NPC. Too bad / Good. Because they are dead. You unalived them.

Want your party to be rich and you don't care how it happens? Well with some stealth, some smart thinking, and maybe a little bit of luck, steal all the money from every vendor. Then wait for them to replenish their stock and come back to steal it all again! Then you can buy stuff without worry! Or... why not just steal that too? (Not recommended if you are a Paladin. wouldn't want to break your Oath now, would you? Unless you want to be an Oathbreaker paladin. Then go ahead. Break away!)

The amount of things you can get away with in this game and the number of DIFFERENT ways you can solve issues is probably just being limited by your imagination (or choices you made previously). 

There really isn't any other (video)game out there that is THIS in depth with decision / consequence layouts.

For table-top Dungeons and Dragons players, YOU might have a little less freedom, because you don't have a DM to allow your insane out of the box idea that breaks rules for the sake of "cool" - but there are still PLENTY of fun, cool, hilarious, or serious character building ways to handle the situations in this game. 

SERIOUSLY - I HIGHLY recommend this game. 
in fact, there are no words to properly describe the level of "recommended" I have for this game. 

So in the words of a dead meme - 
"DO IT! JUST DO IT! Don't let your dreams be dreams." - Deity of Motivation, Shai LaBeouf, speaking on whether you should play BG3 or not.

The best CRPG ever made!

And i tried them all!

One word: Revolutionizing

So much so, that other game companies find the need to berate Larian for making a game that is "too good" to set standards towards. I've spent 80 (update, 350) hours in this game and I'm STILL learning new things every day that I play. I get so entranced by the incredible storytelling, the infinite places to explore, the Easter eggs and hidden secrets, the fights, everything about this game has been made in a way to appeal to us as gamers, not as pockets full of money. 

This is the very first CRPG that has ever caught my attention, and has completely made me fall in love with the entire genre at this point. Now, I want to play actual DND just because this game helped me understand it so well, and appreciate it for what it is. 

The only real downside is some of the bugs. Recently (2/20/24) I've come across a bug that causes the game to lockup and eventually crash. In Honor mode you can lose hours of progress (at least, until I realized you can still quicksave just not quickload), but Larian is incredibly good at listening to feedback and fixing these game-breaking bugs as fast as possible. 

Good to see that not all game companies hate it's playerbase now. Best $60 I've ever spent! If you've never tried this game, you're doing yourself a disservice!

My favorite game of 2023 BY FAR. As soon as I finished the game, I immediately started a second playthrough without even closing out of the game. Tons of content - hours of gameplay. Worth every penny.

In an age where many of the well established corporate gaming giants try to convince us that the future of gaming is copy and pasted content with "battlepasses/store fronts" offering garbage-tier "content" for "whole game prices"... This game was certainly a breath of fresh air! Truly outstanding amount of content, quality of the multitude of interwoven storylines with the same attention to detail to the voice acting and musical score... All for a single cost! I have completed two runs so far with ideas for more later on. 

I do not see this games amount of dedication and passion being beaten anytime soon, especially from the majority of the giant corporate deadwood, but I hope more gems, even if only half as good as this, pop up out of the golden age of indie developers! AAA gaming is very stale and dead at the moment, but I have a lot of hope that games like this inspire new blood to rise up and fill the void! Well done, Larian Studios!

I have never played a game like Baldur's Gate 3 ( the closes I can think of is Skyrim ) and I loved every hour of it ( and there were a lot of hours ) The Story telling is amazing and the and keeps you looking for answers for your problem. There are also countless ways you can play, from both a story telling and play style standpoint. You can be a saint or someone who aims to sow nothing but chaos. You play several classes that have their own strengths and weakness'. The combat once you get a handle for it, is a ton of fun. It encourages you to think outside the box in order to defeat your opponents which can result in some entertaining outcomes. There is also just so much to do in this game, it took me 72 hours to beat the game ( I did it in a week and a half, I have no life ) and I still missed out on a ton of the companions and their quest because I was too focused on completing the main quest. Therefore I am on my second play through lol. To avoid this. I recommend exploring the entire map, especially the starting area.

154 hours to beat the game once and I still didn't experience everything. This game has a fine polish and replay-ability that has been sorely lacking in AAA games as of late. I would recommend this game for anyone that enjoys an in-depth story and tactical game play, as well as a game where your choices matter and contains characters that you really get connected to. 
          Additionally, this game has so many different ways to play. I discovered created homemade pipe-bombs by putting barrels of explosives in backpacks and throwing it at bosses. This game really captures the essence of DnD, both through lore and it's freedom of game-play that is only limited by your imagination.

I thoroughly enjoyed this game and am already considering starting another playthrough soon. However, I must mention that Act 3 seemed to lack the polish that the other acts had, and I couldn't help but feel a bit disappointed by the absence of an epilogue. I grew so fond of the characters throughout the game and had hoped for one final gathering with them after the thrilling finale. Here's to hoping that these concerns will be addressed in the definitive edition.

edit: This is the best game ever. I can't stop playing it. I NEED MORE CRPGs like this.

I spent $70 to become a beta tester. The gameplay and story is great, but every patch and hotfix throws up bugs galore and many brick existing saves. I saw an article of how few players actually have gotten to the end. It's because Larian released an incomplete game and they have to restart the whole thing.

Overall Rating 9/10 

This game is amazing but to pretend like its perfect is just not true. It is near perfect and the blend of turn-based vs live makes the game more immersive while maintaining the strategy component. 


- Game story and variation 5/5

===== I just completed my first play through and started my second. I've already encountered a bunch of stuff I missed the first time. This game has TONS of replay value.  The story is  immersive and very much impacted by in-story choices.  I do wish you could chose your alignment and have dialogue more geared toward (good / neutral / evil). 

- Game mechanics and interface 3/5 

===== Interacting from one floor to another lower or higher floor is super annoying and sometimes impossible. 
===== Inventory management is a freaking nightmare.  
===== A smaller issue is when the characters move into a cut-scene for the story. The characters will go into conversation and interact in the story but then they revert to where they were when you walk into the room. This is good for setting up a strategy but, also feels janky because its strange to have the characters go from talking to a npc back to hiding behind a pillar when the cut scene ends.

How the hell did this win so many awards. It's got to be close to the worst game I have ever played. A snail moves faster. The combat is horrific, and it only happens once every hour. I'm on the easiest mode and I can't do anything except die. I get 1 spell to use and then I have to go to camp and sleep. Are you serious!!!

This game is excellent. I love a an evil play through when it comes to D&D; most games do not deliver true "evil" options without ending or breaking the game. BG3 has multiple ways to be thoroughly evil. Yes, the plethora of goody two shoes stuff is still there, and is fun also, but the depth of the writing in this game... I just want a picture of the flow room. You know those diagrams with the strings and tacks you see on homicide dramas? I bet the one for this game looked like spaghetti noodles for 400 people, with some poor dev curled up in a ball under it all, just rocking it away. There's a few bugs here and there, but the company seems intent on squishing them. If you're good at D&D and pissing off your DM with your creative problem solving IRL, you will love the ability to do so in this game given enough time, strength, inventory space, and creativity. I am on my 3rd play through and I've not stopped discovering new things, despite being one of those annoying MFers that has to peek in every. single. corner. I also love the amount of representation in this game. It's beautiful. The more I play it, the more I love it. I resisted for so long because I *knew* I'd be obsessed. And here I am, correct in my obsession. 

I don't use mods or anything, but I hear there's fun ones out there if that's your thing, too. But it doesn't really need them. 

This game deserved GOTY! woo!

This game is absolutely beautiful! I love how different each play-through can be, depending on your in-game choices. There are so many small details to find through investigating NPCs and world objects, making the open world aspect of the game really fun to explore. 

BG3 can run on my Macbook Pro (even if it sounds like a jet engine) without me having to change the default graphics settings and is extremely mod friendly.

My only negative is that I wish the character creation was more detailed. I find it really strange that you can't edit the preset faces, since that seems to be the standard in most games like this. I would have also liked some variation in the races; seeing some non-human build options would have been really cool.
This has become one of my favourite games and I would recommend it to anyone.

Baldur's Gate 3 is a reminder of how great video-games can be. 
Between the quality in animation, storytelling, voice acting and graphics, you get a very good experience ,that is, only if you can play turn by turn games because fights can get very frustrating especially those that lasts a good while and that you have to start again.
Beside that every character breathes with life because choices matter and it's very rewarding to make one get off a dark path or feeling the consequences right in the face because you forgot about something or dealt a situation badly. It makes you wonder how you could have done things differently and that's great because the game can be easily done again and again. 
Though it must be known that later part of the game is kind of lacking in terms of content and the endings can be very disappointing as of now.
Gameplay wise Baldur's Gate 3 gives many classes to play with as well as a many settings to create your own character which enables you to have many lines in conversation especially made for your class/race.

Playing the game just makes you feel all how much love has been poured in its making and it's quite the feeling.

This game is fantastic and highly recommended. One of the very few games that feels full and (mostly, though later patches have fleshed this out) complete on release, with none of the bullshit that seems to be flooding the modern gaming market (MTX, Season Passes, Games as a service, etc.). It's got an engaging story, fun combat and social systems with real depth that allows for a variety of builds and approaches to situations, and an overall attention to detail that makes this game a joy to play.

A stark reminder of what video games used to be. Upon purchase, you get exactly what you paid for and much more with no microtransactions, cut game content resold as DLC, and so forth.
A fond return to a better time where each year wasn't filled with disappointing, broken game releases, developed by souless corporations with no creative drive and only a hunger for money.

If you and/or your friends love D&D then this game will be your GOTY as much as it was for the rest of us. If you are unsure, I'd still give it a shot.

Easy to get lost in the stories, and unlimited stuff to do, worth it in every metric.
edit: One of the best games I have ever played and you can feel the love of the creators all the way until the end. Thanks! :)

Honestly and sadly i hated this game.  Act I was pretty good but the story is downright horrendous from there.  There are a couple of good characters but not really enough to fill your party.   Not that it even matters because every one of them wants to screw  you (the good kind)  after talking to them basically once, so there is no point in even interacting with them unless you are looking for a fancy dating sim with no real character development.  It may sound strange but I wanted to actually play the game and interact with my party members without constantly being hit on sexually.  It doesn't even take any effort.  You literally cannot interact with them without being rude or leading to a romance.  Any by the way, its ALL of them.  You can't even make ONE friend, comrade, buddy, teammate.  Talk to them nicely once and it becomes awkward.  Character romance in itself is fine but do you need to be bombarded with it by every character whether you want it or not?   

All that aside the story tries to be so epic that it is completely ridiculous, childish, and terrible.  There is no adventure to it, no subtly, or nuance.  Even little things like your camp are annoying.  Why the hell is your camp like a 5 star luxury hotel?  You escape a mind flayer ship with nothing but a....fully furnished luxurious portable apartment.  You are supposed to be suffering hardships and overcoming trials not living it up in style like some spring break road trip.  Where is the rugged adventure?  It is beyond stupid and makes the game developers look like spoiled children who get anxiety if their triple venti soy latte isn't made to their standard.   Beyond that there are many many more problems that you will discover on your own after wasting 60 of your hard earned dollars.  

To be somewhat fair there are elements of the gameplay that are very good and I do really like the graphics.  The combat can be annoyingly slow if there are a lot of enemies but it is still fine.  Overall though, a wretched game.  It did not have to be the original Baldur's gate, but it did have to be a good game.  And at that, it was a critical miss!

At ~ 60? hours: So far this game is great, and I will write a more comprehensive review later. The voice acting and the character animations are probably the best out there.
I just thought that I needed to warn everyone of a couple things first. Without spoilers. This game is still buggy, in a frustrating, rage-quit way at times. I have had to backtrack HOURS of tough, grueling gameplay, because the game either a) did not warn me of a "point of no return" and online spoiler-free quest order guides blithely told me to do those things in the wrong order; or b) certain party-npc related story-development cutscenes fail to trigger (again, found this out after more hours of questing, when looking up a hint). I've since read many reddits about bugs and bug fixes, so it WAS worse, but it is still not 100%. There are also a lot of very non-intuitive things regarding some of the strategies which are most effective. I've played a lot of d&d (including 5e since its release about a decade ago), so I know a lot of tricks, hacks, and out-of-the-box tactics that work. That said, I should not have been getting Dark-Souls level stomped on as much as I have been because I didn't do something juuuuust right (there are very weak enemies that can one-shot, no-resurrect, kill your party members for instance...if there is a cliff nearby). 

So, in conclusion: this game is absolutely worth the high price tag, just for what it does well. BUT you need to make a lot of manual saves (it allows you to change the label so you can keep better track, so A+ for that) because almost certainly there will come a point were you did something WRONG (according to the invisible game mechanics) and probably don't want to slog 50 more hours into a game that you: have a broken NPC which no longer will follow the party and just stands in whatever dungeon you left him; somehow glitch-stalled a romance you had been working on for no discernible reason; you can't revive your main character for some reason no matter how many scrolls/spells/or money you throw at it; will die over and over again fighting bosses with tons of allies if your first round isn't perfect.

Edit after 240+ hours, patch 6 downloaded, complete Tav and Durge playthroughs: this is now my desert-island game. I am STILL finding dialogues and character interactions I missed or which changed based on different choices I made my second playthrough. There are still bugs I encounter but I learned enough from my first run how to fix/avoid some of them (seriously, sometimes it's just talking to people in the wrong order that does weird stuff). Patch 6 just went live and fixed a ton of stuff and added some nice extras as well. It seems like Larian's patches repeatedly add content (I guess those poor gamers at release didn't get an epilogue?) not just fixes, so it is well worth a revisit to old saves. I hope they keep adding stuff on the regular. I don't even need "new quests" type DLC, just more time in this world and more time with these ragtag weirdos I've become so enamoured with.

I had the pleasure of playing Baldur's Gate 3, and I must say it's an absolute gem in the gaming world. The visuals are nothing short of amazing, immersing players in a captivating and visually stunning environment. The story writing is fantastic, weaving a narrative that keeps you hooked from start to finish.

What truly sets this game apart is its engagement factor – it's super engaging, drawing players into a rich and dynamic world where every decision matters. The inclusion of love interests adds an emotional depth that makes you genuinely care for the characters, adding a layer of connection that enhances the overall experience.

For Dungeons & Dragons enthusiasts, Baldur's Gate 3 is a dream come true. The attention to detail is remarkable, creating an intricate and authentic D&D experience. From the character customization to the in-depth storytelling, this game truly captures the essence of the tabletop game.

In conclusion, Baldur's Gate 3 is a masterpiece that combines stunning visuals, compelling storytelling, and an immersive D&D experience. It's a must-play for both fans of the genre and newcomers alike.

It was all a ruse. BG3 went from Early Access right into Early Access release - the first act bugs that were plaguing the game years ago haven't been fixed and then added some.

There are redeeming qualities (mainly in dialogue writing and environmental design), but they aren't enough to compensate for what a big great mess this game is. 

It's not a good CRPG (most of the times you still end up fighting the entire camp no matter your choices), the combat is very tedious and takes way too much time, the quest design is extremely janky with you never being able to do what you intended to do (it's like I'm playing a game written by an alien that just don't understand humans).

Play this game in a few years once it gets discounted; it's basically Dragon Age Inquisition and that game was neither worth it full price.

Baldur's Gate 3. What is there to say which hasn't already been said? I rarely play CRPGs more than once to completion. They are typically huge time commitments, and even if it's a good one, I treat it as a one and done. BG3 is the only one I have played from start to finish multiple times. And I am STILL finding new content and there are narrative paths I still haven't taken. Try as I might, I can't seem to squeeze all the fun out of BG3. 

Immersion is a trite word for game reviews, but it really is the best word to describe how BG3 feels. In some ways it reminds me of Red Dead Redemption 2, in that its production values and atmosphere made me want to linger even when I wasn't actively progressing in the game. The game invites you to inhabit and explore its world, not just mindlessly progress from one area to the next. 

Given how much content is in the game, I was shocked--and then disappointed-- when I heard they cut the upper city from ACT 3. (It's no spoiler that you ultimately make it to Baldur's Gate, it's in the title.) I hope Larian adds it back in , even if they repackage the assets as DLC. I was also shocked to hear they weren't planning any DLC or expansions, but it seems like they don't hate money after all and are going to do some. This is good news, since a game this good, with such a well realized engine, should serve as the framework for yet more. 

A few words about the story. IMO the main story is not as compelling as the way the companion character's own quest lines feed into it. The dynamics between the companions is the best part of the story. These are fully realized characters, with their own motivations and purposes, who at  first mostly want nothing to do with each other. They are only brought together because by a stroke of fate they were all cursed with the same problem. It was a stroke of genius for Larian to weave these character's plotlines into the main narrative arc. Too many rpg devs don't take that opportunity. 

Another great touch was how many quest lines evolve from act to act. Choices you made in act 1 will come to fruition in act 3, and it gives the impression that you are leaving a mark and that your actions have consequences. 

That said, I thought the main narrative was a little too gimmicky. It all revolves around the mind flayer tadpoles and a deeper conspiracy, but it still relies on MacGuffins (gimmicky plot devices) too much, and I was never really fully sold on the threat the Absolute represents. It kind of felt like a marvel movie plot, flashy but short on substance. Still, all the pieces are there for motivating you to advance the plot with a feeling of tension and urgency. As a framing device for all the companion characters extremely well done quest lines, it does the job.

I do hope BG3 gets some old school meaty expansions. It deserves it, and Larian is the studio that can do it. As huge as this game is, the world of DnD is much vaster. Even with all its content, BG3 only scratches the surface.

This game amalgamates all the elements we cherish in video games. It harmonizes player agency, exploration, and creativity with an engaging story, rich characters, and meticulous world-building. It's fully voice-acted, and it's the only game I've seen spark debates over its claimed 17,000 different endings. Whether these are defined as 'slight variations' or 'subtle permutations' by critics, or seen as unique endings, the mere fact that we're discussing the number 17,000 is staggering and unprecedented. Larian immerses its players in a world so profound and rich that, even 1,000 hours and numerous playthroughs later, you're likely to still be uncovering new secrets. While the game is linear in its progression through three distinct acts, unlocking large swathes of the map, this description masks the truly non-linear, player-driven journey you will embark upon. The creation of Baldur's Gate 3 might seem an impossible feat, yet here we are, thanks to the team at Larian. 

And... You can pet the good boy. You can even play fetch! 

Or... You can kill him.

The game is truly up to you.

Found the fix for CPU Heat issue at least:

So 3 main things I changed and now the game runs at 30 degrees instead of 80, performance is exactly the same.

1. Set the Windows 10/11 Power Mode to "Better Performance" (option in the system tray)
2. Turn off "game mode" in Windows Settings
3. Go to your power plan in control panel (powercfg.cpl) and set your maximum cpu to 99%

I started this game with the highest expectations. I liked the predecessors a lot. A game with a genre I like, hyped by fans and critics alike. What could go wrong?

Actually and sadly a lot... and I am still confused and astonished how gravely my opinion went downhill.
30 hours in, having almost finished the first act, I stopped playing the game out of boredom and even annoyance over some aspects. Here are some:

[h3]Gameplay[/h3]
Its ok... When you play a D&D-game you expect some level of randomness due the game system being solely based on die roles, but this is ridiculous. I had one encounter where enemies appeared unexpectedly. Before I was even able to perform my first move, three party members were dead, one had 2 hit points bleeding and burning in the middle of an AOE spell. Reload... The same fight: not taken a single relevant hit. And this continues on and on. Each fight is basically the constant decision process when to reload or keep gambling.

[h3]The presentation[/h3]
The graphics are ok. Spell effects, animations and sound design are quite good. I get it why the main Character is not talking. This would have caused the need for multiple recorded versions of the main character for multiplayer, but man... what a hell of an immersion killer this is! Having the own character just staring emotionless into nothingness during important "conversations" is not thrilling at all.

[h3]The Story[/h3]
I am not in the position to rate this after having only finished the first act. Until now it’s a pretty standard okayish fantasy plot. It is not enough to keep me playing considering all the other downsides.

[h3]The environment[/h3]
Unplausible. Obviously driven by the design goal to have a lot of "hidden" areas. Looks nice but is composed out of a lot of empty space with far too much empty containers. (Containers with worthless 1-goldpiece-crap are technically empty)

[h3]The option to solve the quests in many ways[/h3]
In the main enemy camp of act 1 I found a hidden passage that retrospectively was a major shortcut to the end of the act 1 main quest. This results in the only option to basically wipe the whole area without further story interaction afterwards. I love games that trick you into bad decisions with catastrophic outcome, but this felt like accidentally picking the wrong story-breaking meta choice without even knowing the options. Killing everything is not exactly my understanding of multiple interesting story paths.

[h3]The party members[/h3]
This is my overwhelming pain point. You assemble a group of the most annoying and unrelatable characters I have ever encountered in such game. Instead of being interested in their (over-the-top-ridiculous) backstories I was hoping for them to just stop talking. This is even made worse by an absurdly exaggerated voice over-acting. I do not even dare to compare this to beloved characters in - let’s say - the Mass Effect series or alike. After 30 hours I did not connect with a single one of them. I give Karlach the credit for being the least annoying though. At least she is funny, but this is only based on her being one of many fantasy clichés: the stupid, blunt barbarian.
And then the romancing... I mean this is kind of childish in all RPGs, right? But this part of BG3 is downright silly. Throughout the whole first act there is no hint of romantic interest by any of the other party members and then the celebration at the end of act 1 suddenly turns into an NPC-all-you-can-plow-buffet. The interaction options could have been a drop-down menu: Who do you want to hop in bed with?

[h3]Synopsis[/h3]
Overhyped, tedious, average RPG.

A fun game with a wealth of content to dig into. I do not believe it is all it is hyped up to be, and was not my choice for 2023 GOTY. 

I did enjoy the level of player choice available and a few of the characters you meet are memorable, but most are boring. Many characters and writing in this game is very "modern" and does not fit the dark and gritty setting I prefer within the fantasy genre. ie (Witcher, GOT, LOTR). Characters are all young, pretty, and dress in bright neon colors or armor that looks like its made of pure silver/spun gold, rather than iron plate.
The side quests are good and worth doing with a few stand outs. But they do not come close to the side quests offered in Witcher 3 or Fallout 3 and New Vegas. 

The main questline is good but really loses steam in act 3. Due to the length of the game and how strong the first and second acts are I think people either haven't played the third act or gloss over its short comings.
Overall I had fun playing this game, and I took my time doing it. (100 hours in a single playthrough) I would recommend it to any fan of RPG's or the fantasy genre.

---SECOND PLAYTHROUGH REVIEW---
[h3]Baldur's Gate 3 is great. Simple as that.[/h3]
Second playthrough, playing completely differently and with mods this time. The game is unique and beautiful every time you play it. There are still bugs and issues, but the developers are crushing through them with every major and minor update they release. This game is easily within my top 10 games I have ever played, and I suspect it will stay there during my entire lifetime.


---ORIGINAL REVIEW BELOW---
[h3]When Baldur's Gate 3 is good, it's so good. When Baldur's Gate is bad, it's frustrating and disappointing.[/h3]

Baldur's Gate 3 is [b]NOT[/b] a tabletop role playing game [TTRPG]. I, [i]stupidly[/i], thought that this game would allow me to pretty much do anything and everything that I wanted, like a TTRPG. It doesn't let you do that. The game has limits, and honestly that is a good thing [i]at times[/i]. There were plenty of times that I just wasn't allowed to do something that I thought I was able to do. Or the opposite, I would get punished for walking too close to something without any indicators telling me otherwise. The vanilla game feels and plays like it's modded and has some janky bugs in it. Maybe I should just play with mods...

I have never finished my own run. I am simply a side-character. A side-character who's being limited to interacting with Astarion at the camp...

Seriously, though, the graphics are amazing; the voice acting, top-notch; the storyline, captivating. I have never played a game where I'm so happy acting like a NPC and tagging along the whims of the main character.

Unfortunately, Larian Studios is not able to serve several platforms at the same time, despite their announcements. So far, all patches and hotfixes have been released at different times for the individual platforms. The time differences are usually several weeks.

It is therefore simply impossible to play together across several platforms. Once the update is available for all platforms, the next update is released just two weeks later and you have to sit out for several weeks again.

Unfortunately, Steam also does not allow you to suspend or postpone an update so that you are forced to play the latest update. The "unnecessary" launcher between Steam and BG also has no option to skip an update. So it's simply for marketing purposes.

Glad Larian is now in the mainstreams eye.

Easily the most overrated game in the history of video games, this game won GOTY while barely even managing to run. In six and a half months, tons of hotfixes and patches, many of the former had to be pushed out to solve problems introduced by the latter. One hotfix wouldn't even launch on the Steamdeck - one of three platforms available at the time - so Larian does zero software testing.

The characters are two-dimensional stereotypes, and Astarion, far from being the LGBTQ hero he's made out in the press - is a bad trope from 1970s that younger queer folk have been using to point out how self-loathing previous generations of gay people are.

This game is crap fest of bad story-telling, bad design, bad corporate management, and horrible writing. But hey, there are dicks in it, and sex, so GOTY!

This is why I never take game awards seriously. Beautiful art? Sure. But I can go to a museum for that. This was sold as a piece of software. As such, it's a miserable failure and anyone who falls for the hype deserves what they get. 

I'm fully expecting next year's GOTY to be an empty box with a card that reads, "Ha ha, suckers!" inside.

Save your money. Hasbro and Larian aren't worth the hassle or the expenditure, and I've seen better D&D campaigns written by pre-teen lemurs with cognitive problems.

I have respect for this game, the huge updates and whatnot. BUT
This game is just impossible and by far the most overwhelmingly complicated game I've ever played.
It's just too much. I really want to like this, but I just don't.
The combat is luck based, whereas I have always preferred skill based. "Almost" Every encounter I had with enemies, I had a complete team wipe, because all my characters miss all the time and when they do hit, they only do 2 - 4 damage, whereas every enemy is hitting me for 10 - 11 damage each time.
I find it just unfairly difficulty and it just isn't a fun time.
When you level up, you get the choice of around 15 or so different things to pick from, each of which isn't easy to understand what you're picking or useful in combat at all, since I can never seem to use them anyway.
Inventory system is extremely complicated as every items seems to be very cryptic in what it does. Some make more sense than others.
As I said at the start, I respect the game, but it just isn't for me. It's too complicated

[h1] If you don't like overcomplicated RPGs like Wasteland 3, Original Sins, Pahtfinder, etc... Think twice before buying Baldur's Gate 3[/h1]

Baldur's Gate 3 is a very, very complicated game to play. The learning curve is steep and uninteresting because of dozens and dozens of, and let's be honest about CRPGs here, useless systems and sub systems which could have been hidden to the player like in most others modern rpgs, without harming game and metagame richness.
Everything in the game is unnecessarily complicated so if you don't want to waste hours learning how works spells attributes, sub attributes, sub-sub attributes, characters attributes, sub attributes, sub-sub attributes, dice systems, sub systems, etc... maybe think twice before buying it.

[h1]Moving in the game with K&M is a chore.[/h1]

The worst thing about the game though, is how poorly the mouse & keyboard combo is managed. Thanks to outdated point&click movements which are unsuitable for moving through very complex environments like the ones in BG3. The game is slow, clunky and adds to player fatigue generated by already overcomplicated mechanics and the general slowness of the game. 

Players with controler are more lucky and will be able to move their character more naturally, almost like a modern third person RPG. But even them will eventually get bored by several radial menus in which they're forced to navigate through, only to make one action. That's the reason why I can't play with a controler either.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

I don't want to waste more of my time on BG3, because personally, the issues aformentionned are a deal breaker. So I'll wrap it up by saying that video games should not exhaust players with unnecessarily complicated systems management or outdated point&click controls and for these reasons, I don't recommend Baldur's Gate 3 for players who don't like CRPGs, even if they're fans of modern RPGs, like I am.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Having spent more than 600+ hours in the game, I hope my review will help someone in some way.
This is the best rpg game. Act 1 and Act 2 are amazing and fabulous, but let's put it in order.  

The first and second acts are written logically, there are a lot of dialogues, conversations, companions communicate all the time and there is no sense of plot drawdown, as it is in the third act. 

I really like this game for its romances, it's amazing that there is such a game in the world in principle! Thanks for that, it was missing! But one romantic scene in each act is not enough for me. The game is big, I have to wait some romantic scenes for a very long time and they are very short. I would like more romantic dialogues. After all, 1% of romance in the game is very little. 

New kisses appeared, but I also want hugs and animations of lying next to a romantic partner while sleeping in the camp. 

Next, I'll be more specific and that includes [u]spoilers[/u]:
All the companies, and there are more than 4 of them, I romanced Astarion and was mostly on the good side, only once making assholes: he ascended, and I captured the Absolute. To be honest, there is much less content on the good side. While the ascended Astarion has an additional great dialogue after Casador, where he praises me, three kinds of kisses, four very beautiful answers to the question "who are we to you?" then the non-ascended Astaron has only one vague answer to this question, one new kiss and one old one. that's all. 
If I'm on the good side, then I want more romance, especially from the spawn Astarion. I want to listen to sincere declarations of love, perhaps a special additional dialogue about it. I mean, we all know that the ascended Astarion calls us [spoiler]"consort"[/spoiler], so why not make a really romantic transformation of spawn Astarion then in revenge for the ascended? 
Also, when I was dark urge and defeated it in special scene in [spoiler]Bhaal Temple[/spoiler], I was dissapointed by spawn Astarion answer to me. It was so strage short response after what we've been through together.. Especially in romance. I expected more, frankly speaking.

Act 3 feels very raw and boring if you take out all the side quests and climb into every basement. The companions in the third act seem more detached and do not comment much, especially among themselves, as in the first act. The plot slack is felt. Companions stop commenting on such trivial things as [spoiler]the bombing of the Steel Watch Foundry[/spoiler] or the defeating [spoiler]Orin[/spoiler]. There are less camp scenes than in act1 and it's boring. Because in act3 we obviously need sleep more than in act1. 
 

But in general, the game is the best and deserves all its awards! Thank you for being there! I hope one of the creators will read this and listen to my humble requests. 

With love, Kitty ^_^

[h1] You should buy this game even if you have no intention of playing it. [/h1]

Why? Lets do some philosophy. By buying this game you will support the devs, and the devs care about creating high quality products. Also, Larian does NOT (and likely NEVER will) incorporate loot boxes or other such anti-consumer nonsense into their games. Therefore, by buying this game you will contribute in helping the industry recover what it once was: a bunch of nerds creating games they were passionate about. 

Your purchase will be a small, but not insignificant, step toward wresting control of the industry from the greedy technocrats that currently control it. Such people do not even know how to set-up their smartphones yet they are the ones making all the decisions. You only need to review the backlash this game received from the big studios following release as proof of how it made them squirm.

Larian set a new bar. Right now they are the only studio across the entire planet that can make a compelling RPG, but all good businesses have their copycats. I say let them. The more studios like Larian the better. However, this game needs to make as much money as possible, the greedy technocrats need to see proof that there is significant enough demand for excellent games, therefore you must buy it. 

If my philosophy holds true then one day a developer that makes games more to your liking, if for some reason you don't like BG3, will do so to an incredibly high standard. First it is up to you to demonstrate that you are happy to spend your hard-earned cash so long as the product is good and doesn't waste your time.

Support excellent studios and buy this game. No more CS weapon skin marketplaces, no more loot boxes that are designed to prey on addictive personalities and no more fucking horse armour!

This game is the most significant western RPG released since The Witcher 3, and Skyrim before that. It is also the first true spiritual successor to Dragon Age: Origins that feels like it actually expands on the feeling that game gave at release. 

You will be playing BG3-inspired games for a decade after this (see: TW3 inspiring "question mark open worlds" all over the place).

Snappy, deep combat system that gets more rewarding the more you learn about it. Great story with very high stakes that hits all the beats you want. Grand adventure through a large variety of locales that never wear out their welcome. Every party member is compelling and complex in their motivations. Excellent soundtrack. Your choices matter, and can drastically alter your experience. Difficulty levels reward game knowledge in a very satisfying way. Very high production value among others in its genre. Immense replayability.

If you haven't bought it, and you like RPGs or you're looking for an introduction to cRPGs, [b]buy it[/b]. The only bad thing I have to say about it is that there isn't more. I would pay full price again for a definitive edition that polishes Act 3 and increases companion reactivity in the second half of the game.

This is my first true D&D style game, and it is probably not for people looking for a simple, casual experience.

I would have never expected such a masterclass of a game to emerge into my sights when I first laid eyes on it a year ago, I never knew about the game even in its beta and alpha stages, but when the full release came out and a friend asked me to buy this game to play it with him I had my doubts like any human being would with purchasing a $60 game, but after hearing this is one of the truest and accessible adaptations of the Dungeons and Dragons format of play, in a no hassle online game with proper world immersion I bit the bullet to decide to try the game with my friend.

Good god did this game catch me off guard with its splendor instantly.

Games that advertise a roleplaying factor to some degree like diablo, divinity original sin, and skyrim all have cemented a status worth praising. But I never felt a strong enough connection to my character in these games since all story points and cutscenes were so out of my control, my character felt plainly to put it, just a controllable character. Most scenes would be left up to your imagination as it is told and described through a text box, which makes sense in a proper DND setting since the DM would be doing this in real-time to you, but I never felt apart of these worlds since I felt held back with a leash on how much I can explore or interact with the environment. This game finally broke that line between static cut scenes and linear gameplay. I could not be more blown away by the beauty of the game that I was apart of with my carefully custom created character, FINALLY a game acknowledges the absence of true cutscene interaction and proper engagement within its own game. Gone are the days where if you played with friends they were soloed out of all cutscenes or you are not apart of any at all to begin with. Everyone is apart of the action and everyone should be included within the story that you all want to tell, I HATE IT when games just exclude people for the sake of their stupid a## pre-rendered cutscenes, this game only uses one pre-rendered cutscene but its before anything is established for your character so it makes sense to use one there, instead of in the middle of the game where all of a sudden you are just deleted from existence, unable to act because the game needs to force this character introduction down your throat its so awful. 

Combat in this game is immensely satisfying and made beautifully, the amount of customization and options you have to work with on any character is astounding. I think the dice roll system is perfectly fine as is, it may have its moments where it could be annoying but I think this adds its own layer of suspense and risk to any combat encounter, A strong foundation of proper positioning and tactics make this fun to play alone or with friends. Winning an encounter because of wits alone is an unmatched feeling, instead of brute forcing the victory like most games task you to do, brute forcing a win, is not fun! That is not good game design that's just an object with a health bar, its not innovative, and its not engaging. 
The leveling of this game is great, always keeps with the pace of the game and rarely will there be times where you will have to forcibly get out of your way to get another level for a boss fight unless you are genuinely biting off more than you can chew.

Character customization by far one of my favorite aspects of this game, I have made numerous characters just for the sake of it. Also with all of the diverse races and vairants you can choose from really hooked me into the lore of all that is DND, like where did the drows originate from? What are tieflings? And why are dwarves so... tiny..? I think in any playthrough, everyone should really take the time to make a character that they would want to be proud of, I just advise against making "yourself" in a videogame, thats not original, think of something fresh! For your first playthrough any choices you make should be what you want to do, but any after that I highly recommend actually rping as your character, and doing what they would do, it really adds a layer of depth into the game you should try it!

My only complaint with this game is that some classes feel a bit underpowered at levels 1 - 5 and it really shows with the amount of options you are given for that class. Ranger I almost never choose starting since from a roleplaying standpoint, and a combat standpoint fighter or even bard is just a way better option for any "ranged" combat until you reach like level 6, but even then having to wait until you are a certain level to enjoy a class sucks a little bit, it all evens out though.

Well I could go into more detail but I am running out of text to type, overall, 11/10 game, New favorite game ever of all time, and anyone with a console or a pc should buy this game and enjoy it from beginning to end, by yourself, with a friend, or an entire adventuring party, the choice really is yours..!

I'm generally not a fan of this genre of games, but eventually gave in to curiosity based on the thunderous praise the internet was singing of it, and I have not regretted it. Exceptionally fun game with probably the best replay value I've seen in years. If you're a fan of the CRPG genre at all this feels like a must have.

'Man', you say, 'a D&D campaign in video game form would be super cool, but probably not something people could practically achieve AND have it be good at the same time. Oh well'. 
Trust me when I tell you - Baldur's Gate 3 is that game. It embodies the key elements of a good D&D game the best it can in the video game medium. It's flexible and rolls with the way you want to solve problems. It's stuffed to the brim with well-written, charming characters and plenty of secrets. It's both loads of goofy fun and amazing at creating a heavy tone when it needs to. I have always been skeptical about paying 60 dollars for a game, but I earnestly do not regret buying Baldur's Gate 3 at full price. I think it wholly deserved it's GOTY title.

Whether it was as Gorion's Ward, The Nameless One, the Hero of Ferelden, or even Harrier Du Bois, I've always appreciated a deep, immersive RPG. I feel so at home pointing and clicking through fantastical worlds, reading entire novels worth of exposition, and making difficult decisions that shape who I am and what my journey will be. Baldur's Gate 3 goes far beyond being a return to form of RPGs from ages past; instead this game carves out its own spot in gaming history as one of the all-time greatest. If you've had a Bioware-shaped hole in your heart for a good while now, like I have, do yourself a favor and play this game.

This game is epic. I've played WoW online and I've played D&D tabletop, but I'd never played a D&D game online until this. Having a blast! I'm playing alone and in a multiplayer scenario - enjoying multi the most but both are fun. The D&D logistics are teaching me new things about tabletop playing. The many storylines and character arcs are awesome - evidenced by how many people have Youtubed various character scenes and sequences. As someone who doesn't do a ton of PC gaming (more Switch, tablet stuff) I will say that the camera and character movements gave me a lot of frustration early on but I quickly built the muscle memory to the point where I no longer have any issues. And I absolutely love how much control I have over visual angles during game play so it's worth the work to learn. I recently (and with some hesitation) tried streaming the game from my gaming desktop to my more portable laptop and I actually feel like laptop play (keyboard plus trackpad) is a bit easier for me than desktop play (keyboard plus mouse)... but the smaller screen is definitely a hinderance. This is one to play on the big screen, folks.

PSA: As a mom gamer, gonna say that I'm super cautious about playing this anytime or anywhere that my kids (6&9) might walk in. Lots of blood, scary stuff, and of course sexy escapades so.... I only get to play late at night or when the kids are completely out of the house. Sad face. Bottom line: not at all a game for little kids.

It's a great game with an even greater storyline. So why the negative review?

The game has major bugs and issues. It's 2024, 3 years after this game's early access, 4 months after it came out. I bought this gem a week ago and already ran into multiple issues:
- Game thinking it's the first startup, losing all settings made, for no apparent reason. Happened multiple times already, many players seem to have the same issue according to discussion boards.
- Losing all progress. Can be solved after searching through the internet and copying saved games. Yet many people don't have the technical knowledge to fix losing their progress themselves. Apparently I was even lucky, as many people reported being unable to restore their progress... 100+ hours of save games lost, forever, according to online discussion boards. Such a major bug should not exist in a AAA-Game three years after early access. According to some sources this problem is known even since older games Larian created. Not good.
- Broken questlines [spoiler]Can't talk to Mol after the Investigate the Beach quest as I already had contact with her previously[/spoiler].
- Updates need free space the size of the whole game, which now amounts to 150GB. From a developer perspective I don't even want to ask why, but it seems they took the title BG to their heart. An game eating up lots of space for no valid reason, but make it twice as much for a tiny update.
- Broken story continuity. A whole game made with player choice in mind doens't adhere to it in storytelling. There are lots of characters talking about things that don't reflect the current in-game reality any more - not tiny things one could overlook, but major things like talking about an influental person in game being a threat... although they're already dead and they know it.

As a software developer myself I can't think of any reason why Larian did not put any effort in these fundamentals. Fixing major issues is not only basic respect paid towards players who bought that game - it is a measurement of the quality a company is able to deliver. Larian, you can do better. It's a "Game of the Year" where players lose hundreds of hours they put into the game, and no fix in sight. Any other software being sold for 60 Euros with such issues would have the worst reviews. But games aren't software, they are considered art. Your art is great. Please let the coding effort and mechanics live up to your art.

Minor issues I have:
- Certain controls and the user interface could be better. Level-up options should not be pre-selected to prevent mistakes made by newer players. Movement and aiming sometimes behave erratically, being able to hit enemies although the game deems it impossible, and other times pathfinding leads one to a really bad position. It's already on a high level, so this is complaining about the finer details and not a major issue.
- They probably wanted to create a dating sim, according to the comments from other characters if you don't want to bed anyone of the main narcissist characters. Was it an all-male crew? "Hey, it's your story, but if you don't want to see the neat graphics of 2 characters gettin' it on, we try to mildly harass you with commentary." - get that into your head: Just because somebody gets into a life or death situation with other adventurers doesn't mean they'll develop any romantic feelings for them.
- Maybe a few other things I am unaware of or have already forgotten. I can't guess and haven't checked if connection losses in multiplayer sessions or bluescreens are due to a problem on my end, or due to software issues which may be related to certain hardware used, or are a general issue. That is out of my knowledge, and I won't dig deeper here.

Verdict: Great game, but also BG. I'll continue to play it. A game worth buying, but with some major issues which simply don't allow providing a good review.

A solid "B" aka 4-out-of-5 stars. 

Is it worth getting, especially if you've never played a DnD simulator before? Yes and no. 

Yes, if you love role-playing mechanics and freeform problem-solving. The extraordinary amount of flexibility is staggering, and that means the risk of losing hundreds of hours of your life as you try different ways to tackle the same situation.

No, if you prefer a more organic, immersive experience. This game is overtly scripted (and sometimes manipulative) to get you to the next plot point. It's about accomplishing the next task, not to just wander and enjoy the atmosphere.

PROS:
- Some of the best vocal talent in recent memory
- Characters are charming and complex
- Extraordinary flexibility in regards to customization, combat and problem-solving - excellent replay value
- Diverse library of spells, creatures, equipment
- Wide variety of themes, locations, characters, moods
- Karlach is an absolute cutie-pie.

CONS:
- Even with a decent computer/laptop, you must customize to avoid frame-rate / glitch issues
- Camera controls are frustrating and clunky
- Inventory management can be overwhelming (and uses up half your time)
- Interface is complex and can work against you if you're not careful
- Cutscenes are choppy and buggy

PERSONAL OPINIONS:
- The music is overall uninspiring and repetitive
- This game is obsessed with tieflings, halflings, devils, and cats for reasons unknown
- The story can be pretty silly, convoluted, and with a big dollop of manufactured melodrama
- Art design is not unique. Looks a lot like other games in the genre
- Relationship mechanic was distracting and artificial. Honestly - is everyone bisexual?

Summary: Good characters. Overly tactical with clumsy controls. Story becomes unbearably bad.

Pros: Extremely immersive world. Great graphics. Excellent voice acting (and *tons* of audio dialog) and facial animations. Interesting story. Valuable story and strategy clues in various readings and dialog. In the first half, there are many ways to develop story and relationships. Ease-of-use features (e.g., magic pockets, send to camp). Easy access to camp whenever needed. Turn-based combat makes constant pausing unnecessary. Tons of quicksave slots. Objects that come between camera and characters fade to transparent.

Cons: No display of character skill totals, so that you don't know which character has the best stealth skill, etc. Game can't be paused (turn-based mode pauses only the world inside the battle). Camera can't look up. Camera controls are clumsy at best, with only 2D commands in a 3D world. Can't select characters by clicking on them. No combat AI for PC/NPCs, so battles require micromanagement. Combat animations take too long. Horrible pathing often requires micromanaging party movement (e.g., characters will walk through lava rather than around it; characters will walk into traps you've already discovered and warned them about). The highlight objects function only highlights *some* interactables (e.g., containers and most things you can pick up are *not* highlighted). Object interaction can be a hassle (e.g., reading a book before picking it up takes two distinct action cycles, each requiring you to select the object and choose an action). Can't click on a spot on the map in order to have your party walk to it. Initiative is badly broken: Attack a sleeping monster and it may still get initiative. Sneak up and attack a monster, and it may still get initiative. Startle unarmed naked monsters having sex, and they may get dressed, arm themselves, and attack before you can do anything. The story is also inconsistent at various points: The *wrong* character can successfully complete actions *required* of another character, and that other character gets the credit. Completed quests are not reflected in later dialog. NPC banter doesn't evolve, even when it contradicts the story. Oh, and make sure you're somewhere safe when you save, because bad things can happen to the party while the game is loading. Finally, the story falls apart eventually, with no enjoyable path forward.

Stuff I don't like but you might: No alignment system. No traditional multiclassing (as per BG1 & BG2). All classes have rogue skills (everyone can pick locks, disable traps, etc.). All joinable characters will invite you to pursue a romantic relationship, regardless of sex or species. Some dialog options require INT, WIS or CHA saving throws specifically on the PC (e.g., NPCs can't initiate dialog in the PC's dreams), so some classes will always have fewer interesting conversations. Some people probably like the story. I've personally never cared for the parts of D&D that have nothing to do with medieval lore. 

Final thought: Yes, it's buggy. But it's new, so we can forgive that. Micromanagement, tactics-driven battles, and poor controls are annoying but not game-breaking most of the time. The story starts of well but becomes horrible, in my opinion. I have not finished the game because of this.

Clearly this game was made with love of the genre/series.  There are so many instances where you wonder how did the developers have the time or the thought process to include this little tidbit in the game.  It deserves all of it's praise as a whole and probably deserve the overall 10/10 rating that it often got. 

With that said, it doesn't mean it is truly perfect or for everyone.  Obviously if you are for fast pace action type games, this is not for you.  But even among its genre, the studio's own predecessor (DOS2), I think DOS2 has the better gameplay, ie. the fights.  It's overall rule set, and depth and breadth of it's combat is superior and that is because it was created by Larian and not beholden to Dungeon and Dragon's rule set.  Also, they have different pacing; BG3 starts with a bang and slowly whimpers towards the end; though there are key moments throughout each act.  DOS2 starts slowly and crests as the acts go on.  Where I think BG3 still gets the overall nod is the presentation is phenomenal, the voice acting is probably the best ever... in any genre.  The freedom to do what you want, and Larian having thought of it and allows you to do it, is probably the best ever, again in any genre.  And then lastly, the characters in BG3 are far better than DOS2.  Every last one of the origin characters are great.  

Overall a Spectacular game!

Waited nearly twenty years for the continuation of this series.  From EA to the live version (being lovingly and obsessively updated and crammed with as many hours of game play possible) Larian has done it.  Not only making a wonderful game but doing so at a one time cost without fleecing their fans.  Not an anomaly with Larian Studios either.

A full spectrum of gaming style is met on BG3. From number crunching to overcome the most difficult possible custom settings or Honor Mode to casually strolling through enjoying the story on easy mode. With regard for difficulty there is a thousand hours minimum over multiple games played through different story elements and outcomes for both the lifelong hardened DnD veterans and also the clueless first timers.  Larian brilliantly embroidered modern gaming and DnD concepts into the old, vibrant, soulful land of Faerun to create this masterpiece.  Much like BG1 and BG2 before it, BG3 exists as a partition of life.  A universe so rich and full of countless opportunities.  Whimsical enough to follow your every fancy.  As safe or dangerous as you'd like.  Create anything you want, tell any story you wish.  Log in to this game and forget about the ebb and flow of normal life.  Only near perfect MoCap, soundtracks, and voice acting can make something so beautiful.

Larian has set an unrealistic bar for the game development community.  The only problem you may have with this game is constantly having to update it because at no additional  $$ cost to YOU.  Larian Studios respects their following and the gaming community in general.  Regardless of how you may feel about these kind of Dragon/Magic/Fantasy video games;  Know that as a gamer, and a consumer, THIS is the kind of content you deserve from your studio overlords.  No fleecing.  No shop.  No subscription.  Just a great game.  Love, dedication, and respect for the craft.  

Worth every penny.

COULD have been the best game I've ever played.

My story:

Tiamat Knowledge Cleric (2)/Dragon Sorc.

I read and heard a lot about how an evil campaign kind of sucked, but for my playthrough it was fine due to being politically savvy rather than murder hobo/pick bad option because it says it's bad.

*The entire story is basically a Tiamat campaign, even though there doesn't seem to be any Tiamat NPCs to interact with. I would have liked more and mostly used outside knowledge to guide me, which explains why people think there's not many Tiamat choices. You can get an extremely good ending for Tiamat though.

Why isn't it the best game?
* With the Upper City political section cut from the game, it felt like a lot of interactions lead nowhere, rather than leading to some sort of big coming together and outing Gortash in Act 4 (which obviously can't happen). Probably some sort of court case or coming together of the council (it's obvious to see how they changed this, for the worse).

I expected any sort of Tiamat NPC in the Upper City.

Aylin and some other camp NPCs and world NPCs just start to feel broken and repetitive in Act 3, it felt as if their stories had been cut, and must have had something to do with Act 4 being changed.

In all the removal of that section felt like there was a massive hole in the story, and that a lot of actions and choices didn't matter. E.g. I was being manipulative and helping people with the intent to betray them eventually, but the opportunity to do so was removed- I did get to do this for some characters though. Sorry Lae'Zel. :')

As that was the entire point of my character, a more political section of the game being removed directly lowered the quality of the story.

Act 3 problems:
There's some really fleshed out sections when you first arrive, but some really unfleshed out sections. The circus felt like it could have had more to it. 

The inside of the big factory felt shallow and bugged out for me really badly.

The changes they made to force boss fights in act 3 really made those fights weak, and one of the fights I expected to be really good was one of the worst in the game.

It almost feels like you stumble into the end of the game by accident? At the time I didn't know the Upper City had been cut, and everything felt like it was leading there for Act 4, so I expected a Thorm style escape section, but it was actually just the end of the game, and I missed out on finishing some quests because of it. After that I read about it being cut and the Chosen of Bane/stumbling into the end of the game made sense.

I really hope they add Act 4 back.

A lot of bugged quests or forced ways of interacting with the quest:
- More ways to knock out Minthara has been addressed, but I had to reload before Act 2 to ensure I did it right. Really time consuming
- The haunted mansion questline was all over the place for me, and I felt like an NPC was hostile for seemingly no reason (I explored the sewers and other places with minions before heading to the main part)

Other problems:
- Item management - I used the bag of bags mod, which made character item management better, but you still have to manually do it for the camp and it takes way too long
- You're not sure if items will ever be useful so you end up with lots of junk in the camp chest, including ingots and books
- Need an auto read books for new games
- One of the NPCs with an over the top accent connected to the Chosen of Bhaal's voice was so ridiculous it completely killed the moment for me. It's so bad that his voice even breaks while speaking and nothing has been done to edit it.... (I'M NOT SURE IF THAT'S THE CHARACTERS VOICE FROM BEFORE I HAVE ONLY EXPERIENCED BG3)

Conclusion:
It really is one of my favourite games, but the cut sections give it a bitter aftertaste.

I was 15 when Baldur's Gate 2 launched. It was my initiation to PC RPG, and my first immersion into the Forgotten Realms. I keep playing that game, from time to time : graphics can get updated, but good storytelling is forever. This game is forever, too. 

I usually don't write reviews, and this is the first one I post here. I really wish to recommend this game, while thanking and congratulating Larian for what they accomplished. The gameplay, the writing, the acting : everything has such a level of detail, so much singularity and the clear sign that it has been created by people who loved to play the original game, love their work and love to satisfy their community, while aiming for perfection.

To Baldur's Gate, and to the hope of more adventures to come!

Verily, noble sirs and gentle ladies, attend closely as I weave a tapestry of words most intricate, a review befitting the grandeur of the epic quest known as “Baldur’s Gate 3.”

Of Baldur’s Gate 3, I sing—a digital realm wherein pixels dance and polygons cavort, a veritable phantasmagoria of swords, sorcery, and serendipity. Yon game, wrought by the skilled hands of Larian Studios, doth transport us to the Forgotten Realms, a land where dragons soar, and adventurers tread with hearts both valiant and quivering.

In this hallowed expanse, characters emerge—fully realized, their voices resonant as if whispered by the very gods themselves. Behold, the protagonist, a cipher for our own desires, embarking upon a journey fraught with peril and possibility.

And lo, the choices! Aye, they abound like leaves in autumn, each decision a fork in the road—a crossroads where destiny dallies with caprice. Shall we befriend the enigmatic warlock, or smite him with righteous fury? To romance the bear, or seek solace in the arms of a spectral bard? Such quandaries vex the soul, and yet, they exhilarate!

The combat, too, is a ballet of blades—a symphony of strategy played upon the stage of turn-based skirmishes. Cunning tactics prevail, and the warlock laughs as wooden gates splinter before his arcane might. Fire spells ignite the flammable, and axes sunder doors with a satisfying crunch. Walls, invisible to mortal eyes, yield to nimble climbers, granting passage to secret realms.

“Nay,” quoth the game, “I shall not deny thee.”

And hark! Co-op beckons, a merry band of friends—each with custom characters—joining the fray. Whether online or upon a couch, their seamless presence enchants. One distracts the guard, while another pilfers treasures unseen. Verily, this camaraderie rivals the finest mead-soaked tavern tales.

Now, ye seekers of CRPGs, hearken unto me: Baldur’s Gate 3 is no mere diversion; it is an opus, a magnum opus, nay, a celestial crescendo that reverberates through the annals of gaming history.

And so, ere I conclude, let us raise our goblets to this masterpiece—a chalice brimming with cinematic storytelling, sandbox mayhem, and roleplaying aplenty.

Verily, it is the greatest RPG mine eyes have beheld.

Fare thee well, adventurers, and may your journey be ever fraught with wonder and wyverns.

People have said this more eloquently: but this is a top 10 game. If you love RPGs, or D&D you should give this a try. The sheer amount of choice and ways in which to approach problems may seem overwhelming, but it's also incredibly freeing. My first play through I didn't feel the need to "save-scum", but the ability to save at any time, including in the middle of a dialogue tree, makes it so that you can play the game anyway you want and craft your perfect story. For people who prefer combat to story, the combination of party members and various spells and abilities will give you so many ways to destroy your enemies. The approach to romancing your party members is quite novel too, although I still feel there needs to be more and better polyam representation, there have been a few interactions that I really appreciate. 

As stated in this reviews thesis, this game is a Critical Success, absolutely recommend.
