I want to start this review with a massive disclaimer. I actually think this game is incredibly assembled and the team deserves all the accolades they have earned for this project. The detail and polish are fantastic, and they should be very proud of what they've accomplished. 

I purchased this game in the wake of it winning GOTY and on the recommendation of a friend. I had heard numerous disclaimers that this game was very reliant on Dungeons & Dragons mechanics, and familiarity with these would be quite helpful. I played D&D two times, roughly ten years ago - but I figured it had multiplayer capability so I could be helped. I was wrong. Another caveat is the number of hours I've supposedly put into the game is misleading - as several times I was either pulled away with work and parenting duties, or just raged out and never closed the game.

This game does a wonderful job of giving you options. You can play any way you want, as anybody you want, and the game and story organically evolve around these choices. The amount of work that has gone into divergent branching narrative is mind-boggling, and frankly beyond praiseworthy. But the freedom to do anything you want, comes with a cost; especially if you're not familiar with or into D&D. 

During my first attempt, I played a rogue. I got lost several times, in areas I thought were hostile, and ended up making several assumptions that basically ruined the run. Chalk that one up to learning. My second attempt, I played a warlock. This time, I played co-op, figuring my buddy would be able to teach me better. But I found him able to attack multiple times per turn, and I was only ever able to do one thing, often with a 20-30% chance of hitting and even then, frequently low damage rolls. I felt so weak, I tried a third run as a Cleric. I figured trying to heal people instead of dealing damage, would mean I would be targeted less and not care as much about low damage output. Again, not successful, so I tried Paladin - thinking hey, I can be tankier and still heal? Wrong again. So I tried a Monk. Won't even tell you how bad that went. Finally landed on Fighter, and his was the most successful run I had. I had good damage output, good survivability, multiple action uses, and fit the team I wanted best. I made it through Act II, but I still feel like the mechanics of this system elude me. 

I had long understood weapon/armor proficiency and stats help drastically, but I have never once found the ratio of damage output to the amount of enemies in encounters to be well-balanced. I'm either constantly struggling through one encounter, losing half my team in the process, or just wrecking bosses moments later. If you use a bunch of abilities, you have to rest to regain them, and most of the worthwhile ones require going to camp and spending supplies to replenish. If you want to press on into multiple encounters, there's a good chance things will get very difficult very fast. In game that sells the sheer urgency of it's story, and limited number of canonical days, it sure struggles to balance how much you can ostensibly accomplish in a day before needing to rest and recover, with how much you "should be doing for the story." Essentially my biggest issue is that I am not familiar with the mechanics or very good at understanding them.

The game also struggles with letting you know which encounters are appropriate for your level, which both supports and kills the concept of free-roam. In my fighter run, I found the dragon rider patrol in Act I, and the angry lizard woman ran to talk to them. Trying to follow, I started a fight I was in NO WAY equipped to win, and after several save-scums, I decided I'd send her to talk, grab another party member from camp, and come back with better numbers. Whoops, lizard lady got killed while I was doing that, and couldn't be revived with a scroll. It was at that point, that I realized not only did I not care about most of the characters, but that I also wasn't having fun. Choices you make will all impact the game, in ways you cannot predict. Most of the time, they align with traditional story-telling and can be predicted, but in a few cases they seemed completely contrarian or in other cases created a "cock-up-cascade," chaining negative effects down the road. I wasn't seeing the point of crafting my own narrative when I could save-scum my way to any outcome I wanted, but couldn't see where that narrative would take me. It's like folding the ears of pages in a Choose-Your-Own-Adventure book. This is made even worse by the colossal load-times for booting or re-loading.

I never really connected with most of the team I assembled. I tried to be thorough and complete - assembling as many as I could, exhausting dialogue, being friendly to get the most out of them, but they all felt distant to me. They all kept hitting on me, which is another problem - this game must think I am hornier than I really am - but I didn't feel much kinship with the vast majority. They all feel like they're trying to be tragic heroes, but that trope gets old after five or six people. I am not a writer, nor do I profess to be a reputable critic, but the story seemed absolutely loony. There are parts that take themselves very seriously, and parts that are either references to other fantasy games or that don't take themselves seriously at all. The juxtaposition of these pulls me out of the story, almost as much as the frequency of sleeping despite impending global destruction. In short, I think this game struggles with tone. 

This all sort of culminates into the notion of side-quests. You collect a TON of side-quests, which is great for world-building, but not great for other reasons; predominantly not often having a clear direction of how to progress them, or whether those are distractions or actually impact the story. I will say, the game gives you hints for some by way of some text, and generally tells you if proceeding past a certain point might prevent you from finishing some quests. I just frequently felt like there was more fluff to pad out the game in the name of world-building.

In the end, there is a lot to praise in this game, but I cannot recommend it. If you're on the fence about picking it up, think very carefully about your connection with D&D. If it's something you like or love, or something you really want to try, by all means - the glowing recommendations across the community are testament to the likelihood of you enjoying this game. If not, I'd save yourself the money and put it towards something else - or at LEAST wait for a serious sale down the road.

[h2] [b]What a fantastic journey![/b] [/h2]

[u][b]What I loved:[/b][/u]
[list]
[*] Good character development on most of the companions and your avatar
[*] A lot of good utilities and spells to use in or outside of combat
[*] The ability to manipulate/take use of the area you fight at to your own advantage
[*] Boss fights are decent enough
[*] The Mind Flayer is such a fascinating creature!
[*] Excellent music score, sound effects and ambiance
[*] Actions with consequences
[*] A wide array of class/race to mix and choose from
[*] Nice to be able to dye most of the equipment
[*] Beautiful locations ranging from lush forest, deep caves, catacombs and swamps to dark and eerie areas. Large buildings/city with different cultures to explore and small nooks and crannies with secrets to tell for the brave
[*] A few puzzles that adds a little flavor 
[*] A lot of cool familiars that you can bring with you on your adventures or just summon when you want them for a fight
[*] Plenty of side quests with memorable characters and some with excellent fights.
[*] A camp where you can interact with your companions/familiars and chill between fights. Felt like home to me:)
[/list]
[u][b]What I think could be improved:[/b][/u]
[list]
[*] Inventory management is a chore. You can't rename bags which is something that you should be able to do. I would have thought they'd learn from past mistakes like with Divinity: Original Sin 2
[*] Act 3 felt a bit rushed and sluggish. I know Larian has been patching and getting this act better, but I have not visited Act 3 since last play through, so I will be doing a honored mode to see the major changes
[*] I would have liked to see a bit more lore in different books. Most of them were paper thin and while that works for some of them, others could have expanded more on the history of the areas you visited to make them come even more to life
[*] While there were plenty of secret items to find, I would have liked to see more unique feeling items
[*] More puzzles like they did in Divinity: Original Sin 2
[*] Character drag/chain system did not feel as responsive as in Divinity: Original Sin 2. I do believe Larian has fixed this now though
[/list]

Score: 10/10. The score reflects when I finished the game with patch 1 installed. While the game had it's flaws, those were not enough to bring the score down. This is by far one of the best video games I have ever played, so a big thank you to Larian Studios is in order:)

As a massive fan of Skyrim and The Witcher 3 and not previously a fan of turn based combat, Baldur's Gate 3 has still been a fantastic experience for me. I really wanted Starfield to be my game of 2023 but it has been outmatched, by a large margin, by Baldur's Gate 3. The writing, worldbuilding, UI design and art direction are much, much better in my humble opinion. Having spent around 80 hours on my first playthrough I will certainly be replaying Baldur's Gate 3 in the not-too-distant future so I can make some different choices, which unlike in most RPGs these days, are actually meaningful.
This is what happens when an RPG and a TRPG love each other very much.

And as a fan of the previous games, I am very pleased by how Baldur's Gate 3 has stayed loyal to its roots.

Great game. This is my first introduction to a DnD style game and honestly, I love it. The rpg's I normally play are stuff like Elder Scrolls, Dragon Age, etc, etc. But this is something else, great gameplay mechanics, great story, amazing world immersion, fleshed out characters, the works.  I highly recommend this game, even if you aren't sure about the dice rolling system. Its so simple to grasp, that a noob like me picked it up pretty quickly.

Addictive, good game. To mention the downsides (that do not really matter enough to make the game not a good game);
Gobbles up your time. Modding recommended at least after first play-through to speed up certain aspects of the game, like dice rolling speed, perhaps lock-picking speed, movement and combat speed. This is the biggest one for me when it comes to subsequent play-throughs.
Some (many) plot holes with the story if you care. Someone can wish you to death but leaves it to her minions... Villains appearing for the sake of appearing rather than for consistent narrative... but this is offset with good dialogue and characters.
Balance doesn't exist. If you are obsessive about character building, this will obsess you for a while. Swords bards seem to be able to do everything better than other classes after level 6 (full caster and "full" martial with burst). "Don't use it" is a difficult argument when it's a great addition to any multi-class at level 6-8-10, and can make almost any build better.
Some bugs, which are being worked on in patches.
None of this takes away from the fact that this is a great game from Larian.

Update after patch 6:

The priorities of the studio making this game are wrong. They are focused on making new kissing animations and changing already created dialogue options to force the writers opinions on the player. Additionally, Wyll continues to have content removed or is an after thought overall while the white characters have the most voice lines in the game. The updates feel like the game is still in early access even though it officially launched a while ago.

My recommendation is to stop letting fan service drive your update priorities and focus on building out all the companions and add stuff to the game instead of changing or removing content that is already in.

I love the dice rolling mechanic and wish there was an option to make it happen more. The camera controls are a bit cumbersome for me but after I discovered "tactical" mode it helped. The story is good so far and the game is well worth the money spent. Hitting left alt doesn't seem to show everything that you can interact with and that could be improved. Some of the cut scenes are a bit odd as the player character I created (Female Gith) just nods and has facial expressions instead of vocalizing the dialogue that you select. 
Lastly the game download was HUGE and took the greater part of a day on my 1.2 Gbps cable connection, which can often pull a reliable ~5-6 GB per minute from other places. This was followed by a HUGE ~130GB patch (6) that luckily downloaded in 20 min or so but took over an hour to install.  
Despite me listing these things, I highly recommend the game, it is a fantastic add on to the BG line and lives up to the hype.

Let me just say, first of all, this is an incredible game, and I would recommend playing it to anyone and everyone. It is truly fantastic and sets a new standard for the future of RPGs. 
However, I feel there are some major flaws that have yet to be addressed by Larian, and I am going to lay them all out plainly, as I have finally completed the game. Spoilers ahead.
The main issues the game has, both technically and story-wise, are found near the end. One of the most glaring problems is that of Wyll's quest. Wyll as a character has been the most neglected in terms of content, and his story is lacking. Seeing that the Wyrmway quest is now a side quest rather than a part of his main quest is disheartening, and his story has so much potential that is just missed and seemingly brushed aside. The fact that he was forced into Mizora's pact due largely to the Dragon Queen coupled with the knowledge that a dragon lies dormant under Baldur's Gate, apparently destined for Wyll's family to awaken, are two very interesting pieces of Wyll's lore that could have been explored much more than they were. In the Wyrmway, which was originally the final hurrah of Wyll's quest, Wyll's character development is brushed aside in order to develop the Emperor further. It's unfortunate. It would have been much more satisfying to see Wyll learn about and connect with his ancestors, as well as have his own moment with Ansur, undead and turned evil or not. In general, the Wyrmway just feels very rushed, and does not honor Wyll's story in the way he deserves. Wyll also has less romantic content than other companions, and less content in general, as mentioned. He really needs more love and attention from Larian, even if he is less popular than characters like Astarion or Shadowheart.
Another gripe I have toward the end is with Gortash's fight. It does not feel like a boss fight at all. Ketheric's fight was an incredible way to wrap up Act 2. Bhaal's fight was not as good, but still fun. Gortash's just fell flat. He was this huge antagonist, and it was very disappointing to see him treated more like a minor antagonist than a major one. He is the tyrant of Baldur's Gate. He should be in a throne room surrounded by an army. The traps should actually be tricky to get around, and make the fight more difficult. The ambiance should be better, the music, the buildup to the fight, it's just all very forgettable, and leaves you going, "eh." 
After that... oh man, I just have so many problems with the way the game ends. Let me lay it out. Once you reach the Morphic Pool, you've essentially reached the point of no return in that you cannot go back to camp and switch out your characters. You are stuck with your party from then through the final battle. This would be fine if there was any indication that you would not have any more chances to return to camp. However, I think it would just be better if you could reconfigure your party RIGHT before the final battle, like, when all your allies are gathered in the Upper City. Jaheira and Halsin show up to say good luck, but not any of your other companions...? It would make sense if they were all there, and you could switch out companions as you pleased. But I'm getting ahead of myself. 
Before that, you are in the Astral Plane with the Emperor, who reveals that he is going to consume Orpheus' power. On a good run, this is where you are usually like, hold on, I want to save him. But the Emperor is adamant that a) Orpheus will kill you if released and b) only a mindflayer can effectively wield the stones to stop the Netherbrain. Okay... Why? Just because mindflayers have psionic powers? A mindflayer is about as similar to a Netherbrain as a microwave is to a super computer. Orpheus was the one protecting us, not the Emperor. He is the one with the power, not the Emperor. He can protect us from the brain's influence for the entire game, but he cannot wield the stones to take down the brain unless he is a mindflayer? Bullshit. He's the singular most powerful enemy against the brain in terms of lore, it makes no sense. So then you're like, nah, I'm freeing Orpheus, which is the obvious good choice. And the Emperor is just like ok well I'm gonna join the brain then bye. Ahhgdhhsjfsak,dnje. HYDBHJWKNDK. WHYY. WHY. It was revealed that he was the FOUNDER OF BALDUR'S GATE, Baldur himself. Every single thing he's done this entire game--protecting us, protecting our allies, urging us to fight the brain--has been to protect Baldur's Gate. His city. It is made very clear time and time again how he is AGAINST the brain and how important his city is to him. But he just leaves. To join the brain. No hesitation, no nothing. Even if he did believe Orpheus would kill us, why wouldn't he just stick around long enough to see how Orpheus would react? And if Orpheus attacked, he could still mind portal the fuck outta there. It's just so out of character it drives me crazy... He's our ally, we can't even do a persuasion check? So he leaves, we free Orpheus, and Orpheus is like, welllll one of us has to be a mindflayer to defeat the brain. Again, no real reason for this, really just hate that so much. And your options are to turn into a mindflayer, turn Orpheus into a mindflayer, or turn Karlach into a mindflayer. Okay. Say that this annoying line of reasoning is used regardless... Why can't we recruit Omeluum to help us? I went through all the trouble of saving him, I'm sure he'd wield the stones for us. Really, there's no way we can't even ask him for assistance? Reaaallllyy? Why. WHY. Omg. Ok well, in this scenario, the best decision is to turn Orpheus into a mindflayer, even though it still sucks. I freed him hoping he would lead the Githyanki people and destroy Vlaakith, but that's off the table now. Ahhh. So you get to the final battle, it's pretty fun. If the Emperor turned against you, you have to fight him. Even though he can clearly see Orpheus is non hostile and actively helping fight the brain. Again... Ugh. The fight against the brain itself is pretty anti climactic, you are able to take it out in a few hits. I was hoping the final battle would be more like Raphael's battle, with an epic song with lyrics and such, and better ambiance. It isn't the worst, it just isn't up to par with what I was expecting. :( So yeah, those are the big issues I take with the game. I know Larian has been adding a lot of content and fixing stuff, so I hope some of this is addressed in the future! :)
But again, it is truly a fantastic game, and I am so happy to have had the opportunity to play such a work of art. Thank you for all the consistent updates, keep them coming! <3

Edit: coming back to the review having completed the game explored it quite thoroughly, I think the game start to fall apart a bit in the third and final act. The game is still well worth playing and you'll probably have a wonderful time, but you may find many storylines to be unsatisfying in their end, especially if you start looking closely. It's also worth calling out Larian's dedicated support on fixing bugs and adding new features, with extensive patches being released regularly.

The original review is below:

The story is incredibly well done and intricate. Everyone and everything feels like it belongs and there are so many unexpected interactions that make the world feel real and lived-in.

The only thing keeping it from a perfect 10 is that there are a fair few bugs still hanging around in gameplay, but the list grows shorter with each patch. Performance could probably be better too, but it's generally acceptable as-is (especially compared to a lot of recent AAA releases...)

TL;DR: Fundamentally, what Larian did was charge us 120% price for about 80% of a finished game. Their picky-and-choosy adaptation of D&D5 rules is jarring and frustrating. Correspondingly, they don't know how to create balance using this mish-mash of rules. They have no meaningful way for the player to tell their own character's story. These flaws make me regret giving in to the hype and buying the game at their asking price.

There are still MANY things that need to be fixed about the design of Baldur's Gate 3. They have improved a few things, and I'm hoping Act III is finally in a play-worthy state, but I still cannot recommend the game at the full $60 asking price. I STRONGLY encourage Larian to focus on fixing things like basic gameplay, programming, and stability instead of touching up kissing animations.
It seems no designers at Larian bothered to sit down and address the concept of balance in Dungeons & Dragons 5th Edition terms before designing the game. You will see this in every boss fight, and in multiple other encounters. No thought was given to level-appropriate abilities or strengths - or if they were, they were ignored in favor of "lawlz, wouldn't it be cool if..." mechanics and "gimmes" that the enemies receive that make combat and other encounters endlessly frustrating. This is not even counting the problems of using a rigged dice bot that in part is used to create difficulty levels.
"Save-scumming" is not only common, it is impossible to meaningfully progress without it, thanks to the rigged dice-bot in and out of combat, and the frequent imbalances. Larian didn't make a tactical or an interesting game so much as a looooong game - and it appears even they gave up on anything like quality control about 2/3s of the way through.
I regret ignoring my own rule and choosing to purchase the game at full price. Neither of the patches addressed serious issues at the core of the game, and I have next to no hope that Larian will address the serious imbalances and other issues that should have been addressed during the years of early access.

Addendum 1: Quality-of-Life Fixes
--replace the current dice bot with one that is more random (on "medium" difficulty)
--add content that allows us to tell our original character's story (through dialogue options, and maybe quests based on our choice of class, background, or added ideals, bonds, and flaws)
--balance intended encounters to the expected character level. It would be acceptable to make the zones a little more linear so we don't have to double-back very often to finish content, like we do now (probably not a workable fix after release)
--AND/OR add random encounters during long stretches where nothing else happens (but not in boss fight zones, obviously). For example, goblin scouting patrols, shadows rising from dead bodies, or rioting citizens
--if an encounter (such as a boss fight) has a specific strategy that is intended, allow our characters to make checks (such as Investigation, Perception) that give big clues as to how the encounter is intended to be beaten
--speed up quickload times
--fix opponent AI so they do not waste turns trying to perform actions they cannot complete
--reduce the effectiveness of instant death by shoving targets off cliffs (either don't make it so common, or give the shoved target another save to see if they can catch a hold, etc. This seems like a perfect use of the Slowfall spell.)
--improve lip-syncing during dialogues and cutscenes
--clarify what exactly the "target" is during pickpocketing. Is that the total value we need, is it the die number we need to roll, or what? My Astarion had a +8 bonus with advantage on a "target 20" check, and he did not succeed after 30 tries. I ran a simulation on MS Excel, and I got 3-4 20s during repeated batches of 30 attempts (including advantage)
--take out the checks with uselessly low DCs (like DC 2-5) and just give us the results of a success
--following on that, remove "critical misses" and "critical successes" from skill checks. They specifically say that is not how skill checks work in D&D5, and it results in "failing" checks that we would've succeeded at anyway, mathematically
--finish Act III and polish the entire game before you dare call it a "full release"
--AND/OR drop the price 20-33% to match the content
--my final request: Please give us a companion who is not a Mary Sue with CHA as the dump stat and a tragic, haunted backstory. How about a lizardfolk who just wants to eat all the tadpoles they can find?

25 things that will radically improve Baldur's Gate 3 or what an ideal patch would look like

Interface
1. Add UI scaling.
2. Add a setting to speed up the dice roll animation (so that you don’t have to click the mouse every time to speed it up).
3. Add a setting to speed up the battle animation by 2 times.
4. Add the setting to always press "Alt" (to highlight objects). We're tired of holding the Alt button...
5. When you hover the cursor, show information about whether a book has been read or not (including books from merchants).
6. In the alchemy tab, show the properties of the future elixir or potion, and not just the name.
7. When trading with NPCs, scrolls will display information about what spells the character has already learned and what level is required for this spell.
8. When sorting, put identical items into one cell automatically (now this has to be done manually). And yes, why can’t the infernal iron be put into one cell? After all, enriched iron is possible! Give me the opportunity to fold infernal iron too.
9. Add text chat for multiplayer games.
10. Add a button to change floor (sometimes it can be difficult to move between floors because of the camera).
11. Add WASD controls. Moving the keys is really very convenient for many people.

Balance
12. It is necessary to upgrade the weapon to red (very rare), which can be crafted in the infernal forge (at the end of Act 1). Now it is blue (rare) and absolutely useless, as it is worse than even some green ones.
13. Act 3 bosses should be strengthened.
14. The dragonborn race should be strengthened (the dragonborn are the only race with only 1 ability, when other races have 4-5 abilities).

Basic moments
15. Give the opportunity to choose who will conduct the dialogue during a dialogue that has already started! Ideally, who will answer each question. If it is possible to switch during dialogue, that would be just great!
16. After the finale and the end of the game, it would be good to see the statistics of the game - what percentage of additional quests were completed, how much gold we received, how many enemies we killed, what key decisions were made during the passage, etc. The result of our passage in one picture (we would be interested to know the result of our passage and compare it with our friends).
17. Add a crafting profession! There are a lot of different stones, metals and materials in the game, of which there is a lot, but there is nowhere to use it (or there is a lot left over). We want to create new unique equipment!
18. Add the possibility of a romance with Jaheira.
19. When you started an affair with one of your companions, it would be logical that they now sleep together in the camp.

Graphic arts
20. Add support for DirectX 12
21. Add support for DLSS 3.5 (this already includes Super Resolution, Frame Generation and Ray Reconstruction)
22. Add support for FSR 3.0
23. Add support for Path Tracing (or at least Ray Tracing)

Miscellaneous
24. Add Steam cards and a Steam game profile in the style of Baldur's Gate 3. We've been waiting for this for so long!
25. Add Steam Workshop support!

I am highly recommending this game. After nearly 1,000 hours into this game. Let me just tell you. I have never been a huge DnD fan. But this game sits differently. This game may not be for everyone if you don't like fantasy lore such as DnD or have an idea of certain races. But I can tell you this. Race and Class type doesn't matter in this game as much as you think it does, and thats a huge positive. Because they are all useful in many different ways. You can be an OP one punch man monk or a oathbreaking pally. 

From a Fighter/Ranger to a Druid or a wizard like Harry Potter to a Sorcerer named Raistlin Majere. It doesn't really matter. What matters is how you have fun with your party. From Act 1 of spending roughly around 40 hours of game play to Act 2 of spending 80 hours. And still, there is more to see lore wise, every person in the game has a unique story. 

So why not give it its fair shot.
An RPG that will stand the test of time. the same way KOTOR does. AAAA game.

Update at 110hrs: I feel comfortable with with my current time in the game giving a final review on bg3 as I do not think I will be returning to the game First I will start off with the good parts Story is good but for the most part it is an illusion that doing you actions have an effect on the game Much like cybershit 2077 it all ultimately leads to the same ending The graphics are pretty nice almost up to par with what Rockstar had 10 years ago when they release gta 5 

Now I am going to address the bad parts of the game and unfortunately this going to be extremely long  First and foremost is class design Might be some of the worst class design I have ever seen Can't decide between zerker and fighter Don't worry they do the same shit Wondering if you should pick wizard, sorcerer, warlock or druid Go with any they all do the same thing All have the same spells None of the classes have individuality Classes don't synergize with each other OR you can play ranger, monk or rogue All these classes basic attack and that's it Nothing changes as they level up other than they can basic attack again Finally we have paladin, bard and cleric These two classes are just completely full of trash Each level up you get useless spell after useless spell. Maybe next time they should spend less time give trash to those three and more time give ranger/rogue/monk literally anything Another massive negative is spells slots Got a new spell you want to use Sorry to bad it takes a spell slot so you can only use it once Please continue to use shitty magic missile for 99% of the play through because apparently that is fun Seeing that we have divinity original sin we know that the devs can comprehend a good combat system but for bg3 for whatever reason they just decided to remove it Maybe one of the greatest sins in the game is the fact that armor is incredibly unrewarding As you move through the game you expect armor and weapons to get better but in bg3 this isnt the case The sword that you find on the level 1 imp in the tutorial zone is just as strong as the super rare hard to get legendary sword Same goes for armor You are basically punished for wanting to get armor because armor nerfs your characters by proficiency And probably my last big issue with the game is the endless amount of yapping. It is simply non-stop Everytime you go anywhere someone has to talk You want to do long rest so that you can use a cool spell for once before going back to magic missile and cantrips To bad you need to talk to 13 companions and a dog before you go to sleep otherwise they will leave your camp because of neglect All in all, this rates as probably one of the most overrated games of all time I DO NOT RECOMMEND If you want a fun game go get Starfield

This game is utterly phenomenal. 

Having completed three co-op play through's, with every achievement unlocked and three hundred hours in  game, I can genuinely one of the best gaming experiences I have ever had the delight to play. That much was clear even after my first few hours in the game, and it remained true for every single moment of gameplay.

Every, single microscopic detail of this game has clearly been poured over with love and attention by the dev team at Larian - from the beautiful landscapes & graphics,  to the gorgeous music, to the rich story, full of side quests with fully voice acted dialogue that recalls earlier interactions, to the deep backstories and personalities of nearly every character you interact with - it is utterly mind blowing how much detail there is in this game.

Having played through on regular, tactician and honour mode difficulties - I can firmly say the combat in this game is truly great fun, with each playthrough playing differently. In each of our play through's we discovered new parts of the game we had not discovered before, and tried out new builds - we were never bored.

ACT 2 MAJOR BUG/QUEST BLOCKER THAT TRASHED MY STORY, HAS MAJOR CONSEQUENCES, AND YOU WILL LOOSE A COMPANION DUE TO IT.

*** Possible Act 2 Story Spoilers ***

The bug/quest blocker that myself and many others have encountered causes a major Act 2 quest line to fail; and a companion eventually abandons you because of it!

I will make this as spoiler free as possible, but I do describe the issue.  So please decide if you want to keep reading now.

___________________________________________________________________


I killed a certain kid in Act 2 that tried to kill me in a game, had killed others, and wasn't going to stop. I felt they needed to be stopped. Fair enough.

Later I find out that this kid is EXTREMELY important to a major quest line in Act 2.

Even if a player kills this kid they are supposed to be respawnable if you have a certain dialogue with a certain Druid in Act 2. The dialogue option should come up allowing the player to tell the Druid they killed the kid. Then the Druid will respond that you cannot really kill the kid, and the kid will respawn when the player goes back to the place the kid was previously killed with the Druid.

However I don't get the dialogue about having killed the kid. I only get the dialogue to tell the Druid I saw the kid. So the kid won't respawn to be able to talk to them and progress the major quest line.

Not being able to progress this quest, and also that the outcome is so very drastic, seriously trashes my game story. And I loose a companion! It is a major bug/quest blocker that needs fixing. (If I wasn't watering this down, to try and avoid spoilers, you would understand the consequences to the story better.)

I don't even want to start Act 3 until they fix this and various other issues that you can easily find out about in online forums and gaming articles.  I don't want more bugs/quest blockers to damage my story more.

I submitted a report to Larian about this and got no response.

EDIT: Still not fixed after Patch 6. Still no response from Larian after months.  This is a quest blocker that causes the player to loose a companion.  That is HUGE.

Not much that I can say that hasn't already been said. Game is good and could've been a masterpiece, BUT is heavily plagued with bugs and broken mechanics which break the game and ruin immersion. Lots of poor execution and lack of quality assurance. The game has been out for 6 months officially and I am still dealing with lots of issues, even after multiple patches. Gets extremely infuriating and annoying. It seems like the game was not properly play tested, as well as the patches. The worst is the pathing and hitboxes. It is so janky and hard to select what you are trying to. Companions and especially pets/summons are consistently getting stuck on ladders or nothing at all, to find that they got stuck 10 minutes ago. It is a constant battle of making sure everyone in your party is actually following you. It is seriously bad. Had issues with not being able to progress a few quests due to no fault of mine. Transitioning the camera between levels/floors is pretty bad. Some QOL is missing that you would think is common sense which is a shame. There are way too many traps and puzzles in this game, it just gets very annoying instead of fun and exciting. I end up having to interact with every object, book, or person in fear that I may miss important content, items, quests and progression (although the game is forgiving if you don't). It would be a lot better if this was more easily done and indicated. Not sure if some of these issues can even be fixed due to the engine and bad principles. These are only my major complaints... there are still a lot of other minor issues. Overall, the game is rich with story, writing, creativity and customization and is MOSTLY well made. But still needs a lot of polishing.. 

It is still mostly a fun experience and you definitely get a lot of play time. This may be GOTY for 2023, but there wasn't any fair competition. I expected more especially with that title. While they are working on improvements, it is a slap in the face that new patches bring dumb little quirks (like new animations for kissing and your companions at camp) instead of ENTIRELY focusing on fixing the plethora of bugs/issues first... Some of these new features they introduce are also buggy and poorly executed. Example: the new bartering update just makes any items offered disappear out of my inventory without actually offering them. If the game left early access, it should feel mostly complete and polished, but at times it doesn't. Gives me a sour taste in my mouth.

8/10 -- with all things considered, the good still outweighs the bad -- would easily be higher if the game wasn't half broken at times.

One of the greatest video games I have played in the last 10 years and a game I will continue to play years more. Literally filled with endless, countless, and in times senseless possibilities on how one can take their story through. Be the crazy psycho bad guy that unleashes hell against your enemies and fear on your friends, or the savvy wondrous bard playing lute in the middle of combat while beating your enemies with dual wielding salami sticks. 

The characters/voice acting from everyone is 100% quality and passion, giving us fleshed out characters and an arch between all of their stories that allow for anyone to quickly find their own favorite group, and an even greater pool of neerdowells that will tug at your heart strings and support you along the way. I recommend finding yourselves a way to rotate everyone throughout since all have unique dialogue wherever your story may take you.

I have never done turn-based gaming and am a veteran of countless FPS shooters and action/adventure games, nothing in my library at all plays like how this game does and it has been the most satisfying from any game I ever played. I couldn't look away and found myself vibrating in anxiety or excitement when rolling dice for a chance at an action. And every action, choice, and decision you make completely matters as to how the ending plays or the way you are perceived at the moment and in the future.

I could hardly contain myself in most cases, being unable to finish Act 2 and get near Act 3 not because of boredom or conflictions, but because I love it all in the beginning so much it makes me want to experience it all over again through the eyes of a different character and class just to see what other options and exciting opportunities would present itself. You get lost in this game and the design that it will literally make hours feel like minutes.

This game has invoked all the love I have for RPGs and returns it in the most gratifying, and loving experience I ever had in any video game. Not since the days of Mass Effect have I felt this way in a long time, leaving me completely ecstatic to be apart of something bigger than all of us with a community across the world experiencing this either for the first time or a veteran of DnD and the Baldurs Gate series in general. I will no doubt be playing this game every day and chance I get for the next years of my life, and am excited to experience it all in my repeating gameplay and the mods that come out in the future.

10/10 Across the board, beating any and all games developed by "Triple A" studios. 
May Larian Studios bring more wonderful experiences to our lives, may the team experience riches that now comfort their homes. I look immensely forward to the next installments they bring and hope all of you that have the game enjoy your stories. If you're one still on the fence wondering to purchase or not, I say do not even hesitate. If you have the money and can afford it, get it now.

Prior to playing this game, my experience with Dungeons and Dragons was limited to watching the Jeremy Irons movie from 2000. As I’m sure you can imagine, this did not set my expectations very high. Nonetheless, I decided to check this game out anyway and oh boy do I regret that decision. Too much of my time has now been taken up not just by playing Baldur’s Gate but also playing D&D with my neighbour Keith in his basement. The lack of sunlight I see on Sunday’s is truly troubling, but Keith’s storytelling is impeccable, the man has a way with words. Possibly not as good as the storytelling within Baldur’s Gate 3 but he doesn’t get paid to write our campaign so you can’t expect too much from him.
This game really excelled at utilising the best parts of D&D, creating such an immersive experience within a world that feels lived in. The incredible characters and voice acting help to make the player feel like they are actually a part of this tale, something Keith could improve on as the only accents he can do are Jamaican and South African. Another area BG3 tops Keith would be the atmospheric music. He would never have a villain singing their own theme song during their boss fight, which really made Raphael a standout for me in this game. The entire period spent in the House of Hope was one of the tensest sections of a video game I have ever played, knowing that at some point Raphael would show up but not when. Then when he finally does, he is singing the battle music himself, absolute madman.
The ensemble of characters that make up the adventuring party within this game are excellent company throughout the game, all offering different skills and personalities to aid in the fight against the absolute. The ability to swap them in and out depending on what you need is quite helpful, and I wish I could swap out Keith’s friend Louise as she is fucking annoying, but I guess that’s just another thing BG3 has over actual D&D.
Overall, I would highly recommend this game (and D&D in Keith’s basement) to anyone interested in playing and would absolutely place BG3 within my top 7 games on Steam.

Where to begin ? Ive been Playing Dungeons and Dragons since 1982.  Ive played every medieval fantasy game you can name and, while Ive enjoyed many - NONE come even close to representing the actual D&D experience the way this game does.  It surprises and delights me at every turn.  From challenging puzzles, unexpected plot twists, humor, drama , romance and adventure Its simply amazing.  I am purposefully playing slow and limiting my playtime so I can savor the expereince for as long as possible. 

There are a few flaws - The party size limit is 4, despite you often encountering significantly more foes than that - Id like to see 6 or 8 allowed and Id rather do it without mods, which are not yet supported.  But really, those are my only two, very minor, complaints.

The good?   The story, Engaging, well written and not a series of "kill 10 rat" quests.  Each subquest is strange and wonderful... in the past week ive worked for a Musroom King, freed an evil drow with explosives so I could cut off his head, and saved a senile dwarf from a field of explosive flora. 

This morning I met a blacksmith who I gave a random piece of metal to that I found nearly 25 hours of gametime ago - and totally unexpectedly - he made me some plate mail armor.

Decisions have consequences - every conversation you have to consider the long term ramifications.  I suspect strongly that decisions I make early will continue to reverberate throughout the game. 

I rate this game 10 out of 10.  Its fantastic!

Baldur's Gate 3 is an absolute triumph in the realm of role-playing games, setting a new gold standard for the genre. Larian Studios has crafted an epic that not only pays homage to the rich history of Baldur's Gate but also innovatively evolves the RPG experience. The game's world is vast, filled with stunning landscapes, intricate details, and a living, breathing environment that feels real and dynamic.

The narrative depth is unparalleled, with a story that weaves complex characters, moral dilemmas, and a rich lore that will keep players engaged for hours on end. Every choice made has significance, impacting the world and its inhabitants in a deeply immersive way. This level of agency and consequence makes each playthrough unique and personal.

Combat is a strategic delight, blending classic elements with fresh mechanics that provide both a challenge and a rewarding sense of accomplishment. The turn-based system allows for thoughtful, tactical decision-making, ensuring that every encounter feels meaningful.

The game's technical achievements are noteworthy, with breathtaking visuals, seamless performance, and an attention to detail that brings the world of Faerûn to life like never before. The multiplayer experience is seamless, offering a fantastic way to enjoy the adventure with friends.

In essence, Baldur's Gate 3 is a masterclass in RPG design, delivering an experience that is as deep and rewarding as it is fun and accessible. It's a game that will undoubtedly be remembered as a classic, a shining example of what the genre can achieve when at its best

Whether it's your 6th or 60th playthrough, Baldur's Gate 3 never fails to surprise, offering new paths to explore and unlock with each experience.

One of the game's standout qualities is Larian's consistent updates and transparent communication with the player base regarding future additions. If you're on the fence about trying out Baldur's Gate 3, I wholeheartedly encourage you to take the plunge. Trust me, you won't regret it.

One of the best RPG's of all time that I have played, and I still have yet to complete the game. If you enjoy story driven game play with combat mechanics of a turn based strategy, look no further. The writing is incredible, and nearly every character has spoken dialog making the world feel more immersive. This is a game where your choices truly matter and can have an impact to how your character is seen in the world. You may find yourself making multiple attempts to replay the game just to try out a different character or strategy. In doing so, you will discover new areas, items, quests, etc. that you haven't seen before. There are so many hidden gems to find along with the ability to play multiplayer which makes the game very re-playable. It's clear that the people at Larian studios really care about their community as they continue to deliver regular updates and fan service. Besides Baldur's Gate 3, they have made some other fantastic RPG's - I recommend Divinity Original Sin 1 and 2 as well!

Where do I begin? It’s a contender for the best RPG of the decade in my opinion. At first the story seems like a generic D&D story but the more you learn the deeper and more complicated it gets. The game responds to every choice you make. There could well be thousands of plot variations that make everyone’s game unique from one another. The voice acting is excellent, the music is top notch. Almost every detail is accounted for. The combat is extremely fun. I can go on and on about how great this game. 

Also love the various relationships you can build with party members. 

Larian if you’re reading this, congratulations on showing the AAA studios how it’s done. You’ve beaten EA, Bioware etc at their own game and written a worthy successor to the CRPGs of old. I can’t wait for dlc/sequels or even a Neverwinter Nights 3. Game is 10/10.

You can explore, quest, fight, flirt, throw poo (or rub it on your face,) piss yourself, have a lady essentially peg you, marriage, etc etc. There is SO much to offer.

Just give it a chance perhaps, you might end up loving it.

My only issue is that the radial wheel isn't more standardized (playing with controller). Wouldn't it make sense for scrolls and potions to be in separate wheels? Or separate wheels for spell types/levels? Instead, every time you pick up something or learn a new spell, the game randomly throws it into the end of the wheel, and you have to manually find the right place for it. For all five party characters. Every single time. Until you give up around the middle of Act II and stop keeping track of any new spells/scrolls/potions.

That said, this might be the best video game I've ever played.

Balder gate 3 is great,difficult but rewarding isometric CRPG of all time. Over my review,I will discuss the positives and the negatives but I give it a 10 out 10. It could not think of any flaws except one.
**********************************minor spoilers*********************

Story: The hook of the story is immediate. There is no ambiguity about what needs to be done. There is tadpole in your characters eye socket and it need be removed or embraced. As the your characters explore the world, the rich story enfold to other parts of the game that is magical.

Difficulty: Rogue-like difficulty: Each combat is intense so knowing the game rules and spells are important or the part will wipe out and may start at a saved sport or check point, but with honour mode check the game is truly a rogue - like:

Graphics: There are two main types on instances the dialog scenes and the isometric play. The game plays very similar to Dragon Age Origins. There is the party that is in a strategy mode which only has 4 person teams,I wish with their was 6 though. The graphic in that mode are decent, but when it comes to  dialog mode the graphics are awesome.

Dialog and options: This is where the game goes up an way beyond the call of duty. there are 9 classes and 10 main classes but each option weather you are an 1/2 Ork, Elf, to other races, the world subtly treats the character unique. even if you are a male or female, the world adjusts to the character. Each choice impact the character and the world around....12 out 10!. Extra credit for the amount work and detail the developing team took.

System requirements: The requirements for the game requires a state of the art machine. This is a bummer because in order the play what the authors intended for the best experience, I would say it may cost up to $5500. Not going to into super technical details, I hope after it is written, PC gaming machines to play this game will be a lot lower in price. I used an Intel i9 processor with Nvidia 16 GB graphics card with Asus motherboard. I might of over killed it?

Overall: if you have the gear play this game, you will not be disappointed, enjoy the rich and painstaking work and detail Larion went through so everyone can enjoy it. Enjoy the story and the confict the world has to offer.

Only 6 hours in to a singleplayer run, here's my initial impressions:

is the game different from BG1 and BG2? Yes, but that's what happens when twenty years and different developers separate the entries of a series. Many of the disappointments people express are not invalid, because they come down to preferred styles of gameplay. That being said, I think this game is an excellent entry into the BG franchise and I have been thoroughly enjoying it so far. As it is the first day of early access, there is some roughness in the production values that will likely be smoothed over by full launch. The fun, substantive integration of 5E systems into an RPG of this size is excellent. Of the present classes and races, there should be enough to interest anybody, though I am greatly looking forward to the rest of the PHB material. One aspect of DOS2 that lent it a lot of longevity was the modding scene - I hope the modding scene for BG3 becomes just as developed over time. There is truly a lot of actualized potential in the game as it is, and I think that anyone who enjoys fantasy RPGs will find an enjoyable experience in this new Larian project.

Would I recommend this game to anyone who love the likes of Mass Effect, Dragon Age, or even Knights of the Old Republic? Absolutely i would. Also there is plenty of room for new player of this genre to learn how to use the gameplay mechanics and interact with the story. 

There is so much to do in this game and how you can do it, is simply mindblowing. Speaking with animals, speaking with the dead, stealing shit from people while distracting them, and many more ways, how the world reacts if you use different actions and spells on the NPCs. And the dialogues? Entirely unique with every playthrough, painfully aware what race, class, and former choices you roll with. Even with a failed dice roll, the experience can be so epic, just like with a Tabletop game with humanly chaotic outcomes and events. 

The companions, you enlist during your journey are profoundly original, with their own piece of mind, but capable of coming around with any kind of playthrough you go with, if you care to listen, and talk to them. With voice actors so talented, they perfectly capable of displaying the vast array of euphoria, dread, strife humor and pityness that makes them truly believable and humane. Even if you get to know them, the game offers you moments, when they display adaptivity to the story and your choices.  This is what really makes them feel more lifelike. 

Only the amount of quests in this game is simply astounding, and the depth some of them is remarkable. I had many great moments, during my 400+ hours when I was just struck before the monitor. Sometimes soultearing, cathartic cutscenes blew my mind away, many times the simple contentedness, how my character's actions could solve some dread issues for people. And of course there is plenty of opportunity for Larian's sense of humor to shine trough.

With regular updates they always add some more spectacular and fulfilling content to the game. Even some elements that were missing from launch have been succesfully implemented with these updates. I believe it is one of the best games I ever played with, and I am really proud to say this is a game I will always come back to. Also, congratulations for the Game of the Year Award!

Ps.: I love you Baldur's Gate 3, and can't wait for more player made mods and original stories!!!

I'll admit that when Baldur's Gate 3 took the Game of the Year prize in 2023, I was quite surprised that a game I had totally missed had won so much positive reception. About 40 hours in and I can clearly see how this game has won so many hearts and minds. Baldur's Gate 3 however is not so much an open world game as it is an open narrative game. The scope and variety of choices and consequences you place into both short side stories, character stories, and the main story is immense. Much like the Dungeon's and Dragons IP that this game finds its foundation in, there is never one single method to tackling a problem. Do you fight a boss, lay a trap with gunpowder and fire, disguise yourself as an ally, or convince him to kill himself? The possibilities are present but never totally obvious, demanding players use their wits and creativity to uniquely explore this world. It may be the closest adaptation we have in the video game industry to a true Dungeons and Dragons experience.

One of the best games I've ever played!
The devs took into considerations tons of player's choices and variations of his actions.
Gameplay is really interesting since the game itself is a mix of a vidogame and a board game and there are aspects of such D&D genre such as dice which you roll for almost every action from fighting to flirting. Some players may dislike this thing since you may lose some content and use safescam method. But the game is made to be replayed multyple times with different roleplay models.
I loved the world of Faerûn! The world itself is giant and you will always find some hidden locations. The devs made a big work to fill the books and dialogues with pieces of the story of this place. I enjoyed to explore all locations, they're all have their own atmosphere and meticulously worked out details which is incredible.
Also want to mention how various the game is in dialogues and relations between characters. There are several characters in your camp and you can get through their stories if you want or don't interact with them up to the end. Having a certain character in your group cause different ingame situation, i.e. having Lae'zel when you appear to githyankis camp may make it easier to get to the camp since she can talk to representatives of the tribe. AND THERE ARE TONS OF SUCH INTERACTIONS!
Also the plot is kinda interesting with the idea of an "Absolut cult" which I won't spoiler. But I will say that endings vary because of your choices during the plot.

AAAAAAND It is extremely fun to play with friends!

All in all the game deserves its Game of the Year 2023 and other awards. This game is a work of art! The devs put their souls into this game. Play it and you will see why! 
Big thanks to Larian Studios for making such unique and multifaceted game :3

Pros:
1. VAST AND ENGAGING story/content.
2. Fun classes and combat.
3. Extensive intractability.
4. Can save in cutscenes, battle, and out.
5. Well fleshed out companions and NPCs. They all have their own personalities and it's believable.
6. Voice acted cutscenes on virtually every encounter.
7. Great graphics.
8. Respecable relatively early on.
9. Allows mature content fitting with story.
10. Voiced dialogue.
11. !(This addresses most Cons)! Devs have and continue to add improvements. These include quality of life updates, such as accessing quest items from camp chest when away from camp.


(Most Cons are fixed/remedied by point 10 above)
Cons: 
1. Some bugs.
2. Inconveniences:
  a. Map:
    i. When Map opens it doesn't center on character.
    ii. Can't look at maps of other locations without being there while looking.
  b. Can't lock in place items in inventory.
3. Not developer's fault but DnD leveling power up feels underwhelming and lacking in player choice of how to grow skills/talents/abilities. Any choice of feats is usually every 4 levels.

Game of the decade... Truly, it is... I love it. And it is the first game for a long time that managed to make me play it so much.

BUT...

Only the vanilla release day version. Every single hotfix and patch after it was made only to break the game more and more every time. They state about 1000 fixes every patch, but some of them are not even actually still fixed (hi, doors). And on top of that they are keep adding 2000 new bugs and glitches and degradations every time. While also successfully fixing cool features instead of critical bugs (fixing possibility to transform the statue into the sheep is surely is more important, then everything else).

So, Larian, tell me, why players must be your beta testers? Why can't you keep building that Definitive Version without breaking your game every week with patches? Just rollback to vanilla version, and test all of your changes before releasing one single Definitive Version. But yes, i know that this is impossible now, because saves are not backward compatible...

So if you want to play this game, get the vanilla release day version (or carefully choose a patch, which you really need to have). Otherwise, wait for Definitive Edition... If it is gonna ever happen.

3rd play through, after a long, long wait, 3rd of august 2023, larian released the full version, I sunk my hrs into this game, playing a custom made elf female rogue tav, accidentally murdered everyone in last night inn, thanks isobel, all prisoners in moonrise towers killed, halfway through act 3, read online that I could actually save everyone, decided to try again.

5th current play through, dark urge half elf rogue/ranger tav, am in shars trials atm, zero crashes now that the game is installed on ssd.

Imagine my surprise when i realized some bosses dont have to be fought, and can just die by talking. Definitely have to play this game multiple times.

Something that amazed me the most was controller compatibility. It was crazy how different the UI was when switching between KBM and controller. 

Next campaign, i shall get Minthara on the team, since i didnt know she can be recruited and got her killed last time. And try to get the legendary bear scene. And the Dark Urge path. And conquer the world.
(Edit: just completed second campaign with Dark Urge on Tactician mode. It still took me over 150 hours despite knowing what to do, and knowing what characters build to use. Since i wanted to get all companions during the epilogue, so i had to be good the whole run. Thus again, didnt get to see the darker endings.) 

Edit: Campaign 3 will probably be modded run. Maybe even Honour Mode. I am getting all party members all at once. No more waiting in camps. I want to see all those interactions and banter. And maybe now i can go for more ambitious routes? Again, i just realized there is an entire grove defense battle that i missed on both campaigns. 

Some complains about the game (during Patch 5): Act 2 and 3 has quite a number of bugs, as compared to Act 1. Sometimes some characters face has a really long stick protruding out. One specific gnome has a face of polygons. Some conversation options in act 3 do not make sense. Some characters just move funny in the submersible mission. And i dont know why Viconia just got knocked out when I killed her, and she can still do conversation when being talked to. If she was important i didnt see her again after that fight. And if they let Minthara die just like that, surely the game is not forcing me to let Viconia lives and it was just a bug? (edit: Viconia's scene got better in campaign 2, it made sense at least).  And then when we are knocking out Minsc to recruit him, the recruit scene may not happened if the main character was too far away. It was annoying, he immediately woke up and started attacking, we couldnt knocked him out a second time, he died. I had to reload a few times before realizing the problem and reposition myself to be closer. 

My biggest complain yet, was the city Baldur's Gate kept getting mentioned in conversations, but we havent actually been there in the entire game? Surely the lower city doesnt count? 

Overall, 90 out of 100. After the bugs are fixed, it would probably be 98 out of 100.

4 hours in, I wanted to give up on this game a couple of times. But after having read such raving reviews (also the reason why I had originally bought it) and after having read that I should take my time in exploring instead of rushing to solve the NPCs' issues, I decided to give it another go. And boy, was that the best thing I ever did in gaming!!!

The game is a pure gem. The story, the exploration, the interactions and the immersion are second to none. Skyrim is great but it doesn't compare in so many ways (not least because its actually a different genre). Also, take the time to select the best items for your individual characters - the most appropriate weapons, spells, scrolls, armour etc. As you begin to discover the game you realise that there is a lot of strategy involved in the game - in almost every aspect of it. And there are a lot of aspects to it but it is so well set out, so well defined, it truly is an incredible game.

My only criticism is related to my initial challenge and I found that other had experienced the same challenge. Perhaps with the next iteration, there could be a little more initial guidance on where a new player to the genre might best travel and manage.

Thank you for reading my post and happy gaming (also, THANK YOU INDIE DEVS!!! and Regards from one more supporter of your games and your corporate position - Tencent can have their 30% stake, so long as you remain independent and keep producing like this). Big fan.

Baldur's Gate 3 is in my opinion one of the best if not the best game ever. For fans of deep story lines, impactful decisions and character driven stories the game is a must. However when you prefer to have fast past action Baldur's Gate 3 might not be for you. 

I have played ~150h and so fare and I have not finished the game so fare I am in act 3. There is so much to do and explore (I have a second play through with my girlfriend but it here we have not left the first act so fare). Every quest feels like an adventure with multiple possible outcomes even the conversations can go so different. The extend of difference in conversations I had between my main and second character I have never experienced in another game before.

The companions all feel like there is something going on and they are interesting in there own way. Usually I feel like there is one or two companions that are topical soldier guy or another less interesting trope but not so here . Every character has its unique personalty and adds interesting conversations and story lines to the game.

The game creates this feeling you have when going on an adventure with friends in a pen&paper. If captures this seance of possibility to tackle a task in different ways and it captures the chaos that can happen due to some of your decisions very well. For me this is the best game I have played so fare. Since it feels like the open adventure most RPGs claim to be for the first time in this quality. 

The amount of effort to plan ahead capture all the different conversation paths with actors and animators is an astonishing feed by Larian. So as a conclusion I would recommend everyone to at least take a closer look at the game since this is a very unique title that shows us what the RPG genre is capable of.
Won my Golden Dice just now, so I felt like leaving a recommendation. If you're still hesitant on getting this game, don't be. This is THE GAME to get if you're even remotely interested in RPGs.

Baldur's Gate 3 was a surprising delight for me, especially since turn-based games usually aren't my cup of tea. The developers have done a phenomenal job in crafting this game, seemingly thinking of everything. I found myself in awe at every turn, never encountering a moment where I felt lost or without purpose. It's the kind of game that feels like a once-in-20-years masterpiece, leaving a significant mark on its genre. The only downside? Wishing I could erase my memory of it just to experience the joy of discovering it for the first time all over again. Baldur's Gate 3 is a rare gem that transcends personal preferences, delivering an unforgettable journey I highly recommend.

Have thoroughly enjoyed playing BG3. I haven't played a video game since the 90s, (yeah, I'm  a woman in my 50s) was completely WOWed by the graphics, fine details, interactions and play options. This game is nothing like your Mothers video games, let me tell you. I love how immersive the environment is, the details and renderings are like a beautifully enhanced reality, they are stunning. Sometimes I just sit my avatar down and enjoy the scenery :) My favorite part of this game though is my companions, I find myself wanting their approval and to help them fulfill their personal quests. Wish there was an option to just hang out with them, like by sitting around the fire chilling at camp or more alone time with a chosen love interest, I would like it if they would seek out more interactions with me just to chat (that goes for Scratch and Owl Bear Cub too, who by the way could use a name) and it would be nice if there was a prompt for when a specific companion would benefit from being there like, "Hey, Astarion would like to join" or something of the sort. ..Would like more puzzles also, its fun to puzzle them out. But the inventory, it seems like a bit of work to manage, it would be helpful if we could transfer without having the member in your party. I'm playing a wood elf wizard and am impressed with the variety of spells available. This game has sated a need for adventure and fun, I am enjoying it immensely and find myself looking forward to the moment I finally get to sit down and play with it. No idea how something so immersive and intricate was made but it is a fricken masterpiece and its HUGE!! So loving it. Thank you to the folks at Larian, Impressive!! Just WOW!!

If you love D&D, this is your go to, so many possible outcomes, play the game how you like and your decisions play it out differently.

Important note: This is my first introduction to anything D&D. I like to learn the hard way, so I've avoided looking into tutorials, manuals, and walkthroughs. The more I play, the more mistakes I make, and the more I learn along the way. In speaking to friends who've played their own personal campaigns, everyone has a different experience. The fact that this game allows you to approach a situation from so many different angles is a breath of fresh air. You can mess up, try again, get creative, and find your own way through it. It can be a bit complicated as a novice, but it gets very interesting as you learn. The storyline is fantastic, the voice acting is everything you want it to be, and the replay value is priceless. If you like RPGs in general, give it a go. If you like D&D, this is a campaign worth fighting. If you have no idea what you're getting into, definitely give it a chance.

Held off on buying this one for a very long while, as I was scared that my computer wouldn't be able to run it. Turns out that I can actually run it pretty well! That being said, I'd recommend checking your system and storage info first, because it's a pretty big game, but I've had a lot of fun with it so far. Takes some loading time for me (aging computer), and some of the features have taken me a while to learn. That being said, it has still been very worth playing for me.

Fun take on TTRPG combat overall, and I think it was translated pretty well overall from "multiplayer table top open endings" into its more linear, single-player-friendly form. I played 5e years before this game's release, so I already had a rough understanding of its rules, but I think the game's rules have a relatively solid mix of general accessibility and challenge to them, imo. Also, I appreciate the offered difficulty levels; cool touch. The way they implemented inspiration feels very funny sometimes, but I also enjoy it.

Character creator has some cool stuff to it; my biggest gripe with it would probably be the lack of curlier hairstyles. This doesn't impact me personally, but games tend to favour straighter and euro-centric hair styles, and it's a shame to see it in play here once again. (That being said, I hear there are cool mods around.) I've also heard complaints about the overall lack of face and body customization, but I, myself, haven't yet played enough saves for that to be an issue.

I cannot yet speak to character romance, as I haven't really messed with that, but I hear a lot of people are very into that, and I do think that they did some really cool stuff with the characters' branching arcs as they interact with your Tav, romantically or platonically, and as they make strides toward their individual goals. Cool stuff, really hoping to explore more of it as I find the time.

It's very clear that a lot of effort, time, and passion were put into this game. The actors are all great so far, the stories and characters interest me, and the map has lots to explore. It's got lots of ups and downs throughout, but if you think it's something you want to try, I've really enjoyed it so far, so I would recommend it, depending on your interests and circumstances.

Difficulty scaling is not fun, wasted enough time on this. Removed game from account without refund. Yes because the game is that bad. Today, which is a Friday, I felt my work would be more fun than this while playing BG3 (which was just endlessly reloading a save to get lucky rolls), and that was the end of it and it pulled the plug for me.

In my [i]k[/i]-th go at restarting the whole game from scratch, I ran into githyanki dragonrider patrols at level 3 in balanced difficulty, and it is probabilistically impossible to even run away from the fight. I can manage up to 2-3 members to run away but the main character ends up dying because she was positioned badly.

I can change the difficulty to explorer mode and do save reloads to do the fight until 1-2 patrols are left and my party gets wiped. I know that with enough reloads my party can win the fight but at this point this isn't gaming anymore. This isn't a gacha game.

I keep only one save because I am honoring the dice roll that determined Lae'zel to play along but the gith guy caught the lie, triggering the fight. I know there's an inherent problem in dnd where lower levels are rough, but any advices to avoid fighting at lower levels are dismissed because that would mean restarting the game from scratch as I have only one save right before the fight starts. Oh and there isn't even an option to save your character customization, right?

The very fact that devs decided to spend time on a useless feature dubbed karmic dice, which effectively rigs the dice probability mass function (why the hell is it even defaulting to On?), but decided to not implement a basic UX element where it should at least display the expected value of how much damage would be dealt if the attack roll succeded, immediately indicates they don't know how accommodation works. This isn't 2000s anymore. The intent of karmic dice is to help the players, right? Well, when I am pointing at a target I would like to know how much damage I will be dealing as a number (just the expected value is fine), because otherwise I need to manually look at the stats of the target and figure out the distribution myself, which I can do but it gets tedious. This would have taken a fraction of time to implement but this was not done, in favor of spending time on even considering to implement something hideous as karmic dice. Luckily, this is a fixable problem and I've laid a solution here, and I will pay the full price again when this gets implemented in a future patch.

Just to be fair, the characters are amazing. I really wish I could be motivated to see the rest of the game, but this isn't 2000s anymore.

I finally beat 'Honor Mode' this month, this was my goal I had before I wrote this review, now that It's done...My GOD this is one of the BEST GAMES I've played in a very long time. 

I grew up as a Playstation boy and never shot my attention towards PC games unless they were Club Penguin, Poptropica, etc. This game, a Dungeons and Dragons semi-clone in video game format, was the main reason I built my PC. I've been excited for the past few years waiting for this game and when it was on BETA, I spent over 60 hours just messing around in the First Act discovering, testing and enjoying my time with all the customization. This game has honestly changed the bar in the gaming industry, not only setting the new bar in all RPG games but all future games in general. I know it's a lot asking for the AAA studios to make great games like this when all they want is $$$, but it gives me hope to see more enjoyable Masterpieces like BG# to hit the homes of all types of gamers no matter what background they have.

If you like any RPG/Action/Turn-Based  games, this is a great game for you. If you are curious about this type of game, go to a friend's place that has it, to try it out before you decide. If this game isn't for you, that's okay just be cool and patient, whatever genre you enjoy the most, I'm sure some company will make your PERFECT game soon!

THE GAME TO REPLAY MANY TIMES?

Why though?

1. RND is King. Whichever level of difficulty you are playing the realization that a random roll dice on (both yours and on the side of AI) can end your playthrough makes each and every campaign unique. 
2. Customization and multi-classing. You can be whoever you want. Want to be a spicy mix of a paladin and a bard? Here you go! Or maybe a druid/warrior/ranger? As you wish here it is! 
3. Role-playing. Sheer amount of dialogue options based on your background and deeds allow you to live the life of your character. 
4. Amount of builds and equipment. With every new game you will be able to come up with new combinations and variations of loot and equipment for your characters. Just imagine hundreds of different optimizations routes to consider based on your race, class, buffs, blessings, equipment attributes.
5. Constant optimization and develop support. Larian prove again and again that they listen to their community and implement the best solutions to make your game sessions the best experience (based on the patches in the first year post-release). And wait until we hit a full-fledged DLC or expension from them.
6. Soundtrack.Just Borislav Slavov. Some OST are just made for constant repeat on your preferred streaming service.

While not without its flaws, compared to so many major releases (like ala buggy as hell bethesda) it's a reminder of what we as consumers used to expect when buying a game at full retail around 60 USD.

While the slower pace of turn-based combat and exploration may be less than appealing to some (myself included), once I got in the mood/mindset for it.  It did remind me of Planescape Torment, with the engaging storyline and DnD flavor, altho I did miss the floating talking skull.  But unlike PT, there were clearly more potential ways to resolve conflicts, which is nice to see the difference in what 20 plus years makes.

It did help that I had become more familiar with DnD thanks to the likes of Critical Role, High Rollers and other content.  But, the most defining aspect for me is that its been a long time since I've felt a game was worth full retail price.  Not regretting paying (almost) full price is a breath of fresh air when its felt like some other studios have seemingly treated its consumer base like beta testers over the last several years.
