Baldur's Gate 3, the highly anticipated sequel to the iconic Baldur's Gate series, has captivated players with its rich storytelling, immersive world, and deep gameplay mechanics. After investing over 500 hours into the game, it's clear that Baldur's Gate 3 is a monumental achievement in the RPG genre.

One of the standout features of Baldur's Gate 3 is its engaging narrative. From the moment you create your character, you're thrust into a world teeming with political intrigue, fantastical creatures, and moral dilemmas. The branching storylines and meaningful choices ensure that each playthrough feels unique, encouraging multiple playthroughs to explore different paths and outcomes.

The world of Baldur's Gate 3 is beautifully realized, with stunning visuals and intricate details that bring the Forgotten Realms to life. Whether you're traversing the lush forests of the Sword Coast or delving into the depths of ancient ruins, the environments are meticulously crafted and full of secrets to discover.

In terms of gameplay, Baldur's Gate 3 offers a deep and satisfying experience. The turn-based combat system is strategic and challenging, requiring careful planning and tactical thinking to overcome formidable foes. The ability to interact with the environment adds another layer of complexity to battles, allowing players to leverage their surroundings to gain an advantage.

Character progression is also incredibly robust, with a wide range of classes, skills, and abilities to customize your party. Whether you prefer to play as a cunning rogue, a powerful wizard, or a righteous paladin, there are endless ways to build and develop your characters to suit your playstyle.

Furthermore, Baldur's Gate 3 features a robust multiplayer component, allowing you to embark on epic adventures with friends in both cooperative and competitive modes. The multiplayer experience is seamless and immersive, offering endless opportunities for collaboration and teamwork.

Overall, Baldur's Gate 3 is a masterpiece of storytelling, world-building, and gameplay. With its rich narrative, stunning visuals, and deep mechanics, it's a game that will keep you coming back for more, even after 500 hours of playtime. Whether you're a seasoned RPG veteran or a newcomer to the genre, Baldur's Gate 3 is an experience that shouldn't be missed.

Multiplayer:

When teaming up with random players, you're likely to encounter a diverse range of playstyles and strategies. Some may prefer to take a cautious and methodical approach, carefully planning each move in combat encounters and thoroughly exploring every corner of the game world. Others may favor a more aggressive and spontaneous playstyle, charging into battle head-on and embracing the chaos of unpredictable situations.

Interacting with players who have different perspectives and approaches can be incredibly insightful. You may discover new tactics and synergies that you hadn't considered before, as well as gain a deeper understanding of the game's mechanics and systems. Whether it's experimenting with unconventional builds, optimizing party composition, or uncovering hidden secrets, playing with random players can provide valuable insights and inspiration.

Furthermore, collaborating with strangers to overcome challenges can forge unexpected bonds and create memorable shared experiences. The shared struggle of navigating treacherous dungeons, overcoming powerful enemies, and unraveling complex mysteries can foster a sense of camaraderie and teamwork among players, even if they've just met.

Overall, playing Baldur's Gate 3 with random people can be a rewarding and enriching experience. It offers the opportunity to learn, grow, and discover new possibilities within the game while forging connections with fellow adventurers along the way. Whether you're testing out new builds, experiencing different playstyles, or simply enjoying the journey with newfound companions, playing with random players adds an exciting dynamic to the game that enhances the overall experience.

Why are you reading steam reviews about this game ? Buy it, play it, the chances are you're going to love it. The hype and reviews surrounding it are not wrong. I went into this game with no expectations - if anything I was expecting it to be over hyped. Wrong ! Great game. Great production. Excellent all round - gets a little janky the further you get into it ( a few bugs and issues ), but really, you can overlook this. Even if you're not a big fan of this kind of game, you should play it, up there with some of the best production values in a game ever. Plays great either solo or multiplayer, truly, each giving a potentially different game.
Only one real flaw with this game is that it ends. It would have been *lovely* to see this game engine opened up to allow people to create their own scenarios and maps, a la Neverwinter Nights. Shame !

PROS
* Super interesting dialogue and relationships

CONS
* Horrible load times, and if you play like me you are reloading often.
* Lots of crashing for me on 8 gigs of ram (fixed with 16 gigs).
* Many will find the fighting mechanics very dull.

BG3 is such an amazing game and If you like D&D or RPGs this is the game for you. It isn't perfect, but despite its limitations there's still a lot of fun to be had. I'd describe it as the closest to the feeling of playing D&D in a video game. No spoilers in this review.

Pros: Customization for classes adds a lot of flavor/replayability to the game and the choices you make throughout the game mostly have an impact. I played a fighter my first playthrough which made me a beast at combat but a failure at dialogue (but failing can still be fun!). Now I'm playing a bard which is a very different experience and a lot of fun. I really enjoy the turn-based combat that allows for strategy and the scaling in both character power and difficulty keeps combat engaging throughout the game. Interactions with companions are interesting and, perhaps most importantly, you can choose which companions to engage with (you'll probably hate some of them). The game starts off strong and ends really strong as well.

Cons: Combat can be cheesed and/or trivial at times depending on your build and party. The combat is secondary to the story though so I didn't find this to detract much from the game. The story is kind of interesting but sometimes bland and there are times where choices feel forced or like non-choices. For example, choosing an evil playthrough limits a lot of your options, which might make sense story-wise but can be disappointing gameplay-wise. Pacing also slows down toward the middle and middle-end of the game. I think it's 100% worth completing the story, but you can tell that more time was put into the first acts of the game and less time in the later acts. I did have to make an effort to come back to the game and keep playing at times where the game pacing slowed down.

Overall, I really enjoyed playing BG3 and I think it's worth buying even at full price if you really enjoy RPGs.

[u] It's a great game held back by the age old question of what to do with D&D game mechanics. [/u] If you're inexperienced with D&D, the mechanics you use to get through each encounter may be very confusing. The main reason for this is that game developers throughout the decades would use D&D for inspiration and reinvent fantasy combat to suit the video game rather than be beholden to D&D. What works in D&D works at the table, and the GM can mitigate shortcomings through experience, advice, and knowing when to make a judgement call.

[h2] The Good [/h2]
Where BG3 succeeds is how it builds a world and story choices and variety in the outcomes. You can play how you want to play, with a list of proverbial asterisks. That said, there are many situations where your knowledge of D&D and how video games usually work will sadly clash. Video games in general solved many situations where BG3 seems to ignore. 

[h1] It's all downhill [/h1]
This usually comes in the form of traversing environments where you almost wished it wasn't so complicated or difficult to discern the means of getting through. Some areas are obvious to reach, and others aren't, and without proper guides you may skip content because your gamer-mind knows from experience that what you see is background visuals but BG3 actually intended for you to go there. 

[h2] The story itself gets in its own way. [/h2]
A lot of time and attention was given to balancing evil factions with neutral factions through the main character who can potentially mediate overlapping motivations. However, by the time you get to this point you realize the game can rob you of the thrill of being a good mediator. You will struggle to trust the game to let you covertly navigate tense factional situations. Trusting the game is a difficult task because the RNG will let you down sooner than later. Managing mission-critical resources like supplies and in-game time (story-based days) become a huge drag. I personally got so frustrated with one area that I decided my guys were "good" murderhobos because I couldn’t trust the game to give me a good outcome. I still had to explore an entire area and I was sick and tired of looking up each section which I didn't know you could traverse - each time too. Also many fights are basically glorified cutscenes you can win but were designed for the bad guy to get away. If you don't win in 3 turns, the fight is over. You're not told this. Why did you waste your daily spells?

[h2] The combat gets in its own way. [/h2]
The combat shows that a lot of attention was taken to translate D&D spells to the video game experience, but sadly you will not fully utilize it. Some spells are only useful for conquering dialogue scenarios, but the dice is not on your side. It becomes extremely difficult to ignore that the component holding you back from playing the game how you wanted is the dice roll. The inspiration mechanic is there to help you acquire re-rolls but this isn't enough because especially early on you don't know how many chances you will get. It becomes extremely frustrating that your character is built to succeed in specific areas like dialogue, but the RNG doesn't allow for that. It makes you wish for a Fallout-like approach to stats, you dream of dice-rolls being an optional alternative to dialogue choices you are ill-equipped for, but it's not there. 

The combat problems continue when many D&D monster abilities are there to remind you that D&D combat is designed around specifically focused campaigns. An Underdark adventure is something GMs prepare parties for, a cursed land with monsters that steal your turns and deny you mobility is also something GMs prepare you for. Make no mistake, these locations are talked about way in advance. But sadly, these monsters with these abilities are not Final Fantasy monsters where you can cure statuses away pre-emptively without extensive knowledge of D&D and knowing way in advance how to avoid it. Most monsters by this point will disappoint you with the ability to teleport close which limits your combat options since area-effect spells become a liability. This game enhanced hazardous surfaces as a combat mechanic, but sadly they just get in your way and continue even way after combat is over. "Oops," that enemy you killed blew up and damaged everyone around it but you couldn't have known this would happen. It's so random. Pick WIld Magic by the way!

[h2] Spells in general are confusing[/h2]
Because the game sadly is ill-equipped to educate you on how they work in D&D or how they changed them to work in the game. Some spells were changed to only affect party members and keeping track of that over the ones that affect everyone is difficult. Some spells work without fail because an intelligent choice was made to limit who or what they affect. This becomes even more difficult to manage when the environments are either too big or too small for the party and the enemies. If your default "cannot possibly fail" contingent battle strategy is bottlenecking enemy hordes and bombing them, you better expect them to teleport into your face.  Enemies go through obstacles and other enemies but your own party will block each other like it's CSGO. 

[h2] You will have to jump through your party. [/h2]
But this wastes Actions. Spells and abilities that take a turn to charge are going to be ignored no matter how you enjoyed them in D&D. Battles are too frantic and stealing turns from your enemies is your main priority. It is already ubiquitous to do so in optimal battle strategies across different games. But in this game it's mandatory because of the wide range of damage monsters can cause and even the simplest enemy has spells and abilities to steal your turn. You will be surprised with how many enemies make 1-action-per-turn a non-factor that only you have to deal with. By this point you will realize that most classes, sub-classes, and most of what the game offers in general is not viable.

[h2] You can build a throwing character. [/h2]
But they didn't design the inventory management properly. It's very detailed and offers a lot of quality options which are necessary to skip past the lootfest, but sadly it's not enough. You can send your items to your camp, but you still need to "Add to Wares" which puts them back in your inventory.  You will wish for a Torchlight sell experience instead of barter and merchant mood mechanics which you will never make use of. Even really minor things like equipping your characters is strange because the graphical boxes seem to resist dropping items in and swapping them out. You can miss your attack and throw away your turn because it is difficult to click on enemies despite how much control you have over the camera. You can miss your chance to heal your teammate. Shoot at the floor instead of the enemy because the cursor can't assist you.

[h1] You're special if you read this and none of it mattered! [/h1]
All of this is completely noticeable on the moderate (medium), aka "Balanced," difficulty. If you can manage this on Balanced, Tactical, or Honored, more power to you. Understanding D&D mechanics in such an intricate way is a very special skill set. Being able to beat bloated damage sponges is proof you're a special kinda guy. Maybe the easy difficult which takes out most of the combat complexity is a far more rewarding experience. But for those who saw past the D&D and viewed it as a hindrance, it made BG3 a nearly unmanageable experience. I'm the type of person that can go back to playing Icewind Dale and know what I'm getting into. But if you do that, you remember how they changed the D&D experience to accommodate video games. Even back then as it is now, you can't play the game how you wanted.

Absolutely Incredible Game. As someone who's never played much RPG (more RTS instead) and definitely never played a turn-based one, the learning curve was a bit steep starting out. Act 1 is big and tutorials are limited. That said, the sense of discovery throughout the game is incredible. The amount of dialogue choices, storylines, etc. can be overwhelming but going through my second playthrough now feels so different. Especially since I went evil this second time. 

A few things I wish were different from a personal preference style. There's a lot of mutilation and gore. Bodies and blood litter the ground everywhere as if pestilence and burying dead didn't exist ever. I love the dark aspects of the Shadowland, the deeps of the Underdark and Grym Forge. Love the Act 1 surrounds and even the chaos and confusing Baldurs Gate and surrounding area in Act 3. However there are times when I feel it could be toned down in terms of graphic content. I don't mean to say that death and savage scenes shouldn't exist but this game feels more fantasy-horror than fantasy for most of the playthrough.

I do love that you can romance and build real relationships with your companions. I love the battles that can come out of nowhere and slap you if you're not ready, it really makes scouting and being clever rewarding. I love that you can do so many types of playstyles from sneaky rogues, to brawling Owlbears, to raining down lightning or simply bashing a big sword down on someone repeatedly. 

I did feel the end to be a bit anti-climactic given the massive (hundred-plus hours build up) to fight the biggest baddest boss. I'd been saving a certain cleric spell, had all these companions to aid me and didn't end up needing them or using them thinking there would be a bigger fight. Of the 3 main sub-villains, the General was the most standout, the others a bit more lacklustre. I definitely found the difficulty hard enough in the early-mid game and then... 

For Origin Characters, Shadowheart and Astarion are very 3-dimensional and flushed out. Minthara also has interesting depth. Karlach is 2-dimensional but is such a golden retriever of warmth that that is very ok. Gale and Wyll however... Lackluster. Though I did like the Mizora element of Wyll's story. 

Some comments for quality of life:
• Would love an encyclopedia or wiki in game of items, clues on where to find them (what quests), etc. Maybe toggle-able on 2nd-onward playthroughs. It really sucks to find out you locked yourself out of key items you were hoping to get. 
• In character creation, it would be really cool to see what each class gets with level ups. 
• Would love to be able to change body type and gender in magic mirror. Ex. took a female dragon body type thinking it was male (gender, voice and genital were all set to male). However all clothes fit as if to cover non-existent boobs and in-game postures are feminine. Kinda of broke the roleplaying for me and couldn't change it without completely restarting.
• The inventory... is kind of chaotic. Ways to make it more friendly or organized would be appreciated.

First impressions:   Disappointed

Honestly, if I had known this was click-to-move with turn-based combat I would never have bought it. For me, both those control modes are big time immersion destroyers. Constantly manipulating a floating camera to try to figure out where you are, where you are going, and what's going on around you is unnatural and often disorienting, as apposed to simply looking around yourself in the first person perspective like you do naturally (whether its true first person, through your own eyes; or third/first person over your shoulder.)  And turn based combat, as opposed to real time, is just plain tedious.

Okay, so admittedly that's more a critique of click-to-move with turn-based combat games in general than it is of Baldur's Gate 3 specifically. The game environment is gorgeous.  The character creation, character races, character sub-races and sub-classes give you endless options and is a lot of fun just to browse through. The game is pleasingly narrated where appropriate and the cut scenes seem to be well paced. Finally, the nod to classic D20 D&D is kind of cute and fun.

En fin; I'm disappointed because this game simply is not going to engender the kind of addictive immersion I look for in an RPG, but it's still worth playing on a more casual level.


Edit - 

Now six and a half hours into the game and I'm requesting a refund from Steam. I tried hard, wanted to like it, but the reality is I'm spending more time trying to wrestle the camera into submission than I am enjoying the game. And to add insult to injury the turn based combat just feels like it's running slow as molasses, both issues together make the game simply aggravating.  If you are a fan of turn based combat and third person, unhingd camera games you may find a way to forgive these shortcomings as the game is gorgeous and the story compelling.

Second edit: After deciding to get a refund for BG3 I learned that I had played a couple hours over the time limit for a refund, therefore, I kept playing and my frustration grew, until... I poked around on the community discussion forum, and specifically on a thread entitled "story mode is b.s." I should come as no surprise that there are numerous trolls and condescending gaming demi-gods injecting their own b.s. into the discussion but if you read through it there are a plethora of tips and tricks for anybody serious about figuring out game strategy and game mechanics. But probably the biggest thing that's made the game enjoyable is switching from keyboard and mouse controls to a game controller.  I still have issues with the camera mechanics, particularly when you are being attacked by mobs from overhead, and I still  maintain that if I had known this was a strategy/turn based combat game I would not have bought it in the first place. I am, however, getting a kick out of the whole D&D feel to the game. Overall I am definitely now enjoying the game and I'm switching my recommendation from a thumbs down to a qualified thumbs up. If it were stars I'd give it a three out of five.

A little bit late, GOTY trophy already won but I must review this game anyways. 
Being a gamer for decades and following the game industry since SNES and PS1 era, my opinion about this game is very positive. This game raised the bar for the game industry, it's the new standard, just like Skyrim did more than 10 years ago. I'm sure that this style and some of the elements in this game will be copied over and over, even on other genres.

Talking about game design I think this game is just wonderful. Larian Studios, which I've been following since Divinity Original Sin 1, did an awesome work on transcribing the feeling of a tabletop RPG session to a CRPG game. The D&D system is not a revolutionary system nowadays, even though is the most known RPG system, but the way Larian implemented the system on a computer game is revolutionary because: 
[list]
[*]They put a good effort on optimizing and adding new capabilities to their engine (it's the same used in Divinity Original Sin series). You can explore the game on different ways, you can talk to people, reading books, you can use your spells to maybe reach places you normally couldn't, you can swap your party members to get other dialogue options, you can use yours skills to detect hidden items, passages, get to alternative entrances, etc. There are so many tricks the game don't tell you, you just need to explore and try different approaches.
[*]The narrative -which I think it is the most superb thing they done here- is fantastic, there are so many ways to approach the same situation, depending on many factors... Things you've done before, things you want to do, your class, your race, the time you spent to get there. When this game released I had a mind blown when talking about it with friends, they did so many different things, they took different routes, they had dialogues that I hadn't... The sense of discovery is powerful, it makes you want to replay it over and over again. 
[/list]
Maybe the most brilliant thing about this game is the fact that it could be as much complex and flexible as you want.
You're new to RPGs or CRPGs? Okay, you can play it on Explorer Mode, which is more focused on narrative and less combat. Also, the fact that you can handle many many many situations only using dialogues helps a lot. Still a great game.
Maybe you're already a RPG fan but new to CRPGs, and that's ok, you can play it and it will offer a challenging combat system that is rewarding to learn, plus the narrative that I already gave my compliments. Still a great game.
Maybe you're hardcore RPG gamer, you've played other CRPGs before: Tactician and Honor Mode will make your brain explode to get through some battles. You can play the entire game on turn mode if you want to. Still a great game.
In my opinion, that's why the game burst the CRPG bubble. For the CPRG community BG3 borned good game, it used a well known and established system (D&D), with a new narrative standard for the game industry, running on a well crafted engine, but the fact that this game is as much complex and flexible as you want made this game reach people outside the CRPG community.
The icing on the cake of course its the production. Its so clear and palpable the love the Larian put on this... They cared for the artwork, the voice acting, the narrative... They cared for the community, and this is so rare nowadays.
The game stayed in early access for 2 years before the release, Larian listened to the community, listened the feedbacks and bug reports since the beginning and still doing this, they still correcting bugs and implementing suggestions, hotfixes. The game has 0 micro transactions and requires internet just to download patches or to play coop with friends (I really suggest you do that), even being the most accessible game by Larian, it still have that pre-internet feeling, the game will make you read and pay attention to details, it may guide you sometimes but it doesn't have that tiktok-generation-UI-style with arrows blinking, interactive objects blinking, objectives popping up in the screen every minute. The game just let you enjoy and discover it at your own pace.
I think Larian represented the best in our RPG community, they really love what they do just as we love the games.
They showed the game industry that we, as players, just want to play, we don't want to pay for the game and pay for anything "special" inside the game store or any kind of "additional content", it's so simple and we lost it during the years. And if the game takes some time to release that's ok, if we see that the studio is putting an effort to make it better, we don't need to rush game releases, specially if they literally don't work.

My only negative opinion is the resource consumption and the fact that it's not optimized yet. Yes, it's not a light game, you'll need a relatively powerful PC to run it. Act 3 still bugged and an overly heavy act. You'll probably notice some FPS drops and you may find bugs during your adventure, if that's the case you always have the option to report these bugs to the developer and they will answer you, just like they did to me.

At the end of the day, this is one of the best games I've played in my entire life. Thank you.

+ Items and Gearing from DnD. Which means you basically never really out level that really cool weapon you found. Because even a +1 is still a good bonus enough bonus if the weapon has a cool ability.
+ Most of the companions are great.
+ Super Varied. Playing an Evil campaign is almost basically a different game. Sure the over arching story is similar, but the people you befriend and the encounters are different. 
+ Complete freedom. Don't like a character? Push em off the cliff. Don't want to fight someone? Convince them to allow their students to murder them instead!
+ Charisma is king.
+ Mind flayer powers are weird, but fun most of the time. 
+ Certain subclasses are way better than they are in the PHB.
+ Rangers don't suck!
+ You can go almost anywhere. Really high cliff? Fly! place that seems like you can't get to? Jump! Honestly I've been so impressed by how easily I can go places. 
+A certain Companion got a new ending!
+New After party scene is absolutely fantastic. 
Negatives
- Certain spells are completely neutered from 5e Like polymorph and fly.
- Swimming and Flying freely just don't exist.
- Not enough subclasses. They basically just use the PHB, which is a shame.
- No artificer!
- 12 level severely limits certain classes. Come on man, I just wanted my find greater steed. Which would have just worked like a pet, but gimme my gryphon damn it!
- Ranger pets are quite limited. I would have liked at least a couple more options. (Like a giant frog. Granted I'm biased as hell.)

Literally the best RPG that's been released in YEARS. Do you miss how it felt to play video games when you were a teenager and they could really GET you? Disappointed with the direction of roleplaying for the past ten years? Then don't just get this, but grab DOS2 by Larian as well.

SPOILERS AHEAD:

Months later, I feel the need to modify my review. Ultimately it won't change whether or not I recommend the game, because I do genuinely hope for a revival of expansive, branching single player experiences, but I can't pretend like the experience months later is the same as it was on release. There's been a huge amount of micromanaging the reactions and storylines of the origin characters, evidently based on continued feedback throughout the release...which is not how games are meant to work. Lae'zel should not get less abrasive based on post-release feedback. The game is out. It's over. What is the significance of these characters if their whole demeanour can be changed based on a handful of pissy forum posts?

But my biggest beef with the game at this point is that while Lae'zel has had her dialogue endlessly sanded down to make her less hostile, while Halsin has gotten a thousand iterations of kisses and his entire perspective on certain character events changed, while one of Astarion's endings has been made toothless and twee to prefer players who wanted the bad ending with none of the consequences, Wyll's fans have continuously pointed out very easy choke points for his character that remain entirely unaddressed or even acknowledged or discussed. His warlock patron hangs around camp, unable to be dismissed, even after you schedule the break of his contract. He is constantly treated like a monster by his father, a conflict which is resolved by his father going "oopsie doopsie" and Wyll insisting that he was never upset nor affected at all by this intimate betrayal by his only family. Wyll is turned into a devil in the early game, a change in model which is significant from his human form but not significant from the tiefling model. Unable to actually hear or read dialogue, fans assumed he was being mean to tiefling Tavs by being at all bothered by his forced transformation, and so rather than change the model at all they just cut a huge chunk of his dialogue where he talked about being too self-conscious to join the party.

Wyll, an origin character, doesn't have a sex scene. Halsin and Minthara, two side characters, do. Mizora, his primary antagonist who again, you cannot remove from your camp, does. My entire experience with the act 3 Wyll romance has been triggering his final romance scene entirely without warning or prompt (he didn't even have the ! over his head, I just went to talk to him and it triggered) which has ended with rolling around on the ground fully clothed and an abrupt cut back to the inn we were staying in. He doesn't kiss you in the epilogue. Larian seems to have entirely given up on him, which is frustrating as we receive roughly ten thousand micro-patches to [checks notes] change a missable note that a major antagonist writes to a dead npc that's hidden in his basement to cut the erotic content. To this day I don't know why anyone's brain power was dedicated to that when Wyll's quest never seems entirely sure whether his father is dead or alive at any given moment.

It's been disheartening to learn as patches roll out that Wyll's major issues are going to go entirely unaddressed, while everyone else's character remains in constant flux depending on how a handful of people react to them. The game released in August, and again I have to ask: what significance do any of these characters have if they are either in a constant state of change depending on what players prefer, or else entirely ignored? What are they telling me about the plot? The latest patch notes contained a note about how Lae'zel can be told to make her own decisions post-Netherbrain: Wyll will not personally chose whether or not he leaves his father for dead, or renews his contract with his patron. YOU have to choose. There's not even an option to ask him to choose and then to have him bounce the decision back to you, or even for him to ask you to choose because he can't in the first place (which would also suck, but would at least address that he's the only companion with no real agency in his personal quest), YOU decide whether to kill your friend's dad to get him out from under the thumb of his patron: a decision with NO consequences, as you can save his dad anyway, he never loses his warlock powers unless you manually respec him, and, I cannot stress this enough, MIZORA WILL NOT LEAVE MY CAMP.

Ultimately I truly hope they never make another game like they've made this one. I was excited about this game in EA and curious to uncover all the possible branches on release. Now, I just want to experience a story that Larian wrote instead of the Larian forums.

I won't mince words: at first I was very annoyed by this game - I liked the setting and the characters but the fights felt unfair and like the game would fuck me over with random bullshit but after I got used to it I started understanding

This game wants you to be creative, it rewards you for thinking outside the box and outsmarting the DM. It's a game that almost never says no and encourages to go with whatever crazy idea you might have.
If you think that you can cheese a fight you most likely can - hoard explosive barrels and end the fight in one turn? Sure. Polymorph the boss into a sheep and shove him into the void? Why not. Exploit a very specific magical item to kill enemies by doing literally nothing? Go for it.

Or you can just play in Explorer mode and swing your sword at things until they're dead - don't let some gamer dudebro shame you for playing on easy.

I remember learning D&D in the 80's. I remember getting killed by a Brownie on the road to my first dungeon. I cannot recall how many adventures stalled in a bar fight while trying to get my party together "organically" because the rogue and the mage always insisted on roleplaying evil A%^&oles.

I mention these things because I don't think I even played a computer game that came close to capturing the good parts of those days. And I include the original BG's in this. They were amazing games, but honestly this one recaptures the spirit and feel of tabletop D&D better.

First of all, I want to clarify that today, 08/12/2023, Baldur's Gate III has been the winner of the Game of the Year. Now, I leave you with the "small" review, greetings, adventurers.

When a game makes you think about the characters, the choices you've made, the choices you still want to make, the next place you'll want to explore, and the overall progression of the story AFTER you've closed the game and maybe you're in bed or away from home and you can't wait to play again, then something is going terribly right.

This game attracts you in a way that I have rarely felt in anything, it is a different experience, a different reality, it is your own life seen through the eyes of the narrator and your character. You and your character are one.

I'm not a D&D player myself. That's why I barely know the rules, but the game gives you enough information to orient yourself and over time you learn things "playfully".

The world in the game seems so incredibly alive. You never feel like you're "working on" quests because even the quest log is written with written hints, as if you were taking notes on things yourself.

Wandering around the world, you discover something interesting around every corner and get distracted by something on the way to a quest and then you poke around here and there and suddenly half an hour has passed and you have to remember where you're really going. because you've discovered a hidden place that you absolutely wanted to explore "just briefly."

Another point to highlight are the characters. It feels like traveling with "people who live and feel." When you go around the world, depending on the combination you make in the group, people also have things to talk about with each other, some understand each other and joke, others get angry, comments are made here and there. It looks "real." And I don't even want to start with the personal relationships you make with your colleagues. Sometimes you forget that it's just a pre-programmed game.

And then the moral choices you have to make! A simple encounter with an NPC can trigger a powerful story that will leave you not knowing who to believe. Should you believe anyone and who you help and who you don't? Should you help anyone at all? Everything is possible, nothing is mandatory. The possibilities seem endless.

Basically, I just started playing (I'm 30 hours into the game) and I've only seen part of the world so far, I can't even begin to imagine what it will be like when I get to town.

I'm sure I've forgotten a number of things I'd like to praise. Come to think of it, I really don't know how I'm going to justify buying another full-price game in the future given the quantity and, more importantly, the quality you get for what you spend here. I know... it hurts to spend such a large amount of money, but $20,000 (about €60) for this game is really not enough when you see what you get (a finished game with hardly any bugs, nothing to buy through DLC, without microtransactions, you don't have to be in a season pass every month thereafter). You get a game that is just plain fun.

I could have given a thumbs up and left it at that. That's a good thing because no one will read this review anyway. But this GOTY deserves as many words as possible about it. I haven't even begun to do it justice, I could talk about it for much longer.

100% purchase recommendation for the game of the year 2023

I really enjoy this game. If you're a fan of DND, you're definitely going to like this game. The story is amazing, and the characters are really fleshed out and have really good backstories. You can do so many things in this game too, it seems like the options are endless. i love the romance, it's such a good addition. If you even just enjoy dating sims, I feel like you'd still love this game. This game is really worth it, and worth your time. My only complaint is with the customization; it is good, but you can only pick from presets for the face. You can't edit individual things like the height of the eyes, for example, or the type of nose, another example. I also feel like there could be more options with things like eye colours, tattoos, makeup, and piercings. I'd love to see an all-white eye colour! I'd also love to see things like face piercings other than nose piercings, or even having different categories for piercings, like an ear piercing category, a nose piercing category, etc. Or, where you could choose mulitple piercings. In conclusion, this game is worth both your time and money, and you won't regret buying it!

Masterclass Adventuring: Baldur's Gate 3 Sets a New Standard for RPG Excellence

Introduction:
Baldur's Gate 3 stands as a towering achievement in the realm of role-playing games, seamlessly blending intricate storytelling, strategic gameplay, and breathtaking visuals into an unforgettable gaming experience. From its gripping narrative to its immersive world and deep character customization, every aspect of Baldur's Gate 3 exudes excellence. In this review, I will delve into the myriad reasons why Baldur's Gate 3 deserves its status as a modern masterpiece.

Captivating Narrative:
At the heart of Baldur's Gate 3 lies a gripping narrative that immerses players in a world of danger, intrigue, and magic. Set in the iconic Forgotten Realms universe, the game follows a band of unlikely heroes as they embark on a perilous journey to unravel the mysteries of a sinister force known as the Absolute. The story is masterfully crafted, filled with memorable characters, unexpected twists, and moral dilemmas that challenge players to make difficult choices with far-reaching consequences. From the bustling streets of Baldur's Gate to the treacherous depths of the Underdark, every location is steeped in lore and atmosphere, inviting players to lose themselves in a world of epic adventure.

Deep Character Customization:
Baldur's Gate 3 offers an unprecedented level of character customization, allowing players to create their own unique protagonist from a wide range of races, classes, and backgrounds. Whether you prefer to play as a cunning rogue, a powerful wizard, or a righteous paladin, the game accommodates a diverse array of playstyles and character builds. The depth of customization extends beyond mere aesthetics, with players able to shape their character's abilities, skills, and personality through meaningful choices and interactions throughout the game. From forging alliances with companions to navigating complex social dynamics and moral quandaries, Baldur's Gate 3 puts the power of choice firmly in the hands of the player, ensuring that no two playthroughs are ever the same.

Strategic Gameplay:
Baldur's Gate 3 features a deep and rewarding combat system that emphasizes strategic thinking, tactical positioning, and creative problem-solving. Battles are turn-based affairs, with players able to command their party members in real-time to outmaneuver and outwit their opponents. Environmental interactions, terrain effects, and dynamic spellcasting add layers of depth to the combat, encouraging players to experiment with different strategies and approaches to overcome challenges. Whether facing off against hordes of enemies in epic battles or engaging in tense one-on-one duels with powerful foes, the combat in Baldur's Gate 3 is as exhilarating as it is satisfying.

Breathtaking Visuals and Immersive Sound Design:
From its stunning vistas to its meticulously detailed character models and animations, Baldur's Gate 3 is a visual feast for the senses. The game's richly realized world is brought to life with breathtaking beauty and attention to detail, with every location, creature, and spell effect rendered with astonishing fidelity. The immersive sound design further enhances the atmosphere, with dynamic soundscapes, ambient noise, and stirring musical scores that evoke a sense of wonder and adventure. Whether exploring the sprawling wilderness, delving into ancient ruins, or engaging in heated combat, the sights and sounds of Baldur's Gate 3 combine to create an immersive gaming experience like no other.

Conclusion:
In conclusion, Baldur's Gate 3 is nothing short of a masterpiece, offering a rich and immersive RPG experience that sets a new standard for excellence in the genre. From its captivating narrative and deep character customization to its strategic gameplay and breathtaking visuals, every aspect of the game is executed with meticulous attention to detail and a passion for storytelling. Whether you're a veteran of the Baldur's Gate series or a newcomer to the world of Dungeons & Dragons, Baldur's Gate 3 offers an unforgettable journey into a world of magic, mystery, and adventure that is not to be missed.

The game plays like a lazy Dungeon Master who doesn't keep notes and is railroading you the heck out of it. The main beef I got with the game is that I make choices, and not a second later the game will COMPLETELY IGNORE SAID CHOICES... One of the many examples is *SPOILERS AHEAD* Last Light Inn. This corrupted winged Flaming Fist is coming to abduct the Selunite priestess, his minions knock her out, and suddenly the game cuts off mid encounter to give me a cutscene of my WHOLE PARTY witnessing the dude abducting the priestess, then even further proceeds on taking my party out of the Inn without any reason at all. Furthermore I explicitly DID NOT say anything about the Gith Artefact in my party's possession to the Harper Leader inside the inn, yet in future conversations she knows for some reason. I reset to my last save outside the inn, I defeat the ex-flaming fist, then get a quest for The Urge to kill the Selunite. I kill her, and guess what? The game pops a cutscene with my whole party strolling out of the Inn while the magic shield perishes and discusses with the Harper Leader the death of the priestess. Like, why? I didn't want to do any of that. I just wanted to stealth kill her and get out...

So it's a no from me.

One would argue that adding new content is good, but the truth is they just extended the EA period and outed and unfinished game, which by no means will get fixed by any amount of polishing because there's a shitton cut content in Act 3 and the general plot starts falling on its own right after Act 2. 

Act 1, as good as it is, feels like an entirely different game, it's design is grand and ambiguous, but the reality is that Larian's choice to use this variant of the Divinity Engine for such a grand sequel as Baldur's Gate 3 probably made them give 0 shits about the General storytelling and the implications a high level adventure taking place in Faerun carry. Wizards suck, spellcasting is butchered in this game because it would be an enormous strain implicating what a Wizard is capable of doing in this engine, hence why verticality doesn't exist, because Larian chose comfort making a cosplay DOS game instead of making a Baldur's Gate game.

This is the best game I've ever played, hands down. The complex characters and worldbuilding are incredible, and the insanely intricate personalization and choice are on a level I've been waiting for a game to reach for years! And I love the companions so much :)

The world is beautifully built with tons of little secrets and great storytelling. The majority of characters in this game (companions or NPC's) have unique stories and personalities. Different and sometimes morally challenging choices keep dialogue fresh and exciting throughout the game and choices made do often have an impact to how the story plays out. 
Combat feels very good in terms of difficulty. On normal encounters are difficult enough to require thinking about the situation and the next move to make. Once you know how the game works the higher difficulties will keep challenging you to think of new strategies.

After that being said I would also like to exert some criticism: 

Act 3 looses a lot of the games drive. I manage to get to level 12 at the beginning of Act 3 very consistently and then it feels like everything I do in Act 3 is just prolonging the end of the game. Maybe partly to that a lot of quest lines that sound very interesting become "well let's just do this quickly before closing out the game". 

Having romance options in a game is fine but in BG3 it feels very forced. You are constantly being pressed toward romance dialogue without really being able to avoid it. I would like to just not be bothered with long cut scenes and multiple dialogue choices by almost every party member. Personally I would like it if the player had to initiate romance. That way it is a player choice to engage with this part of the game.

I prefer playing D&D without the sexual elements.

BG3 is the best in its genre, featuring complex combat, an intricate build system, outstanding writing, and epic cutscenes.

Are you the type of player who'd never proceed in the Main Quest & storyline until every last pixel of the current local map has been revealed & every single chest been lockpicked? Congratulations, then you have found your very happy final resting place. It is so vast & so complete & filled with surprising side-quests, easter-eggs & countless hilarious NPCs, that at some point it does really feel as if you'd spent all your life there already. As regards the gameplay & technical realisation, it is simply Divinity II perfected. And what more could one ever wish for? In early early access I felt a little anxious that the D&D-ruleset might conflict with Larian/D2 mechanics but instead it rather feels like D&D was perfected, too. By implementing those actual dice-rolls as a fully-animated part of the gameplay-flow, devs have really managed to destill the best from both worlds. Is there anything left to wish for? Yes, even more dialogue, please. Especially in the personal relationships with the companions it can feel dull at times after a while. But, naturally, you can only pack so many hours of soundlines into a game, & the sheer amount of quotes does not lack, admittedly. Also, individual situational quotes of each character can be discovered in replay-sessions, which is certainly huge fun. It is just in the inbetweens, where it can still feel lonely due to lack of anything but the ever same line to talk about. You will also have the same troubles to keep any overview over all those thrillions of items in you inventory as in any Larian game, but that's a ok. Nostalgia makes up for the boredom of sorting sessions. Fully recommended for old-school Roleplayers, BG- & NWN-veterans & puzzle-fans. Not recommended for grinders. This is a game where you want to read journal-entries AND dialogue-lines AND in-game documents. Or you will really get lost & eventually no longer understand what is going on at all. 
And that's what I love most about it.

An experience I won't easily forget. Picking this up is one of the best decisions ever.

If you've ever played any RPG game and loved it,  you'll love this one. I played World of Warcraft for 10 years, and the Zelda series is my favorite of all time, and I've found BG3 to another game I can play over and over again. I didn't complete all of the available story content on my first play through, and it still felt like a complete and satisfying story. I'm on my second play through now, and having done all of the side quests this time, I've just grown to love the game even more. The ability to play as origin characters, the changes in the story based on your romance options, and the changes in dialogue based on your race/class all make this game immersive and fun each time you play. Knowledge of Dungeons and Dragons or the rest of the Baldur's Gate series isn't necessary at all to play and enjoy this game. 

I will say that anyone that is fairly new to gaming will have a bit more of a learning curve to learn some of the most basic functions of this game. While the tutorial is very helpful, it does still demand a level of game literacy not every player will come to the game with. Guides online will help bridge that gap in knowledge, but there's nothing to teach people that they can pick up and move objects in the world in real time. Basic things like that gamers take for granted are missing in the instructions, but I suppose that's also part of the fun of figuring a puzzle out during a game like this. 

Overall, I highly recommend this game!4

Baldur's Gate 3 is not just a game—it's an unforgettable journey filled with excitement, laughs, and plenty of surprises. Dive into a world where every choice you make shapes the story, and every encounter brings new challenges and hilarity.

Customize your character to your heart's content, then join a cast of unforgettable companions as you battle monsters, unravel mysteries, and maybe even accidentally set fire to a few taverns along the way.

Sure, there might be a few bugs here and there, but honestly, they just add to the charm. Who doesn't love the occasional unexpected flying goblin?

So, whether you're a seasoned adventurer or brand new to the realm of role-playing games, Baldur's Gate 3 offers an experience that's as thrilling as it is accessible. Get ready to embark on the adventure of a lifetime—you won't regret it!

I've never played the pen and paper D&D, but I played my first computer version in 1990, and as I recall, it was pretty straight forward design for people who had never played the P&P, and was easy to learn pretty quickly. 
This is my first time playing a computer D&D that follows so closely with the Pen and Paper rules that it ended up being a real learning curve for me, but I managed to catch on quick enough to begin to understand what I'm doing with some authority.  I kind of knew what class I wanted to play, but after making 3 characters, and talking with a friend, I made a fourth that I will be sticking with. Even though you can kind of make some bad decisions that will affect the story, it's still fun to play it through to see what your choices will pan out to be. I recommend it to anybody who enjoys D&D types of games in any capacity, and hope you make sure to give it a little time to catch on to the rules of the game, and you won't regret it.

At the risk of sounding like a Larian Fanboy, this is the best game to come out since Original Sin 2, this is a "proper" RPG where choices are properly tracked and things can actually come and bite you in the backside, sometimes to hilarious effect, not only is this a fantastic RPG but it's an amazing DND game, it's a hoarders paradise (thank you to whoever implemented the "send to camp" button, much love) and while the stealing in the game is a little broken right now, I cannot help myself every time I come across a trader. Only about 30 hours in so far but the story is compelling and I'm massively enjoying it and i'm enjoying the pace as I like to take things a little slow and explore everywhere and do every side quest and collect everything I can first time around.

If you even remotely like RPG's or DND, you MUST buy this game, if you cannot stand turn based then maybe don't but other than that you can't go wrong.

Only thing that has remotely annoyed me is sometimes when I am trying to attack someone in combat and I click as my character is moving it will update the path and sometimes make them travel there rather than attack because the camera is moving with the character who is being controlled. I imagine this will be updated with some patches to smooth things out.

Well done Larian for another masterpiece.

Positives:
- Fully voice acted (minus player character) which adds a lot of immersion
- Play how you want -> can be creative, can be straightforward, can be good natured, can be evil, lots of options. A proper RPG (but its not a sandbox, so be mindful)
- Mostly bug free. At the time of writing this I have not encountered any game breaking bugs, only some minor glitches and items/skills not working correctly, but it has not been a major issue
- Visually stunning

Negatives:
- Some performance issues in Act 3 (framedrops, weird textures)
- With so many paths available, FOMO is real and its easy to get overwhelmed when starting Act 3
- Some classes/subclasses feel underpowered compared to others
- Might be hard to get into without prior knowledge of tabletop RPGs or similar mechanics


Overall an extremely good game if you like RPGs and are generally familiar with tabletop RPGs like Dungeons & Dragons. All negatives are minor for me. I totally recommend the game.

I've now been playing 90+ hours and I'm still in ACT1, I've been trying to force myself to just let things happen but I just can't, there are so many possibilities, so many options, so many builds and I am just stuck redoing my campaign again and again because "WHAT IF I DID THIS INSTEAD". With every new start I'm still loving every moment of it, I know I will eventually make it to ACT2 and even finish the game (multiple times maybe to see the different endings, and hopefully the 2nd round and the ones that come after will be faster than my first/current), how long that is going to take I do not know but I will definately have had many hours of GREAT ENTERTAINMENT for the 60 dollars spend.

Def recommend.
